story:
THREADS DANCE PROJECT

Connecting the movement, music, and meaning of being human....

In 2010, founder Karen L. Charles started Threads to realize a dream and memorialize her beloved father--his generosity, his wisdom, and his light. Since then, Threads has grown into an 11-member professional dance company that needs your help in producing its 2015 performance season: 

Warriors of Light, inspired by the literary work of Paulo Coelho.

This evening of live dance and music will premiere November 6-7th, 2015 at the Cowles Center for Dance & the Performing Arts in Minneapolis, MN.       

We have made significant progress against our fundraising goals so far,  but need your help in fully translating Paulo Coelho's words onto the stage. 

             Make a donation today and help us reach our goal of 

                                         “Seven for the Season!”

WHY WE NEED YOU

As you may have heard, it’s been a busy time here at Threads Dance Project. Auditions have introduced 4 new dancers to the Threads family, preparations are well underway for our Dance Connections Youth Summer Camp, and we are eager to begin rehearsals for this fall’s premiere of Warriors of Light.

This is only the start of our continued work  to serve our community and supporters. In response to demand from parents and teachers, we're launching our first ever dance summer camp. Emerging choreographers and hungry audiences have requested a second round of Tapestries (2.0 anticipated for Spring 2016). The year would be incomplete without our fall production which annually engages hundreds of individuals across barriers of age, race, or class from throughout the Twin Cities. 

Threads performances are well known opportunities for any and everyone to join together as a true community in appreciation of the evocative power of dance. What important work!

But this level of programming costs money...In fact, our organization has to raise over $100,000 through ticket sales, grants, and other sources each year just to cover some of the costs. It is at times like these, that we must depend on donors like you to help fill in the gap and keep the work moving forward.

IMPACT 

 With your help in raising $7,000 by June 30th Threads will be able to:

  • Provide much-needed scholarships to our Dance Connections Summer program
  • Collaborate with the most talented and innovative artists for our season performances
  • Subsidize comp tickets to Warriors of Light for Minneapolis families in partnership with Project Success
  • Present 3 new emerging choreographers in Tapestries 2.0
  • Begin planning for our upcoming 5th Anniversary performances, Fall 2016

RISKS & CHALLENGES

2015 will be a challenging year as we work to expand our programming in the Twin Cities while maintaining the high quality of our main season performances. Warriors of Light also presents a unique creative challenge for Artistic Director Karen L. Charles in that the work draws its inspiration from a literary text rather than the historical events and human emotions our audiences are used to. However: 

  • Previous youth outreach engagements include residencies with youth at WISE Charter School in Minneapolis, lec dems at the FAIR school, and sold out low-cost student matinees
  •  Our dancers are experienced, engaging, and knowledgeable teachers--eager to share their love of dance with young people
  • Influential foundations and corporations including The McKnight Foundation, Jerome Foundation, and Best Buy have already contributed to partially sponsor Warriors of Light and our efforts to expand our community impact

All this leads us to feel confident in our ability to produce Warriors of Light as well as offer increased outreach to artists and the general public throughout the year. But only with your help...

We understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially, but please use the tools on this page to share our campaign with everyone you know and those who can.

Thank you!
story_txt:
THREADS DANCE PROJECT

Connecting the movement, music, and meaning of being human....



In 2010, founder Karen L.
Charles started Threads to realize a dream and memorialize her beloved
father--his generosity, his wisdom, and his light. Since then, Threads has
grown into an 11-member professional dance company that needs your help in
producing its 2015 performance season: 
Warriors of Light, inspired by
the literary work of Paulo Coelho. 
This evening of live
dance and music will premiere November
6-7th, 2015 at the Cowles Center for Dance & the Performing Arts in
Minneapolis, MN.       

We have made significant progress against our fundraising goals so far,  but need your help in fully translating Paulo Coelho's words onto the stage. 

             Make a donation today and help us
reach our goal of 

                                         “Seven for the Season!”
WHY WE NEED YOU

As you may have heard, it’s been a busy time here at Threads
Dance Project. Auditions have introduced 4 new dancers to the Threads family,
preparations are well underway for our Dance Connections Youth Summer Camp, and
we are eager to begin rehearsals for this fall’s premiere of Warriors of Light.
This is only the start of our continued work  to serve our community and supporters. In response to demand from parents and teachers, we're launching our first ever dance summer camp. Emerging choreographers and hungry audiences have requested a second round of Tapestries (2.0 anticipated for Spring 2016). The year would be incomplete without our fall production which annually engages hundreds of individuals across barriers of age, race, or class from throughout the Twin Cities. 
Threads performances are well known opportunities for any and everyone to join together as a true community in appreciation of the evocative power of dance. What important work!

But this level of programming costs money...In fact, our organization has to raise over $100,000 through ticket sales, grants, and other sources each year just to cover some of the costs. It is at times like these, that we must depend on donors like you to help fill in the gap and keep the work moving forward.

IMPACT 


 With your help in
raising $7,000 by June 30th Threads will be able to:




Provide
much-needed scholarships to our Dance Connections Summer program


Collaborate
with the most talented and innovative artists for our season performances


Subsidize
comp tickets to Warriors of Light for
Minneapolis families in partnership with Project Success


Present
3 new emerging choreographers in Tapestries 2.0


Begin
planning for our upcoming 5th Anniversary performances, Fall 2016




RISKS & CHALLENGES

2015 will be a challenging year as we work to expand our programming in the Twin Cities while maintaining the high quality of our main season performances. Warriors of Light also presents a unique creative challenge for Artistic Director Karen L. Charles in that the work draws its inspiration from a literary text rather than the historical events and human emotions our audiences are used to. However: 

  Previous youth outreach engagements include residencies with youth at WISE Charter School in Minneapolis, lec dems at the FAIR school, and sold out low-cost student matinees
 Our dancers are experienced, engaging, and knowledgeable teachers--eager to share their love of dance with young people Influential foundations and corporations including The McKnight Foundation, Jerome Foundation, and Best Buy have already contributed to partially sponsor Warriors of Light and our efforts to expand our community impact    All this leads us to feel confident in our ability to produce Warriors of Light as well as offer increased outreach to artists and the general public throughout the year. But only with your help...
We understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially, but please use the tools on this page to share our campaign with everyone you know and those who can.
Thank you!

story:
UPDATED!

We are in need of less funds now that the building has changed hands, however we will continue to provide theatre until we can find a home.

We are raising money for our small community theatre that was established last year (2014) in Ashland, Oregon and has since then presented 6 full productions and various readings, of new and established works. Now on our road to find a permanent home in Ashland we are facing rental costs, continued funding for future shows and royalties and general operating expenses.

Our next projects that we are looking to present are an original stage play titled "You Are Weak, You Are Strong" by Artistic Director Peter Wickliffe, that deals with the inner battle many of us face between good and evil, Satan and God and ourselves. This project will tour around the Rogue Valley to any venue that can spare a space for us. And after this we are looking to present "Meredith Willson's The Music Man" at Ashland's Armory. On top of this we want to be able to present these performances at the lowest cost to the public to help further cultivate theatre and make it more about theatre and less about the money. Unfortunately money is a necessity in this world, so we are instead asking for any amount that can be spared.

So what do we need and how much? Well let me break it down:

  • Space Rental: $2,000 for space for performances
  • Prodcution Costs: $200
  • Royalties for The Music Man: $1,300 for 3 performances

We want a permanent home for a community theatre in Ashland and also want to be able to keep this small, struggling theatre on its feet and in doing so be able to cultivate more theatre in the area. We all need and could use theatre and what it brings, despite our financial limitations or struggles. Please look at what we have done and what we want to do. Theatre is about the heart and life and dreaming bigger. Give others the gift of dreams and memories.

Thank You All!

story:
Short Summary


  • We are HIT THE STEP!!!  Our dance workshop includes an outstanding faculty of dance teachers currently instructing Hip Hop, Jazz Funk, and Contemporary at some of the biggest dance studios in the world including Millennium Dance Complex, Movement Lifestyle, Debbie Reynolds Dance Studio and The Edge Performing Arts Center all in Los Angeles, California.  Individually, we are giving students tools to pursue dance professionally or giving them movement simply because they love to dance and we figured we could make more of an impact combining forces as one entity.  Dance is a huge part of who we are but we are also so connected to art, which is why we want to eventually incorporate music, fashion, acting and singing into our workshop bringing all forms of art together to create an unbelievable experience for students.
  • The goal of this campaign is to be able to provide start up money for this new business as well as funds to travel to students that are unable to come and train with us in LA.  This campaign will fund our first Tour leg on the East Coast reaching 4 cities in just 5 days.  Proper funding is crucial in making sure we can efficiently  create this amazing and unique convention. While a family member was able to generously fund our first city we traveled to last month, it is important for us to raise the rest of the money ourselves for this future project.  The money we raise would also be able to repay the family member who has given to help start this company.
  • HIT THE STEP is not just a convention to us.  Every single member considers each other family, as we all moved from different parts of the globe to live in LA to pursue our dreams.  When we met, we instantly formed friendships and began our incredible journeys together, helping each other reach our most thought about goals.  We struggled to the point of giving up but because we supported each other, we were able to overcome all obstacles and do what we truly love.  To have this campaign funded would mean the world because a small idea that was talked about years ago between friends that were living on each others couches just to survive and pursue our passions would actually come to life.  We believe anything is possible and we want to share our story and talents with the world.


What We Need & What You Get


  • We would need a total of $15,000 to fund HIT THE STEP's 5 day, 4 City US Teaching Tour.  Faculty $6,200 ($450/class @ 12 classes; $50/day for per diem @ 6 ppl; Tour Manager $500);  Hotel $2,400 ($300/nights @ 2 rooms for 4 nights);  Cinematographer $130; Flights $4,560 (LAX to PA @ 6ppl $1500; PA to NY @ 6ppl $900; NJ to BOS @ 6ppl $360; BOS to LAX @ 6ppl $1800);  Introductory workshop flights $1,190.80.  Perks/Shipping $519.20
  • PERKS!! Every donation will receive some sort of "Perk" whether it's apparel from our faculty members clothing line, a dance lesson or a thank you card for your generosity.  Ultimately, we want people to be a part of building something from the ground up, because together, we are all so powerful and have the ability to create whatever we desire.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we will teach local workshops until we have enough money to support our cause!!  The money we raise will be saved until we reach our goal.  We are so thankful for any and every donation we receive and are very grateful for the opportunity to raise money for this special convention.

The Impact


  • Our project will change the lives of students across the world and it is already beginning.  Our faculty works with some of the most successful artists and choreographers in the industry but have the most humble hearts.  At some point, we were all told some harsh things in pursuing this difficult industry but our love for the arts pushed us into becoming respected in our community and on the road to success.  When this project takes off, our possibilities are endless as far as the impact we will have on the lives of many.
  • With everything going on in the world, dance has been able to lift us up and empower us to appreciate every moment.  We want to give people the opportunity to feel real emotion and express themselves in whatever way necessary.  We believe dance is the universal language able to release any tension or negative energy that is felt.  We want to spread love from one side of the globe to another through our art and our faculty's loving, infectious energy! 
  • We have danced/choreographed for talents such as Beyonce, Rihanna, Justin Timberlake, Nicki Minaj, Fergie, Gwen Stefani, Ne-Yo, Prince, Justin Bieber, Becky G and appeared on TV award shows, talk shows, and music videos. Our faculty, separately, has taught in countries such as London, Amsterdam, Spain, Mexico, Poland, Italy, Australia, China, Tokyo and all over the US.   Travelling has made us who we are and being able to travel is a dream come true for us. With this convention, we will be able to visit these places regularly giving endless opportunities to students and ourselves.  As much as we inspire students, some of our biggest inspirations are our students and we couldn't do what we do without them.

Risks & Challenges

  • Being professional dancers/choreographers, we face risk and rejection on a daily basis.  Going from an audition, to taking class, to teaching class, to our normal job can be the most exhausting thing we will ever experience.  We spend endless amounts of time preparing for jobs we may never get in hopes we get that one chance or opportunity that will send us on our way.  But it never stops.  Shifting from one job to another is our specialty while and we must be able to transform into different characters who are able to adapt and grow from each experience.  We compare ourselves naturally as we all do in any industry but it is a lot more personal when it comes to dance.  We are exposed and because of that, we are sensitive beings but some of the strongest beings we know.  We understand there will be bumps in the road to achieving our goals, but there is nothing we can't handle.  With every failure we're endured, every time we've been knocked down, we've prevailed stronger and more determined. 
  • There is a huge risk in setting up Conventions.  There is a lot of cost as far as paying for the venue, cinematographer, talents, accommodations, and travel.  Once that is paid for, you then have to get the students to come to the classes.  We never know  how many students will come to the workshops, thus not knowing if we can profit until we get enough pre-registered students or walk-ins the day of.  However, because of our wonderful reputation within our community, we are able to pack our classes and sometimes even sell out due to venue capacity!  We are up to handle any task that comes our way and we love a challenge!  We truly love what we do so no matter what happens, nothing will stop us.

Other Ways You Can Help


  • We understand not everyone is financially able to help and that's OK!  We primarily know artists and they aren't the most financially stable creatures.  That said, any amount makes a difference and we would love for your support in any way possible!  We are getting there and we're so thankful to be able to see this day!  If you are unable to donate, we ask you help us spread the word about our movement or follow us and our journey.  Social media is huge in this time so we would love you to spread our voice and be a part of HIT THE STEP!  Our website is www.hitthestep.com  Instagram/Twitter @Hitthestep ;  Youtube: Hitthestep
  • You can also use Indiegogo's share tools to spread the word!

story:
Heathers: The Musical Book, Music, and Lyrics by Laurence O'Keefe and Kevin Murphy

Synopsis

Heathers: the Musical tells the story of Veronica Sawyer, a high school senior attempting to navigate the world of social politics before she graduates. Enter the Heathers: a group of three girls all with the same first name. They are untouchable queen bees. Veronica wants to befriend them, but her boyfriend J.D. has another, more sinister plan. 

What We Need

  • Rights/Licensing/Royalties: Our script and score are the wonderful art of talented individuals who deserve recognition for their work. Licensing fees assure that they receive proper validation. Samuel French, Inc. owns the rights to the musical. 
  • Scores/Scripts: Our actors and musicians need these to create a wonderful performance.
  • Costumes/Props: Our production's goal is to transport the audience into the world of the 1980s and utilizes many costumes and props to do so. 
  • Set Design: We are building a set from scratch and thus need material like wood and paint to start construction.
  • Publicity: We need posters and programs to create a buzz around campus. 
  • Any extra funds raised will be distributed amongst these categories. 

The Impact

Theater is a great way for students to get involved on campus and build skills for use in their professional lives! Live performance teaches thorough text and character analysis, public speaking and the importance of the ensemble and breeds confidence, charisma, and determination. 

Risks & Challenges

There are always risks inherent in live theater but we do what we can to minimize these. A common phrase for us is "the show must go on", and with your donation it will, regardless of any challenges that may arise. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • "Like" our page on Facebook!
  • Share our indiegogo page!

story:
At bS Theatre, we seek to serve the community through affordable and engaging performances of classic works of theatre. We use non-traditional casting, modern edits and a realistic, open style to give focus to the timeless plots and characters at the heart of every piece.

Our productions are funded entirely by fundraising and donations. EVERY dollar we receive directly funds our current and future shows and helps us to maintain our commitment to keeping admission 100% free, always.

We use non-traditional casting, modern edits and a realistic, open style to give focus to the timeless plots and characters at the heart of every piece.Our productions are funded entirely by fundraising and donations. EVERY dollar we receive directly funds our current and future shows and helps us to maintain our commitment to keeping admission 100% free, always.

story:
Inspired by the works of Nikolai Gogol, Cocooned in Kazan explores the complexities of an indecisive man, infamous in Kazan for ‘jilting’ young brides. He yearns to fill the void of his beloved mother and to claim the large inheritance she left him, which he can only receive once ‘happily’ married. The pressure is on for both him and his 'loyal' servant to find the right suitor, all before the leaves of Autumn begin to fall. Throughout this chaotic rat race, we see the hardships of a man whose reputation precedes him in a quest for marriage.

This will be our first tour together as a company, which will take us from London all the way to Chicago. We will be performing 'Cocooned in Kazan' over 20 times and we really need your help!

As we are touring in the US for 6 weeks, costs for an independent theatre company are huge and our small budget simply can not cover it. We have already raised over £800 which has helped us tremendously and is dearly appreciated. However, we need to raise a little more to really help get this show on the road.

If we reach our target of £1400 our flights, accommodation, set, props, costume and marketing and the remaining costs for touring our show will be covered.

We would be sincerely grateful for any donations.

Thank you

RKF

story:
What is the work about?

Muscle memory is a contemporary dance performance piece that investigates the capacity in which our bodies can carry memories, positive or negative, triumphant and failed. The piece involves a creative process that utilizes different methods to physicalize each performers' personal memory, through sharing a memory of intimacy, a memory of being scared or feeling overwhelming joy or a memory of utter sadness, the choreography of the piece attempts to take our memories and bring them back to life through movement. The result is both literal and abstract choreography that unfolds as a movement journal, conveying memory in its most visceral form, through flesh, bone and breath.

Who are we?

My name is Marlowe Porter, I am a dance artist dedicated to creating and performing in engaging dance works that impact the way we think about ourselves as physical beings and that deter from  mind-body dichotomies. I am choreographing and performing in this piece along with 5 amazing collaborators - Mary-Dora Bloch-Hansen, Jessie Garon, Julie McLachlan, Amanda Pye and Caroline Sawyer. We are all practicing professional dance artists that dedicate an enormous amount of energy, time and soul to this important art form.

Why we need your help?

We have been graciously accepted into this year's Scotiabank Nuit Blanche, an all night art festival that gives audiences the opportunity to take in 12 hours of non-stop and free art exhibits of many disciplines. The unfortunate catch is that there is zero funding for artists and we are left  to find other means of generating funds. We are looking for your help to raise money to pay the artists, to help expose audiences to contemporary dance and to keep it alive and thriving in our communities!

Where will the money go?

All the money raised will go to the following:

-Artists fees for 6 performers

-Promotional material fees (printing for posters and postcards)

-Costume fees

-Rehearsal space rental fees

Where and when is it happening?

The work will be performed on October 3rd 2015 as part of Scotiabank Nuit Blanche at 7 Hart House Circle, East Common Room, Toronto, Ontario. The piece will be happening non-stop all night from 7PM- 7AM!!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, we understand. Please spread the word and share the campaign, help make dance matter.

-Artists fees for 6 performers
-Promotional material fees (printing for posters and postcards)
-Costume fees
-Rehearsal space rental fees
Where and when is it happening?
The work will be performed on October 3rd 2015 as part of Scotiabank Nuit Blanche at 7 Hart House Circle, East Common Room, Toronto, Ontario. The piece will be happening non-stop all night from 7PM- 7AM!!
 Other Ways You Can Help If you can't donate, we understand. Please spread the word and share the campaign, help make dance matter.

story: ROBOCLAUS©is a modern children’s Christmas musical with book and lyrics by George Wilkerson and music by Robert "Beto" Skiles. It's the story of what happens when a disgruntled inventor tries to replace the shopping mall’s Santa Claus with an android. This past December, a live reading performance of the show was produced in Nashville and the response convinced us that it’s ready to take it to community, children’s, and high school and college theater groups. But to do that we need to produce a set of tracks of the music to accompany the script. We've lined up some top-notch Nashville musicians and have a studio and producer standing by. So here's your chance to be part of a Christmas tradition. [To see the details of the show, listen to the music, and check out the live reading click here to go to the ROBOCLAUS web site.]

story:
Announcing...

THE Premiere Dance Network!

In a few short weeks, I will be launching the Premiere Dance Network, a podcast network dedicated solely to the dance community; a first of its kind.  

Who am I?

My name is Kimberly Falker and I am the host of Balancing Pointe Podcast where I interview successful and inspiring professionals who are living and working in the world of ballet.  My Podcast was born out of a goal to figure out a road map to help guide my then 13 year old girl daughter as she traveled into the world of professional ballet.

I wanted to create an inspirational resource for dancers and their parents by providing the journeys of REAL professionals and their personal stories into success. 

100 Episodes later...

Today marks the 100th episode of my Podcast with over to 100,000 listeners in 117 countries!

My daughter just turned 16, and while she is still on her journey into ballet...I am now traveling an unexpected journey of my own.



My personal journey into ballet and Podcasting has been such an amazing adventure. I am incredibly blessed to have met so many inspirational professionals and to know that in my own way, I have been able to give back to this beautiful art form and help make a difference in the lives of others. 

New Directions...

For most of the past 100 episodes I have been the sole host and producer of Balancing Pointe Podcast.  Recently I partnered with NYCB Principal dancer Megan Fairchild to add a new segment to my show. 

This was somewhat surreal, as Megan's image donned the walls of my daughter's bedroom for most of her youth.  The new segment is called the ASK Megan show where she provides thoughtful answers to questions provided by our listeners.  This show provides a unique perspective and an added benefit to my show as it has helped me educate and inspire a greater community in ballet.

New Ideas....

One important piece of information I've learned along my journey is that Podcasting is a perfect medium to educate and inspire a very large audience.  In fact Podcasting is the perfect platform to provide information to much larger dance community in all genres of dance; not just in ballet.  

THE Premiere Dance Network

This network will educate, inform, inspire and provide a unique platform for dancers, teachers, parents and the entire community of dance.  The proven success of Balancing Pointe and the Ask Megan shows will serve as the anchor shows for my network of Podcast shows. 

Balancing Pointe and ASK Megan will continue each week on schedule, providing you with valuable education and inspiration covering the world of professional Ballet  The Premiere Dance Network will provide an expanded platform, adding Podcast shows that involve other genres of dance; thus allowing each genre to have their unique voice in the dance network.

The first phase of the Launch will be the creation of a professional media production for listener education, marketing and use with potential future partners.

This phase will open new doors for professionals involved in each genre of dance to educate and inspire their perfect audience through Podcasting.  The video will highlight the network I am creating and its anchor shows using motion graphics, testimonials, music and live dancers.  The video will incorporate the vision of the future of the network going forward. 

This is where YOU come in.

I am seeking to raise funds to create a professional video using an award winning firm.  The video will be shot in Ultra HD.  The funds raised will be used to cover the cost of motion graphics, green screen production (which is necessary to allow for the vex work needed in the video), and the post production editing.

I am asking for YOUR support to help me raise the $5000 necessary to cover video production costs.

Thank you in advance for helping in the launch of THE Premiere Dance Network ~ your support means more than you'll ever know!

story:
Short Summary:

The Inanna myth comes to us from Ancient Sumer.  It is the story of the great goddess's descent to the underworld and the sacrifices that she must make along her journey.  Inanna - at the pinnacle of her powers- chooses to make the journey to the underworld, and along the way must pass through seven gates.  At each of these gates the goddess is forced to surrender one of her magical garments (symbolic of her power and status) until- stripped of all her treasures- she finally arrives naked in the underworld, where her sister reigns .

DESCENT is a new adaptation of this four thousand year-old myth that brings the audience on a journey to the underworld.  During the Halloween weekend performances, the audience enters the forest, passing through the seven gates, just as Inanna did in her descent.  An ensemble of women illuminate the ancient story with song, live music, dance, and spoken word.  DESCENT is a visceral experience of myth and a contemporary expression of feminine transformation.  

These initial performances of DESCENT will be October 30, 31 and November 1, 2015  (Halloween Weekend).  Ancient Sumerians used the Goddess's descent as a poetic explanation for the end of the growing season.  For this reason, our performance is created to be outdoors during the calendar time when we are moving into the longest periods of darkness.  We hope this incites the audience to feel the connection between the story and the land, the parallels between Inanna's "descent" and the turning of our seasons into the darkness of winter.  

These performances are the beginnings of a longterm project to create a community forum for exploring mythology and its connection to personal storytelling.  After the initial collaborative process of developing a framework for examining the Inanna myth, the framework  will be applied to non-performative settings within our home communities.  Through the project's blog and through movement and storytelling workshops, community members can explore and share the ways the Inanna myth is pertinent to their lives.  DESCENT is both a performance and a living piece of storytelling and community engagement.

Your contribution is critical to the production of DESCENT.  We need your help!   

Impact

The modern world emphasizes cleanliness, perfection, and production.  As we negotiate these cultural expectations, the chaotic, dark aspects of society and  individual are often unacknowledged and repressed.  For some, this takes the form of depression or mental illness; for some it is a hidden, unresolved trauma or addiction; for others, a sudden loss of identity and purpose.   Enacting Inanna's descent awakens us to the emptiness and decay that we may attempt to evade, and it reminds us that these aspects of the human experience have value. The Inanna myth reveals that light cannot exist without darkness, and that death  is part of the cycle of life.  

Alison and Sharon are both in their final semester of the MFA/Interdisciplinary Arts program at Goddard College.  They will be leading a team of dancers, singers, and actors in a two week long intensive process of production development.    As such, this performance/experience will evolve directly from the personal experiences and vision of the women who take part.    Both the collaborative process and the performance itself provide a unique and powerful opportunity to honor and examine the darker side of our identities; enacting both our own transformations and providing a scaffolding for others to embark on a personal journey into their dark sides. 


 Project Leaders

Alison Vodnoy Wolf is an actor, playwright, and dancer.  In Cincinnati, she’s appeared onstage at the Know Theatre and has danced many times with Pones, Inc.  As a choreographer, Alison presented her collaborative work, dis(embody), at the Area Choreographers Festival. She wrote and performed a one-woman show, In Rehearsal, which received two ACCLAIM awards and toured to Minneapolis, Indianapolis, Chicago, and Cincinnati.  As a playwright, her adaptations, The Eyes of Oedipus and The Dragon, were produced by The Know Theatre.  Her original script THE MACHINE received a staged reading at Mind Art Core in Chicago.  Her adaptation of James Joyce’s ULYSSES was commissioned and performed by CCM Drama.  Most recently, Alison’s original play HUNGRY MOTHER premiered in the Cincy Fringe and will be remounted in Cincinnati, February 25-27.

Sharon Penz is a conceptually based performance artist working in dance, theater, and other media. As a solo artist, she uses dance and character development as a way of exploring her identities as a mother, a woman, and an artist. Her work evolves from her own intimate experiences of being and asks questions about the ways in which we relate to both our own lives and our bodies in a time of deep social and physical disconnect. Sharon studied modern dance, choreography and theatre at the University of Colorado in Boulder. She has since worked as a dancer, choreographer, storyteller, and cellist for more than 20 years; performing and creating both solo and collaborative work and teaching for local schools, libraries, and community groups. She has also performed and taught at several Artist's Residency programs throughout New England, and directed and choreographed under local and regional grants. Sharon teaches contemporary dance and improvisation at the Saugerties Ballet Center. She is currently attending Goddard College where she is working towards her MFA in interdisciplinary arts. 


What We Need 

Alison lives in Cincinnati and Sharon lives in New York.  We need to be in residence together to start the creative process.   We are asking for seed money for this project so we can create the first performances and begin getting the community engaged.  We anticipate using the funds that are raised for the following items:

Travel expenses for Sharon to come to Cincinnati

Fabric and costumes

Promotional materials like postcards

Stipend for the performers

The development of a sound scape that can be shared online. 

Transporting a cello from New York to Ohio for live music at the event

Continuing opportunities to engage our home communities in the Inanna myth


What you get

The satisfaction of knowing that you are an part of this profound collaborative project, and our sincere and heartfelt gratitude.  Also, check out our perks.



Risks & Challenges

Th funds from this campaign will be used as seed money to launch a long term, collaborative project between the artists and their communities.   The biggest challenge will be to secure long term funding to sustain these creative efforts in our New York and Cincinnati communities.


Other Ways You Can Help

We love you no matter what.  Even if you can't contribute financially, you can still help the campaign by sharing it with others.     You can use the Indiegogo share tools or your own clever social networking strategies.

story:
WELCOME!

Welcome to The Dreaming's crowdfunding page! Thank you so much for taking the time to read this and (hopefully) supporting this wonderful production! Please take the time to read this short summary so that you know exactly what you're getting yourselves into!

Why Are We Doing This?
When Jordan was 14 years old he was cast in the National Youth Musical Theatre of Great Britain's production of The Dreaming.  He had an amazing time performing in this production and it was one of the main things that inspired him to to pursue a career in the theatre industry.

Jordan says: "It's a show I've always wanted to direct and I think that it would be an interesting show to take to America.  I want to bring some British musical theatre over to smaller fringe venues and create a buzz and excitement for British theatre, which is easily accessible to audiences who might not necessarily be able to see shows on Broadway."

British musical theatre is thriving at the moment.  Our team's mission is to create professional, unique shows that are exciting, imaginative, and accessible to theatre lovers in America, starting in the Big Apple at the wonderful Chain Theatre!

A Bit About Us

  • Jordan Murphy - Director, a freelance theatre director based in London, England. This will be Jordan's second time directing in New York and he is very excited to be bringing this great British musical over to you all in America!
  • Mariel Letourneau - Choreographer, a professional choreographer and performer in NYC and NJ.  She works on musicals, solo pieces, ensemble pieces, and music videos. She is so excited to be putting together this production with Jordan and Marcus!
  • Marcus Baker - Musical Director, freelance music director and youth theatre educator in the New York area. Mr. Baker has worked in every type of venue from Arizona Theatre Company to a high school near you. Always up for new works and supporting emerging artists, he's pleased to be a part of this international consortium!

What We Need & What You Get

So here's what we need...
We need to raise $9,000 (£5775.27) to make sure this production gets the professionalism it deserves! 

But Where is Your Money Going?
Well let us break it down for you...

OUR VENUE
Our beautiful venue is The Chain Theatre in Long Island City, just a short train ride from Manhattan!  This wonderful space unfortunately comes at a cost and this is $4,500 (£2887.63).  We love this intimate venue for The Dreaming and we know that it would be a perfect home for our project!

RIGHTS
To perform such beautiful musical theatre we have to license the show through a publishing company.  The wonderful people at Faber Music, who hold the rights, have quoted $1496.04 (£960).  It's a lot of money but we promise you, the music to this show is worth that amount alone! 

AUDITION & REHEARSAL SPACE
AUDITION SPACE - The most important thing in this show.... the cast.  We need a cast of talented performers to join us on this wonderful venture, and to do this we need to hold auditions, which would cost around $400 (£259.34) to ensure our audition venue is accessible to a large number of performers!

REHEARSAL SPACE - We want our company to be able to feel as comfortable as they can during rehearsals, which is why we would like to raise around $1,500 - $2,000 (£962.54- £1283.39) so that we can have a suitable and safe space to rehearse in! 

SET AND COSTUME
Obviously set, props and costume are extremely important to the show and we want to be able to be as creative as we can!  So we are looking to raise around $250 - $300 (£160.42- £194.50) to ensure our cast looks fantastic on stage, surrounded by a beautifully creative world.

Where Do The Funds Go If We Don't Reach Our Goal
Have no fear! Any money that is donated still goes towards our project and helps us try and achieve our dream!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support us financially, don't worry, we would love for to help us spread the word! Please share it on all social media sites if you can.

Thank you so much, your support means so much to us. We look forward to creating this beautiful piece of theatre for you!

story:
A Public Fit continues its community outreach with FREE monthly staged readings of some of the most challenging contemporary plays being produced in the modern theatre.  

      It is our ardent goal to continue providing these one-night-only theatrical experiences utilizing the finest talent Las Vegas has to offer.  Our acting company includes myriad seasoned performers currently appearing in "Blue Man Group," "Mystere," "La Reve," and a host of Las Vegas Strip extravaganzas.  And our audiences remain the most engaged in town, often staying far into the evening to continue the conversation with our patented post-show discussion forum, "the Buzzz."  

     Here, audiences have the rare opportunity to meet the players personally and discuss the work itself - its concept, creation, design, production and execution.  We approach all of our theatrical productions as "conversations", demanding that in order for theatre to remain relevant, it must be dissected, analyzed, chewed-over and disseminated."

The Mission

The song remains the same.

     In an age where the notion of “neighborhood” is fast evolving into a series of intangible on-line social media webpages, A Public Fit aims to reinvigorate the tangible community by working with emerging Las Vegas artists to create exciting, innovative and provocative professional theater. APF believes strongly in the communal power of great stories, dramatic ideas and the sincere engagement that audiences find in challenging theatrical events. A Public Fit genuinely hopes to unite professional artists and audiences through the most effective form of human connection, treating each production as the beginning of an unending conversation.

“The artistic team driving APF to the forefront believes and embraces the notion that theatre is for everyone, it will always be relevant and it is a vital part of our community's culture.”

-Melanie Jupp, Assistant Program Manager, Education and Outreach, The Smith Center



The Aim

Success has made us bold.

APF is trying to raise $40,000 to produce our second season.

     This money will pay for the spaces, the sets, the costumes, the designers and performers.  Plural, because this year we’re going to produce a 2-show season while continuing the free monthly staged readings.  As before, the staff of APF will be working merely to cover their expenses in order to make absolutely certain that the performers and behind-the-scenes artists get paid first.  A Public Fit respects artists too much to ask them to work for free.

“We’ve got this exciting moment happening in Las Vegas where a lot of good and talented people are all here at this one moment.”

-Ian Pugh, PhD, Ohio State University



The Past

     A Public Fit’s on-going series of free monthly staged readings captured the imagination of an ever-growing audience of theatre aficionados who braved SRO crowds.  Our first fully-realized production, Dawn King’s Foxfinder, was met with critical and commercial success, selling out its November 2014 run and garnering 11 Las Vegas Valley Theatre Award nominations - including Best Play, Best Director and Best Ensemble Cast - nominations in every category for which it was eligible.  

“A thrilling show with powerful, claustrophobic performances that caught me up and wouldn’t let me go.”

-Jacob Coakley, Las Vegas WEEKLY



The Present

     A Public Fit is changing the inviolable role of the audience in today’s modern theatre with an ambitious new commission -  A Summons from the Tinker to Assemble the Membership in Secret at the Usual Place by Joseph Kucan - an immersive theatrical event based upon Fritz Lang’s classic 1931 film “M”.  October 15-31 at the usual place.  In step with the most cutting edge theater currently happening around the globe, A Summons from the Tinker… blurs the line between viewer and artists, creating a truly one of a kind experience that will leave audiences gasping.  Once you’ve received your summons, there’s no turning back.


The Future

     The second show of our second season will be Gina Gionfriddo’s  Becky Shaw.  This Pulitzer Prize Finalist allows A Public Fit to ask:  What do we owe to the people we love?  To the strangers that we meet along the way?  To ourselves?  Fast-paced and smart, Becky Shaw  is witty, complex and devastatingly funny and will be performed for the first time in Las Vegas, March 10-27 at the Art Square Theatre.  This is the kind of flat-out, take-no-prisoners theatre that A Public Fit thrives on.

“Las Vegas needs A Public Fit because it needs an alternative theatre.”

-Jeff Koep, Dean of Fine Arts, University of Nevada, Las Vegas



The Culture

     Las Vegas is changing.  The past 40 years have brought a wave of emigrants yearning for new vistas to explore, new freedoms to flex, new art to define.  A Public Fit is quickly becoming home to those cultural expatriates - an innovative, professional, theatrical oasis in the literal desert.  Our aesthetic is unique, our vision unparalleled, our commitment unrivaled.  And while Las Vegas still draws the most talented people on the planet to perform in its spectacular strip extravaganzas, the need for cultural expression of a more connective nature still burns fiercely in the breasts of these creative super-stars.  A Public Fit exists to give voice to these yearnings, to create exciting, innovative and provocative professional theater.



The Plea

Please help us continue what we’ve started - a larger season with 2 fully-realized productions; a world-premiere production based upon the classic cinematic work of a legendary genius; the drive to maintain our standing as Las Vegas’ only professional theatre company.  Add your voice to the growing chorus of those who demand more from the Las Vegas cultural landscape.  Sing proudly with us the anthems of optimism and audacity.  It’s time that what happens in Vegas shakes the artistic pillars of the nation.
story_txt: A Public Fit continues its community outreach with FREE monthly staged readings of some of the most challenging contemporary plays being produced in the modern theatre.        It is our ardent goal to continue providing these one-night-only theatrical experiences utilizing the finest talent Las Vegas has to offer.  Our acting company includes myriad seasoned performers currently appearing in "Blue Man Group," "Mystere," "La Reve," and a host of Las Vegas Strip extravaganzas.  And our audiences remain the most engaged in town, often staying far into the evening to continue the conversation with our patented post-show discussion forum, "the Buzzz."       Here, audiences have the rare opportunity to meet the players personally and discuss the work itself - its concept, creation, design, production and execution.  We approach all of our theatrical productions as "conversations", demanding that in order for theatre to remain relevant, it must be dissected, analyzed, chewed-over and disseminated."The MissionThe song remains the same.     In an age where the notion of “neighborhood” is fast evolving into a series of intangible on-line social media webpages, A Public Fit aims to reinvigorate the tangible community by working with emerging Las Vegas artists to create exciting, innovative and provocative professional theater. APF believes strongly in the communal power of great stories, dramatic ideas and the sincere engagement that audiences find in challenging theatrical events. A Public Fit genuinely hopes to unite professional artists and audiences through the most effective form of human connection, treating each production as the beginning of an unending conversation.“The artistic team driving APF to the forefront believes and embraces the notion that theatre is for everyone, it will always be relevant and it is a vital part of our community's culture.”-Melanie Jupp, Assistant Program Manager, Education and Outreach, The Smith CenterThe AimSuccess has made us bold.APF is trying to raise $40,000 to produce our second season.     This money will pay for the spaces, the sets, the costumes, the designers and performers.  Plural, because this year we’re going to produce a 2-show season while continuing the free monthly staged readings.  As before, the staff of APF will be working merely to cover their expenses in order to make absolutely certain that the performers and behind-the-scenes artists get paid first.  A Public Fit respects artists too much to ask them to work for free.“We’ve got this exciting moment happening in Las Vegas where a lot of good and talented people are all here at this one moment.”-Ian Pugh, PhD, Ohio State UniversityThe Past     A Public Fit’s on-going series of free monthly staged readings captured the imagination of an ever-growing audience of theatre aficionados who braved SRO crowds.  Our first fully-realized production, Dawn King’s Foxfinder, was met with critical and commercial success, selling out its November 2014 run and garnering 11 Las Vegas Valley Theatre Award nominations - story:
THEATRE CAN SAVE THE WORLD

A bit dramatic? Hey, we can’t help it – we’re theatre people. But think about it: even the smallest energy spent by us on the stage sends energetic ripples into the world, changing us, our audience, our community, our world, our universe. Theatre truly has the power to save the world, and now you can help us fight the good fight!

We are Working Class Theatre, a professional-level not-for-profit theatre company in Taos, New Mexico. Working Class Theatre is committed to keeping the art of theatre alive by producing provocative and socially relevant theatre, creating new theatrical works, developing emotionally authentic ensemble acting, and fostering a nurturing environment where theatre artists at any stage in their development may train and assist in the production of professional theatre.

And in all of this, Parks Playhouse – our workspace, our home, our stage – has always had a starring role. We’re reaching out to ask for your support in keeping the doors of the Playhouse open as we head into our 2016 season.

In the upcoming years, we plan to expand the minds of theatre goers and players with imaginative new interpretations of our changing world, dedicated and professional staging of the classics, and emotional and evocative workshops and classes. Your donation to this campaign will give us the boost we need to kick off this new revolution of creativity!

Support Parks Playhouse!!

THE PLAY(HOUSE)’S THE THING

Parks Playhouse, an intimate black box theater that seats fifty-six, is special to everyone who has performed there or who has been in the audience at any of its well-loved productions. Some were lucky enough to have known the man for whom it is named. Some know it as a sacred first audition or rehearsal space. Many have begun a lifelong love of theatre after attending a first performance there. To other local theater groups, touring productions, musicians, poets and speakers the Playhouse, has been a special temporary home.

The only venue of its size and type in northern New Mexico, the Playhouse plays an essential role for the performing arts community here. After some recent financial struggles, we’re asking for help from our community in keeping the doors of the Parks Playhouse open. Your donation will help launch a renewed and revitalized Playhouse, as Working Class Theatre redoubles our commitment to bringing high-quality, socially-relevant theatre to Taos and its visitors.

A WORKING CLASS HERO IS SOMETHING TO BE…

And it’s so easy to help Parks Playhouse continue as a venue for professional performances and workshops for community members of all ages, and as an affordable rental resource for visiting and local speakers, performers, and acting troupes.

Check out the many different levels of financial support, choose one and click on it. That’s it! We’ll supply the perks – and the works – in our mission to enlighten! Who knew it was this simple to help save the world?

Be a Working Class Hero. Support Parks Playhouse

Sincerely,

All of us at Working Class Theatre.

story:
Short Summary

Since 2006, more than 140 people have been killed by the Chicago Police or while in police custody. Gone But Not Forgotten is a community quilting project, documenting the names and lives of these individuals. Over the last year, more than 150 individuals have participated in combination quilting circles/peace circles across Chicago.  In partnership with grassroots groups, religious organizations, art spaces and schools, we are sewing together the memories of those lost to police violence, while discussing questions of transformative justice, police accountability, and community safety.

Gone But Not Forgotten is a collaboration between Rachel Wallis and the grassroots group We Charge Genocide.

What We Need

The initial materials for the quilt and the 2015 quilting circles were funded by a $5,000 grant from the Chicago Department of Art and Special Events, but we need your help to bring this project to completion!

We need a minimum of $7,000 to be able to finish the 30 foot quilt and mount an exhibition featuring the quilt, process photos, and a video installation with interviews with the friends and families of some of the victims.

Your donations will help pay for:

  • A full color publication that will accompany the exhibit, featuring process photos and quotes from participants in the quilting circles; an examination of the research and data involved in uncovering the names in the quilt; selected stories of the victims included in the project; and a complete list of all of the victims.
  • A zine, created in partnership with the For The People Artist Collective, which will provide a background of the Movement for Black Lives in Chicago and ways that visitors to the exhibit can take action to end police violence.

  • Graphic design and publicity materials for the exhibition.

  • The labor needed to complete the quilt and create the video installation. This project has been made possible by hundreds of volunteer hours over the last year, from myself, circle keepers, teaching artists, partner organizations, and photographers. In order to create the best possible exhibition, we're hoping to pay myself, the creator of the video installation, and a project assistant for at least some of the final work to complete the project.

This exhibit will happen regardless of whether or not we reach our goals through this campaign. We have applied for grants, received support from the universities where we work and study, and drawn on the talents and generosity of dozens of artists and activists from around the city in order to bring the project this far. Your donation will allow Gone But Not Forgotten to be exhibited with the care, attention to detail, and support that this urgent issue deserves.

The Impact

Gone But Not Forgotten is more than just a quilt or a gallery exhibit - it is a space for ongoing organizing around police brutality, accountability, and transformative justice. We have partnered with grassroots groups on the front lines of the Movement for Black Lives around the city in the creation of the quilt, and the exhibit will continue that commitment. Throughout the gallery show we will feature panel discussions and workshops on issues related to the project.

Once our initial gallery exhibit is over, this funding will allow us to package up the show and related publications and offer them to other community spaces and galleries across Chicago and even the country, so that the project can continue to be a catalyst for organizing even after the quilting is complete.

Risks & Challenges

If we do not raise enough funding for this exhibit, we may have to scale back our broader goals for the exhibit (like the accompanying publications and workshops). Although we hope to show the quilt in the fall of 2016, we're still in talks for the final exhibit space, and there is a possibility that exhibition date will have to be moved into 2017. The quilt will be finished and displayed in some form, however, regardless of funding.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Host a quilting circle! Quilting circles will continue through June 2016, and we're still partnering with organizations who would like to host the project.
    • Help with the sewing of the quilt! Do you have experience with machine sewing or quilting? Let us know! We still need support in piecing and quilting the final panels.
    • Offer a space to exhibit the quilt! Do you have a wheelchair accesible art or community space that is interested in showing the Gone But Not Forgotten exhibit, either in late 2016 or 2017? Let us know!

story:
Straight Up:

We have a venue 'The Lion and Unicorn Theatre' for the 8th, 9th, 10th and 14th of August. We have a full and committed cast and we have a script, basically now all we need is to raise the funds to pay for hiring the theatre, registration costs for the Camden Fringe Festival and the very few props we need!

Who are Malarkey Theatre?

We are four female graduates of the Rose Bruford Acting Foundation Course. During our training we decided we worked well together and should start working on a project. The script was written, rehearsal's started then 2 months later we decided it was ready for the Camden Fringe festival. 'Awkward Topic' will be the company's debut piece and we'd love for you to be involved! 

Why pay for our play?

The most important thing about this play is that it is entirely made up of other peoples words, it is formed of answers to questions about gender from approximately 50 different men and women. This play covers everything from tinder chat up lines to the difference between how men and women identify themselves. This is not your typical feminist play, we do not put a specific gender on a pedestal. Our aim is to leave the audience questioning their own views on feminism. We feel this topic is so important right now along with a young persons viewpoint on it, which is why we have the drive to make it happen.
(If you can't afford to pledge money please follow Malarkey Theatre's Facebook page, we always ask for people's answers to random questions for the script so you can still be a part of it. We want this play to voice the most relevant and most up to date opinions on what it means to be a man or woman in the 21st century.)
Help us make this happen and get 'Awkward Topic' on its feet so that hopefully next year we can make it grow. We have idea's of taking it to Edinburgh Fringe and other arts festivals in the years to come, so please be part of something with great potential!
