To show our appreciation for your generosity, we will be offering some great
perks, including show tickets, original posters signed by the cast, digital
copies of our making of feature, which will reveal intimate behind-the-scenes
moments about the show, and many more. 
Why support us?
Our team strives to show that independent
theater can be possible without succumbing to compromise, and that it can
provide an ethical working environment for the people involved. Our artistic
policy is to present the audience with original performances whose construction
and/or subject differs from what is expected from a typical theater play. 
11.1 doesn’t need a target audience. It is
meant to speak to anyone in a certain manner, because it tells stories which
could be about any one of us at certain points in our lives. The play is not
meant to shock or to brutally interfere in the viewer’s life, but to raise
questions about the relevance of everyday moments which we pass by, without a
second thought. The full construct is a story focused not on the beauty,
sadness or tragedy of those moments, but on their ultimate relevance in the
whole equation of one’s life. 
What’s next?
We plan to perform the play in other
locations around the country, always promoting an architectural monument in
need of revival. It is our way of making people aware both of the importance of
their history, as well as the need of transforming abandoned buildings into
public spaces that can act as nuclei for communities, through art.
At some point, we would also love to be able
to transform the making of feature we are recording, into a full-fledged film, as
we find it to be an interesting point of departure for analyzing the blurred
lines between theater and cinema. The „making of” DVD will also provide insight into designing and completing site-specific theater, which is an often-coveted and all-too-rarely approached form of performance art. We intend to make our DVD as a helpful tool for artists and critics alike. Of course, our ultimate goal is to bring the show to as many breathtaking spaces as possible, throughout Europe. The underlying premise, the lifeblood, if you will, of our project, is the idea that universal epiphanies come from otherwise banal circumstances. This is a boundless concept, and we are hoping to reach a boundless, global audience.Other ways you can helpSpreading the word is just as great as money! If you cannot donate, please share this campaign with your friends and family and show us your online support on facebook or tweeter. You will have our friendship and appreciation until the end of time. The team
Director: Sebastian Marina
Set designer & costumes:
Cristina Milea
Choreographer: Andreea Duță
Music: Eugen Nuțescu (Kumm)
Production Manager: Maria Chirilă
& Cătălin Mareș 
PR: Mircea Laslo
Light designer: Lucian Moga
Sound engineer: Gabriel Gheorghe
Assistant: Bianca Stânea
Cast: Oana Rusu, Ionuț Oprea, Radu Câmpean, Claudia Ardelean, Diana Grigoroșcuță, Bogdan Nechifor, Dan Clucinschi, Loredana Topciu, Ion Fiscuteanu Jr, Ana Covalciuc, Adrian Anghel, Elisabeta Râmboi, Cătălin Mareș, Ioana
Farcaș, Sebastian Marina, Andreea Duță, Raluca Felezeu, Răzvan Corneci, Daria
Moraru, Vlad UnguruTranslation copyrights for the plays: University of Arts, Târgu-Mureș, Romania

story:
Welcome to the Bomb Squad!


We are the Glorious Bomb Squad, and we need your help to get our production of THE HUNGER ARTIST in fighting shape for the Cincinnati Fringe Festival.

We take special interest in found-space work and non-traditional performer-audience relationships. That means, in a GBS show, you might find yourself jumping on a bed while a performer cheers you on. You might pass underneath the bridge where wanderers look for the edge of the universe. You might hear a prostitute bite the hand of God. 

Since 2013, we've produced seven shows:

Two original devised works, two brand-new translations of classics, three local premieres. (Check out our gallery to get a taste.)

After closing our 2014 season, we moved to Chicago, changed the company name, and got to work.

This Fringe Festival will give us the opportunity to get our work out there for a wider audience and, quite frankly, give us memories and stories worth even more than that. We're young and poor and this will help us build a theatre company that lasts. 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need is actually fairly straightforward:

  • We need to get ourselves to Cincinnati
  • We need to feed ourselves while we're there
  • We need to buy costumes, props and all the other things that go along with putting a play together.

If you put your hard earned money towards this project, that's what you'll be paying for, and, if we surpass our goal, your money will simply go to our next projects: the Chicago Fringe Festival and beyond!

By donating, you'll have the opportunity to receive the expected stuff like signed posters and thank you notes, but you could also have an impossible play written about you or a signed copy of a limited print run of the script.
If we don't reach our total goal, our first priority with whatever money we get will be getting our actors food and transportation to the festival. So the first chunk of money will be appreciated the most. After that, the money will go to elevating the technical elements of the show as far as it will take us.

The Impact

Since we are a group of young artists just out of college, this money will be a godsend for us. It is truly the only way that we can do anymore than put actors on the stage with their street clothes on.

By donating to this fundraiser, you will be helping seven or eight young artists get out there into the world, to network at a wonderful festival and to build the kinds of resumes it takes to make it in this business. And if you're in Cincinatti at the end of May, you'll also be helping to build an awesome show!

In 2013, as Alarum Theatre, we ran a sucessful Kickstarter campaign for around the same amount, and it allowed us to produce fully seven shows! You can see pictures and get a look at all that came from that succesful fundraiser on our website.
If you make this fundraiser happen, you can be sure that this money is going to help some poor, young artists do really exciting and glorious things.

Risks & Challenges

The fringe festival format is a really demanding one. You have to travel to a new city, do one rehearsal in a space you've never been in, and then put on the best show of your life. So this presents two major hurdles: the artistic and the financial.

With our experience working in strange theatre spaces (under bridges, in abandoned houses, and on street corners), this is right in our comfort zone. We love using non-traditional spaces, and we love being transient theatre hobos. It's what we do best.

And while this amount of money (after you take out bus tickets and food) is still a really small amount to put together a play, we have been excelling at low-cost, high-concept theatre for the past few years, taking nothing and turning it into challenging, exciting theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money to our campaign, you can still help! 

Use the INDIEGOGO tools, or just find a way to like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, subscribe to our blog or head over to our website. Any exposure helps.

facebook.com/gloriousbs

@gloriousbs

gloriousbombsquad.com

turbotheatre.com

story:
Welcome to Hard Sexy Serious Love Conversations!


Who I am

I can't imagine anyone visiting this page doesn't know me, but just in case, my name is Sarah. I am a playwright. How do you know I am a playwright? Because I have the great pleasure of writing plays. I also earned my BA in Playwriting in 2010. So there. 

For the very first time in LA, I am producing one of my own shows in the Hollywood Fringe Festival! I've worked at Fringe as a stage manager for the last two years and in large and small LA theatres since 2011, and I've got the very best people on board for this show. I also produced several shows of my own work in college, and even way back in Ye Olden Days, a one-act student play festival in high school. Long story short: producing and playwriting (on a budget) is my jam. I'm good at it. I know what I'm doing. I'm not going to take your money and run away on a very short trip to Aruba.

What I don't have is a lot of money, which is where you come in. Right now, I have enough money to rent the space (already booked at a central Fringe venue, Theatre Asylum), pay the festival fees, and meagerly create a world on stage. Our budget for all of that is about $1,300, all of which is coming from my tax refund and personal savings. We can make it work, but we'd like to make it great with your help.

Why this play? Hard Sexy Serious Love Conversations is a play about what you do when you realize life can go on, when you think that it's all over and then you have to keep going. I've been writing it for over three years, and I've come to realize that it's a question we face all the time, and it's a question we don't have a guide for. HSSLC is not that guide, but I think it asks questions that allow us to make choices, which is, after all, what living is. 

Why support this play? Successful plays in the Hollywood Fringe often transfer to local theatres and longer runs of performances. Several have gone on to the New York Fringe Festival, the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and off-Broadway. Some are being produced in venues around the country and the world. It can lead to more art and more work and more connection for some time to come. More importantly, I am asking you to support the creation of a work of art that creates community, collaboration, and collective purpose. If that is worth a few dollars, please throw them my way.

Just 120 people giving $25 each helps us reach our goal, and we will happily work with more (or less)!

What We Have and What We Need

We have a great team of artists:

Director, Bianca Lemaire
Set Designer, Katrina Coulourides
Costume Designer, Rachel Clinkscales
Lighting Designer, Brandon Baruch
Sound Designer, Corwin Evans

We also have a incredible graphic designer, Mary Harburg-Petrich of MissMaryMary.com.

So far, every member of the team has generously agreed to donate their services, which allows us to actually produce this show.

We have a phenomenal venue, Theatre Asylum. Actually housing four performance spaces in the heart of Theatre Row, performing at Theatre Asylum makes us highly visible and lends high credibility to our play, making it more likely to be seen by the best-connected members of the theatre community.

We need actors, who will be cast at the beginning of May, and we need the financial support to offer the actors a paycheck and ensure we have the best skilled artists join the team, not to mention a set made of something besides secondhand cardboard.

We Want To Raise $3,000

The first $2,000 you give us goes straight into the show costs: 

-Approximately $500 total for design elements -- that's any pieces we have to buy or manufacture for the production, including set, light, sound, and costumes. We're necessarily limited in capacity by the parameters of the festival, which also limits our budget needs.

-Approximately $300 to pay our graphic designer, who up to now has been donating her time and services.

-$235 for each of the actors, designers, and the director -- this is an honorarium, and nowhere near what their time and skills are worth, but it will cover gas and couple of drinks.

The final $1,000 dollars will go to paying me back for the initial investment (which, let's be honest, will almost certainly go and fund the next show, unless I break my arm or something).

Any money we raise beyond $3,000 will go into the next production.

If we raise less than our goal, we'll make it work. Raising this money allows us to the work better and pay our skilled folks for their time.

Why aren't there more perks?

Because we're making art that lives for just a few hours on stage, with a limited number of people to see it, and then disappears forever. The play is the perk. You also get a hand-written card, and who doesn't love that?

I Don't Want To Give You Money Here, But Perhaps Some Other Way

There are a few ways to support the show:

-Buy tickets! They can be purchased here, starting May 1:  https://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/2298

Use the discount code SPINTHEBOTTLE for $10 tickets!

-Buy a t-shirt! Our profit margin is pretty minimal on these, but they're great for showing off your hipster street cred: https://represent.com/hardsexyseriouslovefringe

-Buy something from my Etsy shop! For the months of April, May, and June all profits are going straight into the show: https://www.etsy.com/shop/Delishtaknit

-Just give me cash! I'll take it.

-Spread the word on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter using the hashtags #hsslc and #hff15.

story:
Our Real Story

  • Hi.  We're Nick Santa Maria, and Paul Louis (Nick and Pauly),  two middle aged goofy schmucks from Long Island, who grew up to be actors & show authors (but still goofy schmucks).  We've written an original musical called, "REAL MEN, a musical for guys and the women who put up with them". Why? Well, because we wanted to write a brutally honest, intelligent, funny and poignant musical for men who hate musicals. You know, a musical that women don't have to DRAG their men to.  :)
  • So far, our little "Broadway World Award-winning" hit musical has run in Miami at Actors' Playhouse, and Los Angeles at The Norris Theater.  The show received unanimous rave reviews from critics and audiences alike.

  • And now here's the BIG NEWS, ...  we have been invited to run this Summer of 2015, on the famous Theatre Row at The New York Musical Theater Festival (NYMF).  For old guys like us, this is truly a life long dream come true.  Everyone who's anyone in the theater world, will be there to see our show, ... BUT ... we need your help.
  • Although NYMF pays for the high cost of the venue, publicity, theater staff and more, we still need to pay for our own festival fees and production costs (ie: Director, Actors, Travel, Housing, Stage Manager, Food, Insurance, Costumes, Set Design, Crew, Strippers, and, .... er,  wait scratch that last one, ... and so much more).  ..... Joking aside, we need help.  We've already cleaned out our savings, putting in a great deal of our own money, ... but we simply can't bring this truly entertaining evening of theater to New York City on our own. 

What We Really Need & What You Really Get

We need to raise about $50,000 in order to pay for the costs involved to run our show at NYMF.  Yikes!  Like we said, we're just two goofy schmucks over here! Brilliant, but goofy!  However, the two of us, Nick and Pauly,  have very strong reputations in our theatrical community as two honest, award-winning artists, who've given great opportunities to other artists.  With a long background in comedy and puppetry, we also produce edu-taining children's programming to help young children learn and grow.  Our work in this particular field has been called "High Quality Children's Programming", by President Bill Clinton himself.  Not too shabby, huh? :)  We promise you, we're the good guys.


So, we've got some really nice and unique "Thank You" perks to give to you in return for your generous financial support.  We've things to offer you like, personally autographed scripts, cast recordings, show tickets, party invites, custom built puppets, full video production services, custom songs, theater season tickets, private performances and so much more! 

EVERY amount we raise will go directly to the costs of getting REAL MEN to the festival this Summer.  You can contribute as much or as little as you're able, and you'll still get your thank you gift.

The Real Impact

  • There are so many shows for women out there, like , "Menopause", "Divorce Party", Cougar", etc., but there are no musicals made especially for men that deal with the very "Real" things that guys deal with, and from a man's perspective no less  (ie: dating, marriage, kids, mid-life, our elderly parents, etc.)  Our musical message is simple, ... ALL men, ... whether old, young, gay, straight, single, married or divorced, ... we have a common bond in that we're not always perfect.
  • Everyone (both men AND women) who has seen our show, leaves the theater feeling good about themselves and the particular "place" they might be in their life (But only after they have caught their breath from laughing so hard).  How wonderful it is when you can take time and laugh at the many "real" issues you go through in this crazy journey of "real" life.  
  •  

  • Real Risks & Real Challenges
  • We realize the risks involved with any online crowd funding campaign like this. But rest assured, we have also scheduled fund raising events outside of Indiegogo, that will be held live and in person.  Added to these event donations, ANY amount you contribute here will help us with our goal.  Your financial gift WILL NOT go to waste, and you will be a part of musical theater history.  

Other Real Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • You can share this campaign with everyone you know on Social Media and more! (Facebook, Twitter, etc.)
  • Indiegogo has some VERY easy "share tools" for you to do just that!

We've got our award winning creative production team in place and ready to take New York by storm, but we can't do it without you. So, ... PLEASE help "REAL MEN, a musical for guys and the women who put up with them", run this Summer at NYMF.   We promise you, it'll make you feel good in that you've helped two middle aged goofy schmucks from Long Island.  Thanks :)

.... Nick & Pauly

story:
UPPERMOST ENTERTAINMENT, LLC
                                                                PRESENTS                                                                                                                
                                                   I'M ALWAYS ON MY MIND [IAOMM]
                                                           WORLD PREMIER
                                                       0NE-MAN STAGE PLAY


Uppermost Entertainment Creative Team Bios:
Lisa Bills - President and COO
Leslie O'Hare - VP of Creative Development
Linda Leonard - Director
Scott Rolfe Josephson - Scriptwriter
Julie Hanley - Sr. Marketing Strategist

Company Background:

Our team at Uppermost Entertainment [UME] has over 25 years of experience in the entertainment industry. We specialize in creating entertaining, engaging and inspiring shows for theatrical stage plays, television, film and online media streaming markets with platforms across, comedy, reality, talk shows, news programs, animation, feature-length dramas and drama-series.


I’M ALWAYS ON MY MIND [Humorous Comedy, One-Man Stage Play] 

SYNOPSIS:

Brock Besson is a 40-year-old, charismatic and handsome manga cum laude graduate from Harvard. President of his fraternity and has since become an extremely successful single businessman. Brock’s ego has been his compass his entire life. It doesn’t matter whose toes he steps on as long he gets what he wants, when he wants it. He is sparked and intrigued when he meets a girl, London, who repeatedly refers to him as a narcissistic jerk. This drives him absolutely zany. In an effort to understand what that means, he decides to seek out a Narcissistic Support Group. His best friend, Larry, tells him to contact Dr. Criscella, a nationally recognized and a formidable condescendingly empathetic Therapist. Through their meeting, Brock quickly learns that he really does have a problem and needs help.

OUR FUNDING GOAL:
$150,000


WHY DO WE NEED FUNDING?

We’re excited about opening the door to provide job opportunities in all areas of the entertainment field.

This entire creative journey for us has always been about making dreams come true for others. As well as creating engaging storylines that will entertain, inspire, educate and leave an impactful, memorable and positive imprint on the lives of our team and our audience members forever. We think there’s a real thirst for it out there to bring these storylines to fruition and we know that we’re the company to get it done, and now is the time to do it.

We need your support to help us produce our 2015/2016 season. With your contribution, the possibilities are endless. Our funding goal is the minimum amount we need to make this dream a reality, however, the more we raise, the bigger this production show can be and the more impact we can create.


WHAT'S YOUR UPCOMING 2016 PRODUCTION?

LIVING WITH REJECTION [Dramatic, One-Woman Stage Play ]

SYNOPSIS:

Living with Rejection is based on Leslie O'Hare's personal life story. This show takes you a roller coaster of emotions filled with jealousy and envy from a mother towards her daughter.

This play is riveting, sophisticated, twisted and thought-provoking… Whenever you let this character [Logan] into your lives and into your heart, she’s going to captivate you, you will love her, you will be on the edge of your seat rooting for her and trying to save her.


WHY SHOULD YOU SUPPORT?

Our incredible stage productions are an ideal networking opportunity with a substantial, cultured audience who appreciate your commitment to our community.

Participating in our sponsorship opportunities shows your serious investment in the arts and your support of local talent who make our city and region an interesting, lively place to live and work. 

You can be a part of building this from the ground up, what's really great, is you get to choose the incentive you would like to contribute from our IndieGoGo sponsorship page; let's create amazing shows and opportunities, together. 


WHAT OTHER WAYS CAN I HELP?

No amount is too small (or too big!), and every dollar helps, but we understand that making a contribution is not possible for everyone. You can still be a huge help to us by simply spreading the word about our campaign and sharing our video on Facebook and Twitter. You can use the IndieGoGo share tools to make this easier. And check out our website to learn more about our company, team, and upcoming productions: www.UppermostEntertainment.com. You can also follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube.

Thank you for your support and commitment to the ARTS!

story:
My name is Kenden Dean (birth name Kent Cloud) and I am the Production Manager of Upright Theater Cafe and Gift Shop. I have a Master’s in Education and have skills as an entertainer, producer, writer, and youth advocate. For years I have worked for schools and social service  organizations as a youth counselor using educational entertainment and games to engage the children and young adults. My wife Salma Brahimi is an excellent chef of world cuisine. She will be the Food Service manager of our cafe. Our business partner Farhan Saadi has the right skills to manage the day to day operations of Upright Theater Cafe and Gift Shop.

Our goal is to establish a venue to showcase educational entertainment and games to facilitate the mental, moral, and spiritual growth of children and families. Families have very few ways to spend real quality time with their children out in the community. There is no family interaction in a dark movie theater. There is too often just mindless amusement and inappropriate scenes, even in rated G movie. Upright Theater Cafe and Gift Shop is an interactive theater where families watch a presentation (short movie, puppet show, play, or performance) and then compete for prizes in a game show that makes everyone think about what they saw, explore meaning and take it home with them for further discussion. We need to bring more substance into the time we spend with our families. Upright Theater Cafe and Gift Show can help us do that so that we can strengthen our families and make our communities more vibrant. Healthy families make up a healthy community. Our goal is to have an Upright Theater in every small town strip mall across the country.

This project has come a long way but see still need your help to make it to the finish which is Grand Opening. We want to open by the first of June, as school is letting out. At this time we have finished renovations on the main theater, children's theater, gift shop and recording studio. The next step is the cafe/concession stand. This will allow us to serve food and concession items during the events as well as serve breakfast and lunch Monday through Friday to the more than 400 employees that work in the 2 large companies in the plaza. This will provide a strong revenue source to help keep our theater going.  The renovations will include plumbing, electrical, walls, ceilings, flooring, counters, cooking appliances, and initial food items. The rest of the funds collected will go towards cafe seating, a real sign for the building (what you see in the picture is photoshop), an some restroom upgrades. 

The perks we are offering for locals are memberships, which include tickets to the theater and discounts on food and gift items. For those not local we will offer digital files such as educational entertainment video or audio downloads (songs, rap, puppet shows, concerts, and short films). We will also give autograph pictures of our characters Mikey & Mandy and more.

If we fall short of our 25K goal, we will put whatever we have collected toward the renovations required for us to get our certificate from the health department so that we can legally serve catered food during our shows. This is amount 10K. 

The family is the building block to a strong society. Our family system has been breaking down for the past 50 years. Most will agree that the entertainment industry modeled rudeness, disrespect for parents, and infidelity that has contributed to this degradation.  Now it seems that technology is even further isolating family members with everyone texting on their devices with ear buds in their ears. If there is no real communication going on, there is no getting to knowing each other, no caring for each other, no enjoying each other. There is so little time we have in this life. The next thing know your family has for one reason or another dispersed and you wish your could again have an opportunity to talk with them and share some quality time together. 

I have raised a family and know first hand that when we do get that window of opportunity to do something with our spouse and kids we often blow that time on something that fails to facilitate healthy family dialogue and interaction, for example going out to the movies. There is no talking to each other in the theater and the movies are usually too shallow to facilitate any after the movie discussions. Also, if you have kids older and younger kids, the older ones will refuse to go to the rated G movie and end up going on their own the other theater to see a more mature movie. So the family is again split up. 

There is so much good entertainment out there, inspirational films teaching life long lessons that just need to be edited for the whole family to safely view and benefit. A quick edit of a few bad words and 2 second scenes and they are fine. There are educational songs that our kids never hear because love songs dominate the airwaves and always have since the start of pop music since that is what sells. Entertainment is a tremendously effective teaching tool if it is used to teach and not to play on the base desires of the audience with violence, profanity, crass jokes, and nudity. Art should be created and showcased not solely with the intention to sell. When this is the sole motivation, the producers will go to any extreme even if it means throwing an inappropriate scene or joke in a rated G  movie just to help the parents site through the movie. 

By finding, editing and presenting high quality edutainment to families with food, games and prizes, we can help the moral, mental and spiritual development of our children and teens. Also, we can affect the thinking and improve the parenting skill of the parents. Furthermore, we are not just in this for our business to profit. We hope our model of family entertainment will be an example for other venues, schools and religious organizations to duplicate and offer to the families they serve. This job of rebuilding the family and community is too big for one company to take on. 

One challenge we may have is finding content. We plan to overcome this challenge by having a strong social media presence. We will ask the Face Book and Twitter communities to help with the effort of identifying the hidden or forgotten gems of edutainment out there. Fans and followers can post or tweet us films, songs, poems, etc. that they think we should showcase at Upright Theater Cafe & Gift Shop. Another challenge is to raise enough money to pay the license fees needed to present the edutainment we want to present and buy prizes for the gift shop. We believe the income from the cafe will cover these expenses and also we have the support of a non-profit organization called Professional Good Doers, Inc. that will help raise funds for the prizes given in the game show. Also, business we believe business will donate items for advertising purposes. 

Please join this effort by sharing this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools. Spread the word. If you are in the area, please stop by and see us. Thank you all for giving this important effort your time and support. Keep this project in your prayers and keep in touch. 

Sincerely, 

Kenden Dean

story:
A hearty welcome to you, wayward traveler!

Reader beware, this is no ordinary run of the classic Shakespearian tale. Oh no. This is The Tempest as you have never seen it, through the eyes of Kate Szekely.


Who is Kate Szekely?

Kate is many things. First and foremost the captain of this ship, sailing us through this Tempest. Before she wound up in the captain's chair she graduated NYU - Tisch in the Spring of 2013 and has been working tirelessly in different postions in many theatres and various shows around New York City. She is currently the creative director at The Hive NYC, a multifaceted artist collective in Brooklyn, which brings us back to the now. 


The Vision

Kate chose to do this show because not only does it speak to her on a very personal level, but it also touches on a lot issues that we, as a society, are dealing with today. Kate's vision of this classic Shakespearian tale takes us to a dark, murky bayou in a 1830's New Orleans where voodoo runs rampant and forces our characters to look inward at themselves.

The Storm

It is a familiar storm to us all. Fundraising. The plans that we hold for this Tempest are grand ones. The biggest one is giving back to those who have been kind enough to lend their amazing talent and time to this production, the cast. We would love to, at the very least, pay for their transportation to and from rehearsal and show nights to relieve some of the financial strain. The next, and even bigger hurdle, is transporting our audience to the New Orleans bayou in 1830. To do this we would ideally love to cover the house in spanish moss and have dry ice pumping a creeping fog over the floor. Continue to picture a voodoo ritual alter looming up through center stage.In addition to making our audience feel like they're there, we also have to make our cast look convincing. While our costume designers are offering their talents, we still have to get the materials for them to transform into the beautiful pieces the cast will be wearing.




Risks & Challenges

As with any stage production there are many obstacles that Kate and our team are going to face throughout the process. However, how we face them will be a huge factor. Everyone on the team has many years of experience working on a variety of shows big and small. Our biggest factor is time. Something that each person involved is donating to take The Tempest from script to stage. Though we are starting our process early as to avoid the crunch of the clock.   

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, no sweat! There is a multitude of other ways to contribute. One is simply by sharing this page via Facebook, Twitter, any social media means. Maybe you know a person who is looking to write off some tax money for the 2015 fiscal year... Just send them on this way and we can guarantee their money is going to an amazing cause.

story:
Two years ago the good people of Lightning in a Bottle "Voted for Love" and made Amori's Casino & Burlesque a reality. Thanks to the continued support of the Do Lab and your our Amoricans, our growth has been tremendous and we've had the opportunity to touch the hearts of many, many festival goers. 

This year for our third appearance at LIB we are taking things up a MAJOR notch! The incredible Mike Russek and his talented crew at 1028 Designs has designed a beautiful new home for us and we are beginning our fabrication process now.  
Our stage is not our only new upgrade this year, we will also be dazzling your eyes with digital mapping over the entire facade, tickling your ear drums with our very own house band and tantalizing your taste buds with sit down dinners at Amori's.
We just need a little of your love
The Do Lab has generously continued to support Amori's growth, but we have a big "heart-on" for you people and in order to keep topping ourselves and deliver the kind of experience you have come to expect at Amori's Casino and Burlesque we need your help. 
The $5,000 we are asking for will go directly to materials for the new set, video projectors and artists for our digital mapping and funding our house band. Any additional funds we raise will be put right back into our build and making this year at LIB Amori's best year yet! Our new set design will also allow us the ability to begin to scale Amori's and bring it to other festivals so we can truly share the love.

No cash to spare? You can still help spread the love! 

We understand that not all our Amoricans may be able to help with a donation, but you can still help by letting people know about what we are doing! Please share the campaign with your friends by posting, tweeting, instagraming, emailing, snail-mailing, smoke signals, or whatever means you use to communicate with your peeps.

story:
Gigue in the Dark, c’est quoi?

Un projet de gigue contemporaine. Dans le coeur obscur de Montréal.

Les spectateurs entrent. Dans un espace vide, éclairé par des spots, des bougies. Qui s'éteignent, un à un, jusqu'à ce que l'expérience commence. Noir. Silence. On entend des pas de gigue à gauche. Lumière frontale qui s'allume. Un homme danse quelques secondes. Noir. On aperçoit furtivement comme une luciole, une danseuse, avec des lumières collées sur son corps. Noir. Un groupe de gigueurs se fait entendre. On dirait qu'ils avancent, le public doit se déplacer, de peur de ne pas savoir ce qui se passe, ce qui se danse, ce qui se fait entendre. La tension monte. On entend comme un bruit sourd gronder. Que va-t-il se passer encore pour susciter l'appréhension? La surprise? La curiosité?

Gigue in the Dark, c'est plonger le public au cœur d'une expérience sensorielle basée sur le caractère expressif de la gigue. Un spectacle hybride qui carbure à la sensation autant visuelle qu’auditive, autant au toucher qu’au ressenti. Pour susciter autant l'émerveillement que l'inquiétude. Un spectacle interactif que l'on ne pourra vivre passivement.

Venez errer dans cette grande noirceur traversée par des éclats de lumières, habitée par des danseurs-fantômes, venez entendre cette gigue qui suscitera en vous plus d'un frissons. Venez tendre l'oreille pour entendre tous ces bruits produits par les pieds de ceux qui peuplent cet espace poétique. Venez apercevoir des ombres, approchez-vous de ceux qui vous entourent pour vous rassurer. Gigue in the Dark, une expérience pour meubler l'imaginaire des spectateurs, le faire vibrer, capter son attention.

C'est une création de cinq artistes qui sont des expérimentateurs amoureux fous de la gigue : Lük Fleury, Nancy Gloutnez, Sandrine Martel-Laferrière, Philippe Meunier et Ian Yaworski.

Lük Fleury

Nancy Gloutnez

Sandrine Martel-Laferrière

Philippe Meunier

Ian Yaworski

Photos : Valérie Sangin

Soyez les premier testeurs de Gigue in the Dark!

Seuls ceux qui contribueront dans le cadre de cette campagne de socio-financement auront la chance de vivre la nouvelle expérience Gigue in the Dark, la version 0.0, en juin 2016. Personne d'autres que les premiers testeurs sauront où et quand se déroulera cette plongée dans l'inconnu. Vous pourrez déguster ce privilège de raconter par la suite comment vous aurez vécu Gigue in the Dark, de l'intérieur.

La BIGICO, qui sommes-nous?

Fondée en 2005, la BIGICO s'impose de plus en plus dans le paysage de la danse à Montréal comme un diffuseur spécialisé qui orchestre le développement du mouvement de la gigue contemporaine par l'organisation de divers événements publics. La BIGICO attire le respect en privilégiant des démarches créatrices novatrices, personnelles et hors des sentiers battus. Chacune de ses manifestations représente une opportunité pour des artistes authentiques de prendre la parole, sans perdre pied, à cheval entre tradition et modernité. Des artistes résolument contemporains.

La BIGICO assume un rôle de chef de file organisationnel au sein de la discipline et vise ainsi à soutenir son développement dans la philosophie de regrouper des artistes qui oeuvrent autour d’un même médium d’expression. Ce qui unifie tous ces artistes aux horizons différents, c’est leur volonté d’expérimenter autour de la gigue afin de s’exprimer librement sur la perception de la place qu’ils occupent dans la société actuelle.

La BIGICO crée des opportunités uniques de faire valoir sur la place publique l’inventivité d’une société de gigueurs en pleine effervescence. Ce rassemblement de plusieurs visions assure la vitalité d’un mouvement en constante mutation. Inventer une gigue contemporaine, c’est affirmer que nos racines sont encore fortes, que nos pieds ont encore mille et une raisons de s’accrocher au sol pour nous parler encore, ici et maintenant. C’est affirmer que nous sommes tributaires de ceux qui nous ont précédés et qu’à partir de cet héritage, nous créons un langage renouvelé qui témoigne de notre époque, un 21e siècle à la boutonnière. Giguer, c’est un art de vivre. D’aujourd’hui.

Que ferons-nous avec l’argent?

La création de Gigue in the Dark demandera un investissement de temps important de la part des artistes. Tous les dons sont les bienvenus. Soyez assurés que votre argent sera dépensé intelligemment :

-  Rémunérer les artistes

-  Payer des locaux de répétition

-  Trouver le lieu de représentation

Grâce à votre participation, vous permettez aux artistes de s'offrir un luxe : le temps. Le temps de s'investir à fond pour donner vie à un projet novateur pour le monde de la gigue. Gigue in the Dark, c'est un projet rassembleur. Merci de votre générosité.

What is gigue in the Dark?

A contemporary gigue project.  In dark shaded Montreal.

Spectators come into an empty space, lighted up by projectors and candles that die one by one until the experience begins.  Black.  Silence.  We can hear gigue sounds to the left.  Front lights arise.  A man dances for a few seconds.  Black.  Like a firefly, a female dancer wearing LEDS sneaks in. Black.  A group of gigueurs is heard, coming closer and closer, we need to move.  What is being danced?  What are we hearing?  We can feel the tension as this roaring sound intensifies.  What is to happen next?  Surprise?  Curiosity?

Gigue in the Dark intends to immerse the public in the heart of a sensory experience, based on the expressive character of gigue.  It is a hybrid show driven by visual and auditive sensations, by touch and feeling, Provoking both wonder and uneasiness, this show can’t be lived passively.

Come and raom in this darkness crossed with splinters of light, inhabited by ghost-dancers, come and hear this shivering gigue, prick up your ears to the feet of those who fill this poetic space. Take a glimpse of their shadows, get closer to the ones around you for reassurance.  Gigue in the Dark is an experience that will quiver your fantasy.

This work is a co-creation of five artists infaluated with gigue: Luk Fleury, Nancy Gloutnez, Sandrine Martel-Laferrière, Philippe Meunier and Ian Yaworski.

Be the firsts to test Gigue in the Dark!

Only the ones who contribute to this crowdfunding campaign will get the opportunity to live the experience Gigue in the Dark, version 0.0, in june 2016.  No one else will know when and where this swoop in the unknown will take place.  You could have the benefit of reporting to us how you felt the show, from the inside.

BIGICO, who are we?

Founded in 2005, BIGICO establishes itself in Montreal’s dance landscape as a specialized presenter that specifically develops the contemporary gigue movement by organizing different public events.  BIGICO is respected for favouring innovative creative approaches that are personal and unique.  Each event is an opportunity for authentic artists to literally take the floor somewhere in between tradition and modernity.  Decidedly, contemporary artists.   

BIGICO is an organisation leader for the discipline and aims to sustain its development with an inclusive philosophy towards artists that work with the same expression medium.  What brings all these artists together is their willingness to experiment with gigue in order to freely express their stand in today’s society.

BIGICO creates unique opportunities to publicly value the ingenuity of a bubbling society of gigueurs.  These rallied visions ensure the vitality of a movement in constant mutation.  To invent a contemporary gigue is a statement that our roots are still strong, that our feet have thousands of reasons to hand on to the ground to speak to us again, here and now.  It is also asserting that we are conditioned by the ones who preceded us and that with this heritage, we witness our era, creating a renewed language, in the 21st century.  Gigue, is an art of living.  Today.  

How will we invest your money?

Creating Gigue in the Dark demands an important time investment from all five artists involved in the project.  All donations are welcomed.  Be assured that your money will be intelligently spent for : 

-  the artists

-  rehearsal space

-  representation venue

Thanks to your participation, the artists involved will have the luxury of time to fully invest themselves in giving life to an innovative project in the gigue milieu.  Gigue in the Dark is a rallying project.  Thank you for your generosity.

the Dark, c’est quoi?
Un
projet de gigue contemporaine. Dans le coeur obscur de Montréal. 

Les
spectateurs entrent. Dans un espace vide, éclairé par des spots, des bougies. Qui s'éteignent, un à un, jusqu'à ce
que l'expérience
commence. Noir. Silence. On entend des pas de gigue à gauche. Lumière frontale qui
s'allume. Un homme danse quelques secondes. Noir. On aperçoit furtivement
comme une luciole, une danseuse, avec des lumières collées sur son corps.
Noir. Un groupe de gigueurs se fait entendre. On dirait qu'ils avancent, le
public doit se déplacer, de peur de ne pas savoir ce qui se passe, ce qui se
danse, ce qui se fait entendre. La tension monte. On entend comme un bruit
sourd gronder. Que va-t-il se passer encore pour susciter l'appréhension? La
surprise? La curiosité?

Gigue in the Dark,
c'est plonger le public au cœur d'une expérience sensorielle basée sur le caractère expressif de la gigue. Un
spectacle hybride qui carbure à la
sensation autant visuelle qu’auditive, autant au toucher qu’au ressenti. Pour susciter autant l'émerveillement que l'inquiétude. Un spectacle interactif que
l'on ne pourra vivre passivement.
Venez errer dans

suscitera en vous plus d'un frissons. Venez tendre l'oreille pour entendre tous
ces bruits produits par les pieds de ceux qui peuplent cet espace poétique. Venez apercevoir des ombres,
approchez-vous de ceux qui vous entourent pour vous rassurer. Gigue in the

story:
We are...Movement As One

  • Movement As One Dance Company (M.A.O) is an Atlanta-based dance company whose origins stem from the Atlanta Filipino Student Association (ATL FSA) comprised of students from Georgia State University, Georgia Tech, Savannah College of Art and Design, Mercer University, and other surrounding schools. Through ATL FSA, the dance company has competed in various shows and competitions in Georgia and Florida.
  • Movement As One was formed in December 2016 as a standalone student-ran dance organization to not only continue the mission and drive that the dance crew is built upon, but to be a catalyst in MOVING the dance community in Atlanta and surrounding communities AS ONE. 
  • Thus, we need all the support we can to continue the momentum created by the group while we continue to perform, serve, and represent our respective communities. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our overall goal is to raise $4000 that will go towards necessary expenses for operating a dance company such as creative space, audition/competition fees, travel expenses, hosting of events in the community, marketing, etc 
  • Through your contribution we, the dance company, is more than happy to give back to you as our way of saying THANK YOU through a series of perks and rewards ranging from dance workshops, private instruction, mentoring, volunteer our time at your choice of community service, M.A.O merchandise, and more. Be sure to follow our campaign for more details and announcements on perks! 

The Impact

1. The solidification of an open collegiate dance company in the Atlanta-community 

  • We hope to make the dance company a lasting organization to continue the drive set forth by the dance company as well as being a growing asset in the Atlanta dance community. 

2. An avenue for students to learn, express, and hone their skills 

  • As we continue to grow as a dance company, we cherish the growth of our members and anyone who joins, not only in dance but any talent and skill-sets as well! From multimedia, event planning, to academics, we aim to succeed in all aspects of our everyday lives. 

3. A family that "Moves As One" 

  • Our name "Movement As One" is more than just a moniker. It represents our approach and foundation that the group was built on, family. From taking care of one another, mentoring, keeping up with one another, etc Movement As One symbolizes the unification of our physical and emotional connection as a group. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about Movement As One! You can do this by telling your family, coworkers, friends (or pretty much everyone you know) about this project and sharing our Indiegogo fundraising campaign with them!  We appreciate every post, phone call, and gesture made on our behalf.  Follow our social media platforms to stay up-to-date on what we have going on! 

Once again, Thank You Very Much!

Check out and SHARE our website!  www.movementasone.com 

LIKE us on Facebook! http://www.facebook.com/maodancecompany

FOLLOW us on Instagram!  http://www.instagram.com/maodancecompany

Subscribe to our Youtube Channel!  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChIY5rTqW4fwgw...

Movement As One Dance Company (M.A.O) is an Atlanta-based dance company whose origins stem from the Atlanta Filipino Student Association (ATL FSA) comprised of students from Georgia State University, Georgia Tech, Savannah College of Art and Design, Mercer University, and other surrounding schools. Through ATL FSA, the dance company has competed in various shows and competitions in Georgia and Florida.
Movement As One was formed in December 2016 as a standalone student-ran dance organization to not only continue the mission and drive that the dance crew is built upon, but to be a catalyst in MOVING the dance community in Atlanta and surrounding communities AS ONE. 
Thus, we need all the support we can to continue the momentum created by the group while we continue to perform, serve, and represent our respective communities.

Through your contribution we, the dance company, is more than happy to give back to you as our way of saying THANK YOU through a series of perks and rewards ranging from dance workshops, private instruction, mentoring, volunteer our time at your choice of community service, M.A.O merchandise, and more. We hope to make the dance company a lasting organization to continue the drive set forth by the dance company as well as being a growing asset in the Atlanta dance community.

As we continue to grow as a dance company, we cherish the growth of our members and anyone who joins, not only in dance but any talent and skill-sets as well! From multimedia, event planning, to academics, we aim to succeed in all aspects of our everyday lives.

story:
Summary

Medicine Ball: Playwrights v. Poets is a one of its kind silo busting festival that brings playwrights, poets, visual, artists, theatre artists, and musicians together for a weekend long interdisciplinary festival. We bring together 7 playwrights and 7 poets and pair them up – playwright v. poet. Each pair of writers is given a visual prompt by a local artist that they have to write toward. Then our ensemble of actors and directors rehearse and stage the plays and poems and present them over the course of 7 rounds during one evening like a boxing match. Over the course of the weekend run, audiences vote of each of the 7 rounds of the competition. While we announce a winning group of writers each night – either the poets or the playwrights – the cumulative winners are for this edition announced on Saturday night. This year's edition is scheduled to run June 22 - 24 at the Erickson Theatre, 1524 Harvard Ave, Seattle, WA 9812 and will focus on the theme of unity.

What We Need and What You Get

We need funds to help rent rehearsal space, buy materials, and pay for marketing. Since this is a one weekend event due to the nature of it, the overhead often exceeds the amount we bring in through ticket sales. So we are seeking $1,300 or more to help with production costs.

What you get in return are a variety of rewards including advance tickets, a voucher for a free drink at the show, a Medicine Ball: Playwrights v. Poets T-Shirt, a thumb drive with the material from the show on it, a copy of the event poster, a shout out on social media, and mention on both our website and in the program.

Whatever money we earn will go toward the show.

Impact

Medicine Ball: Playwrights v. Poets is a community building event as much as it is a showcase for the talents of a wide variety of artists from multiple genres and disciplines. Where else can you as an audience member go and enjoy an event that will expose you to poetry, playwriting, acting, music, and visual art – all by local artists?

In addition, we are focusing on the theme of “unity” this year due to the divisive political climate of late. Given this, we have not only recruited an incredibly diverse group of people to participate, but we are also opening our door to students for free. If you have a current school ID, we will allow people in at no cost.

Risks and Challenges

Producing theatre is always a risky venture financially. Because of the nature of the show, we can only run it one weekend, which makes it hard to recoup the investment. So even the smallest amount people can donate toward this cause will help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word. Share this fundraiser with your friends on social media. Endorse it. Post your own video telling people why you like Medicine Ball: Playwrights v. Poets. Word of mouth is always key to a grassroots effort like this.

story:
Here's what we're doing:

Minneapolis /St. Paul is home to one of the most vibrant and thriving theatre communities in the country, and small performance companies are one of the principal drivers of this incredible scene.  But there are not enough places to stage all the rich work being done.  Well, there's a great space lurking right behind Lake Monster Brewery in St. Paul -  a space that Gremlin Theatre is stepping up to build out into a new 120 seat theatre, not only as a home for our productions, but also to host dozens of other companies and performance arts groups who really need a space to produce.  You can make a huge difference in the performing arts - be a part of this project!

Theatre should be social -  a great show and a great time.  And what’s more social than beer with your art?

About the new space:

Conveniently located right off I-94 and Cretin at 550 Vandalia Street and within walking distance of the light-rail Green Line, Vandalia Tower has become a bustling artistic hub for organizations from The Independent Film Project to the Saint Paul Neighborhood Network and contains the offices and studios of many artists and performing arts groups.  Fronted by Lake Monster Brewery, Vandalia Tower features a large courtyard and welcoming patio, complete with rotating food trucks on evenings and weekends and a tap room to wet your whistle and mingle with the neighborhood. 

The new theatre will feature a thrust stage with audience members sitting up close and personal: no more than four rows deep with excellent sight-lines on all three sides.  There will be a large new lobby and box office with high ceilings and easy access to the building’s new and abundant bathrooms.  The theatre will be fully wheelchair-accessible and plentiful free parking is available in the lot surrounding the building. 

Once up and running, Gremlin Theatre plans to stage full production seasons in this performance space as well as host performing arts groups of widely varied backgrounds, keeping the theatre in use year round. 

What We Need & What You Get

There's no way around it; building a new theatre is a huge challenge and a ton of work.  But we believe passionately in the power of live performance and we are dedicated to serving our audiences and the Twin Cities Theatre community.  Great performance spaces are really in need!  We're willing to do the work, we just need a little help from you.  Contribute today and pass the word on.  Together, we can get there.

Here's how you can help:

We're looking to raise $25,000 toward our $100,000 project through our Friend of a Friend campaign.  That's a lot of money!  Well, it's a big project.  Here's what it will go toward:

  • Demolition
  • Construction of demising and interior walls & sound insulation
  • New mechanicals (like heating & air conditioning)
  • Electrical supply and distribution
  • Plumbing
  • Painting, carpeting & finishes
  • Re-installation of Gremlin's lighting, sound, staging, seating & equipment

In short, everything to make a fantastic, intimate, dynamic performance space that we'll be proud to have you in and that you'll be excited to be in.

We're asking that you help us out with a small financial gift.  You'll be amazed how far your support can go.  If 1,000 friends each give just $25, well, we've met our goal.  

And we have something for you:  

If you can help us with a donation of $25 today, you'll not only have the satisfaction of building a new theatre and basking in the glow of altruism, but your $25 donation gets you access to special rotating Theatre Friends ticket discounts that will be available during our first season, as well as notices on Theatre Friends happy hours throughout the year at Lake Monster so you can come check us out and meet us.

Of course, we'd love it if you are able to help us out with a little bit more, as the difference that can make is astronomical.   If you can support us with $50 (or more!), not only will you get access to rotating Theatre Friends discounts, but you'll be invited to one of our special Thank You events this spring at Lake Monster Brewery before the theatre even opens where we'll get to meet you and say thank you in person!   You'll receive a tour of the new space, meet and mingle with other Gremlin supporters & friends, chat with Gremlin actors, directors & designers, and your first beer of the night is on us!  Come celebrate your part in making a new theatre for this amazing community with a frosty cold one.

To donate: Click on either of the perks at right or enter your amount at the top of the page.  Anything greater than $50 will automatically get both the perks listed!

The Impact

Why help us?  Can we be trusted? Don’t know much about Gremlin Theatre?  Want to know more about us?  Here’s a little background (and why this makes a difference):

Founded in January of 1998, Gremlin Theatre is a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization dedicated to providing high-quality professional theatre in an intimate setting, both through our own productions and through the numerous groups that we host throughout the year. 

Gremlin has built and operated two different performance facilities in St. Paul: The Loading Dock Theater in Lowertown (2002-2008) and The Gremlin Theatre on University Avenue near Highway 280 & Raymond Avenue (2008-2013).    Since 2013, Gremlin has been producing in a wide variety of locales and theatres while looking for the opportunity to build a long-term facility. 

As a producing company, Gremlin shows routinely garner critical acclaim and we have partnered with some of the best artists in the Twin Cities while producing in theatres and venues from The Hennepin Theatre Trust to an efficiency apartment studio to the kitchen of the James J. Hill House.  Consistently named to Top Ten lists, Gremlin has twice been honored with Ivey Awards and was named “Best Theater Deal” and “Artist of the Year” by Mpls/St. Paul Magazine and City Pages respectively.

In addition to the nearly sixty productions Gremlin has staged as a company, we have provided a theater facility for dozens of performance arts groups over the years.  These have ranged from summer workshop programs for Saint Paul youth to performing arts groups from such diverse backgrounds as Teatro del Pueblo, Pangaea World Theatre, The Young Artists’ Initiative, Walking Shadow, The Center for Hmong Arts and Talent, Theatre Pro Rata and The Twin Cities German Immersion School (to name but a few).  Gremlin was also successful in bringing the Minnesota Fringe Festival to St. Paul for the first time and was a Fringe venue for four years. The influx of thousands of Fringe patrons to the University/Raymond area over ten days each August was great for St. Paul and the diversity of cultural offerings that came with the Fringe was simply unparalleled.  All told, in just the five years Gremlin operated our 100 seat Theatre on University Avenue (2008-2013), we served over 35 different performing arts groups, 500 artists and 30,000 patrons. 

We could go on and on - but we promise we won't.  Let's talk in person.  We'd love to hear about you.  Help us out and then come and meet us.  We can't wait to meet you!

Other Ways You Can Help

There's one other thing you can do for us.  It's quick, it's easy.  Help us get the word out.  Pass us on to your friends.  After all, this is the Friend of a Friend campaign and we'd love an introduction.  We're trying to build this theatre from the bottom up and we want to meet 1,000 new friends.  Help us get there!  (Remember, you can always share us with Facebook or Indiegogo's sharing tools as well. )

Thank you so much - we're looking forward to being friends!

Peter Christian Hansen, Carl Schoenborn, Sarah Bauer, Ellen Fenster, Lindsey Hansen, Jonna Kosalko & Casey Radmann
story_txt:
Here's what we're doing:
Minneapolis /St. Paul is home to one of the most vibrant and thriving theatre communities in the country, and small performance companies are one of the principal drivers of this incredible scene.  But there are not enough places to stage all the rich work being done.  Well, there's a great space lurking right behind Lake Monster Brewery in St. Paul -  a space that Gremlin Theatre is stepping up to build out into a new 120 seat theatre, not only as a home for our productions, but also to host dozens of other companies and performance arts groups who really need a space to produce.  You can make a huge difference in the performing arts - be a part of this project!
Theatre should be social -  a great show and a great time.  And what’s more social than beer with your art?
About the new space:
Conveniently located right off I-94 and Cretin at 550 Vandalia Street and within walking distance of the light-rail Green Line, Vandalia Tower has become a bustling artistic hub for organizations from The Independent Film Project to the Saint Paul Neighborhood Network and contains the offices and studios of many artists and performing arts groups.  Fronted by Lake Monster Brewery, Vandalia Tower features a large courtyard and welcoming patio, complete with rotating food trucks on evenings and weekends and a tap room to wet your whistle and mingle with the neighborhood. 
The new theatre will feature a thrust stage with audience members sitting up close and personal: no more than four rows deep with excellent sight-lines on all three sides.  There will be a large new lobby and box office with high ceilings and easy access to the building’s new and abundant bathrooms.  The theatre will be fully wheelchair-accessible and plentiful free parking is available in the lot surrounding the building. 
Once up and running, Gremlin Theatre plans to stage full production seasons in this performance space as well as host performing arts groups of widely varied backgrounds, keeping the theatre in use year round. 

What We Need & What You Get
There's no way around it; building a new theatre is a huge challenge and a ton of work.  But we believe passionately in the power of live performance and we are dedicated to serving our audiences and the Twin Cities Theatre community.  Great performance spaces are really in need!  We're willing to do the work, we just need a little help from you.  Contribute today and pass the word on.  Together, we can get there.
Here's how you can help:
We're looking to raise $25,000 toward our $100,000 project through our Friend of a Friend campaign.  That's a lot of money!  Well, it's a big project.  Here's what it will go toward:

Demolition
Construction of demising and interior walls & sound insulation
New mechanicals (like heating & air conditioning)
Electrical supply and distribution
Plumbing
Painting, carpeting & finishes
Re-installation of Gremlin's lighting, sound, staging, seating & equipment

In short, everything to make a fantastic, intimate, dynamic performance space that we'll be proud to have you in and that you'll be excited to be in.
We're asking that you help us out with a small financial gift.  You'll be amazed how far your support can go.  If 1,000 friends each give just $25, well, we've met our goal.  
And we have something for you:

story:
Third Avenue Playhouse has presented me with the opportunity to perform the one woman show, The Amish Project, as part in their 2016 spring season. 

Your support would allow me to bring this beautiful show to Door County, continue my research on the play, alleviate the financial strain of relocating to Sturgeon Bay for the length of the run and create impacting community conversations about the play's themes. Themes that include gun violence, faith, and forgiveness.  

If the fundraising goal is met I will create curriculum for pre and post show workshops that would be provided free of charge to schools, places of worship and other community organizations. These workshops would be tailored the needs of the participants, taking into account varying interests and abilities. 

Me before my understudy run of The Amish Project at The Milwaukee Rep, which will be produced at Third Avenue Playhouse in March of 2016! 


The Play

The Amish Project, written and originally performed by Jessica Dickey, is a fictional exploration of the Nickel Mines schoolhouse shooting in an Amish Community and the path to forgiveness and compassion in its wake. One actress plays seven characters who have each been affected by the tragic event. To learn more about the events the play is based on, click here. To learn more about the original production, click here. 

The Theater

Third Avenue Playhouse is the only year-round professional theater in Door County. In their four seasons as co-artistic directors, James Valcq and Robert Boles have continuously brought unique programming to their intimate space. James, Bob and their artistic associate, Ryan Patrick Shaw, have committed themselves to advancing the arts in Door County. I am lucky to have such staunch supporters and collaborators.

The Actress

I just recently concluded my second summer at Third Avenue Playhouse, this time as the artist in residence performing in Educating Rita, Steel Magnolias, Sylvia and I Love a Piano. I made my TAP debut in Private Lives after making my professional debut in Skylight Music Theater's production of Hair. A Milwaukee native, I was thrilled to be a part of the Milwaukee Rep's acting ensemble this past season appearing in A Christmas Carol and Rep Lab. While at the Rep, I understudied Deb Staples in The Amish Project directed by Leda Hoffmann. As part of my understudy duties I led workshops at area high schools and moderated a pre show discussion before each performance. To learn more about my whole deal, visit my website. 


Thank you!

All contributions are greatly appreciated and any amount is helpful! 

If you find yourself without the funds to donate, please consider sharing information about The Amish Project on Facebook or in real life. I'm so thrilled to be able to share this special piece with Door County and really appreciate you taking the time to learn more about it!

story:
Retorika - performance, installations, video art productions
 

Premiere: 

Kino Šiška Centre for Urban Culture, Ljubljana, Slovenia 10.9. 2015, 20.00

International Premiere: 

Uferstudios, Berlin, Germany 28.1. & 29.1. 2016



Concept and realization: Bara Kolenc and Atej Tutta

Performers: Sanja Nešković Peršin, Bara Kolenc, Rebeka Radovan

Dramaturgy: Pia Brezavšček

Sound design: Jernej Černalogar

The Rumours song: Matevž Kolenc

Make up: Anja Cojhter

Technical support: Radovan Jaušovec

Executive producers: Bara Kolenc and Julia Danila

Produced by Kud Samosvoj

Co-produced by: Kino Šiška Centre for Urban Culture, Kud Pozitiv, Plesna Izba Maribor, Uferstudios Berlin

Supported by Ministry of Culture, Republic of Slovenia



Bara Kolenc, a performing artist from Ljubljana, and Atej Tutta, a visual artist from Venice, are preparing their new transmedia project Retorika.

Kolenc and Tutta are counting on your support to put on performance Retorika, which will premiere on 10 September 2015 in Ljubljana, at the Kino Šiška Centre for Urban Culture, and then be performed in Berlin, at Uferstudios.




Retorika is the third

Retorika is the third part of a more complex long-term project Metamorphoses 1–5, which consists of 5 performances, various installations and video art productions.  

Central to Metamorphoses 1-5 are particular 'civilised' political and moral human passions that, due to the contemporary feeling of political powerlessness, the disintegration of imagined communities, the impotence of language and the growing oppositions between nature and culture, assume a universal character and thus radically intervene in the modes of communal living.


_____________________________________________________________________________


Become part of the Retorika project

If you support us, you will not only earn our endless gratitude, but also contribute to the critical and poetic disclosure of contemporary rhetorical principles, the art of political, media and economic persuasion and the insurmountable power of the voice.


Retorika is a multilevel rhizomatic art project which was launched in 2015 and will be continuously developed in the coming years. It acts as a flaring network of artistic and theoretical gestures that reflect today's use and abuse of rhetorical principles in politics, media and market. 




Retorika proposes intelligent and subtle channels that pierce through the established rhetorical mechanisms.

_____________________________________________________________________________


No criticism, borderline actions!
No panic, a thought!
No silence, voice!


_____________________________________________________________________________


With your support

So far, our projects have been supported mostly by Slovenian public funds. During the European crisis, the already limited funds were severely cut. That is why we lack the essential part of our budget for Retorika.

With your support, we will be able to cover the costs of:

- THE SET-UP

- THE COSTUMES

- THE TRANSPORT

- THE PRINT

- TRAVEL COSTS


Retorika Project is carefully designed in terms of rationalisation of costs and resources.

__________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Perks
You can help us by buying one of our high-quality perks. Some of them have been designed especially for the Indiegogo project, while others are special art objects, including genuine elements of our set design. (weekly updated)

_____________________________________________________________________________

2eur
#THX #LOVE
Thanks for Making Things Happen!

_____________________________________________________________________________

250eur

CHARCOAL - Drawing Logos

The limited edition of the “The Retorika Charcoal Logo” is the oldest sketching and drawing material in the world.

Laser cut plywood, charcoal

Dimensions approx. 38 x 11 x 0,5CM


_____________________________________________________________________________

1500eur

RETORIKA SPEAKER 

Retorika Speaker has sixteen different titles and contents. You can choose one between: Prenner, sister, choose, Twitter, reality, mattress, after, court, Ljuba, voice, no, sense, Love, Kino Šiška, Retorika, future.

This is a limited edition object that is a part of the set-design of the Retorika performance.

Speaker cabinet with a specific audio content for each title.

40W/8 Ohms drivers, Class-D Stereo Amplifier TI TPA3116D Chip.



_____________________________________________________________________________

3500eur

Mecenate Par Excellence - SILVER

Become an Associate Producer.

Your financial contribution  will become a great support for the Retorika project.

Your name will be mentioned in media appearance of our project.

_____________________________________________________________________________
7000eur
Mecenate Par Excellence - GOLD
Become a Co-Producer.
Your financial contribution will become so relevant for the project that you will directly be considered as Co-Producer of the Retorika Project.
Your name will be mentioned in media appearance of our project.


__________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

More perks coming soon! 

Check our facebook and indiegogo pages.
Please share the link to this campaign on your social networks!

__________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Thank you! Be with us!

_____________________________________________________________________________

Thanks for the campaign realization: Mitja Cerkvenik, Matevž Kolenc, Ronny Stepfen, Mina Špiler

_____________________________________________________________________________


Concept

Retorika World

Retorika deals with the problem of language as the fundamental structure of the subject and discourse, focusing especially on the establishment of artificial identities, the creation of public opinion, construction of artificial realities, manipulation and propaganda.

Ideology is the belief that the word has real effects. That a word generates an action; only within ideology, can we give our word of honour and be men of our word. The 20th century is a century of ideologies, their rise, their realisation, materialisation, embodiment, fleshiness and bloodiness. In this sense – and here we can concur with Badiou – the 20th century has lived out its passion for the real.

Rhetoric stands on the other side – where there is rhetoric there is no ideology. For rhetoric believes only the word and only at the time it is spoken. It is not interested in real effects. Rhetoric functions only in the realm of language, operating with arguments and counter-arguments. Rhetoric is a skill, a collection of instructions on the use of the means of persuasion, reasonable argumentation, reactions to the challenges of collocutors, composition of an effective speech, coordination of verbal and non-verbal language, correct listening, reading and writing. While ideologists stand behind their words and use them as a means of persuading the audience into something they believe in, rhetoricians do not believe what they say or, better yet, believe only what they say and not a supposed reality beyond language, which this speech is supposed to represent. 



Free Speech Slavery

Today, everything is rhetorical – television, internet, blogs, websites, politics, culture, art, science. In consumer society and neoliberal democracy, rhetoric is one of the key means of manipulation. PR (Public Relations) is the most vibrant realization of post-structuralists and psychoanalytical discovery, that speech as such is not merely a dry linguistic structure: it is fleshy, it inhabits the speaker’s body and voice and influences the listener directly (at the level of associations, emotions, passions, subconscious psychic operations).

It is not about the content, it is about triggering the desire.

The presupposition of our collocutor’s truthfulness with which we usually enter a conversation gives way to the presupposition of their deceptiveness. It is precisely because in neoliberalism rhetoric became the art of concealing the actual interest and of preparing and delivering the best and most persuasive quasi-argumentation possible that it today connotes fabrication, falseness and verbal virtuosity, which serves as the armour of trickery, fraudulence and exploitation.

Insofar as neoliberalism, which is set on silencing and suppressing the demands for egalitarianism and social justice, almost pathetically stresses individual liberties, parading the freedom of speech, it kills two flies with one stone.

For not only does it forget social justice (changing it into humanitarianism, which is directly opposed to the idea of fraternity and equality), but with the freedom of speech, which is actually unrestricted (censorship exists only as a concealed mechanism, while the official line is that it remained behind the iron curtain a long time ago), it achieves a liberation from the burden of ideological single-mindedness and the weight of one truth. But it does so only to throw speech to the lions, into the arena of (free) economy and consumerism, forcing it to start fighting for its place, to become manipulative. Thus, it is paradoxically precisely (free) speech that enslaves.

Another paradox here is that within the flood of information in the sense of anything goes we do not witness the degradation of the value of truth - truth doesn't dissipate in total devaluation. The situation is exactly the opposite: in the era of virtual capitalism, truth, structured as fiction, obtains its monetary value. 

Truth indeed is no more truthful, but it has acquired another quality: 

today the truth is real. 

It produces capital.
