While ideologists stand behind their words and use them as a means of persuading the audience into something they believe in, rhetoricians do not believe what they say or, better yet, believe only what they say and not a supposed reality beyond language, which this speech is supposed to represent. 





Free Speech Slavery


Today, everything is rhetorical – television, internet, blogs, websites, politics, culture, art, science. In consumer society and neoliberal democracy, rhetoric is one of the key means of manipulation. PR (Public Relations) is the most vibrant realization of post-structuralists and psychoanalytical discovery, that speech as such is not merely a dry linguistic structure: it is fleshy, it inhabits the speaker’s body and voice and influences the listener directly (at the level of associations, emotions, passions, subconscious psychic operations).
It is not about the content, it is about triggering the desire.
The presupposition of our collocutor’s truthfulness with which we usually enter a conversation gives way to the presupposition of their deceptiveness. It is precisely because in neoliberalism rhetoric became the art of concealing the actual interest and of preparing and delivering the best and most persuasive quasi-argumentation possible that it today connotes fabrication, falseness and verbal virtuosity, which serves as the armour of trickery, fraudulence and exploitation.
Insofar as neoliberalism, which is set on silencing and suppressing the demands for egalitarianism and social justice, almost pathetically stresses individual liberties, parading the freedom of speech, it kills two flies with one stone.
For not only does it forget social justice (changing it into humanitarianism, which is directly opposed to the idea of fraternity and equality), but with the freedom of speech, which is actually unrestricted (censorship exists only as a concealed mechanism, while the official line is that it remained behind the iron curtain a long time ago), it achieves a liberation from the burden of ideological single-mindedness and the weight of one truth. But it does so only to throw speech to the lions, into the arena of (free) economy and consumerism, forcing it to start fighting for its place, to become manipulative. Thus, it is paradoxically precisely (free) speech that enslaves.
Another paradox here is that within the flood of information in the sense of anything goes we do not witness the degradation of the value of truth - truth doesn't dissipate in total devaluation. The situation is exactly the opposite: in the era of virtual capitalism, truth, structured as fiction, obtains its monetary value. 
Truth indeed is no more truthful, but it has acquired another quality: 
today the truth is real. 
It produces capital.

story:
Share the AADC legacy with the world

For 41 years under founding director Professor Iris Rosa, The African American Dance Company has been telling stories of the African diaspora and inspiring audiences all over the Midwest. But the company has yet to perform overseas and share this astounding legacy with more people. Now is our chance.

Professor Rosa and the African American Dance Company have been invited to present at  The Rex Nettleford Arts Conference, an international arts and education conference in Kingston, Jamaica this October. Professor Rosa will have the opportunity to teach master classes, and AADC dancers will perform some of her works. This is an incredible opportunity that we can't miss!

AADC will perform excerpts from Professor Rosa's production titled "Confinement" at the conference. View more images from last year's African American Dance Company Spring Concert in the Gallery.


We need your help to send AADC to Jamaica!

Our goal is to raise enough funds to register dancers for the conference by July 15, and begin booking flights soon thereafter. 

As Professor Rosa said in the video, this is an incredible opportunity to represent the company around the world. But an even greater opportunity for the young dancers, giving them an international arts experience that will impact their awareness and lives. Your donation will help cover these expenses for approximately 10 AADC students: 

  • Conference registration: $80 per person
  • Airfare: approx. $700 per person
  • Hotel: $119/night (approx. 3 rooms)
  • Meals: $100 per person
  • Ground transportation: $40 per person
Any donation will help! No amount is too small. 

Other ways you can help

  • Share our campaign with your friends! Use the social media share tools.
  • Follow our journey on social media! We'll be posting with #AADCinJamaica

story:
Who?!

Our Company

Me.Him Theatre is a new company created by LIPA graduates Adam Charteris and Richard Parnwell. 
Me.Him is a company solely focused on new writing and making highly theatrical shows with simple production values.

The Story

Saint Nick is a Christmas comedy that tells the story of travelling pipe-cleaner salesman, Nick, who is fighting to get home in time for Christmas and stop his boss from stealing his family.



What We Need

We are looking to raise £1500 to help start the company and launch our first show, Saint Nick, in London & Peterborough this Christmas, with the future aim of taking the show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival next August.
The money will help us...
  • Pay for venue hire and technical equipment
  • Copyright the play 
  • Props & Costume
  • Advertising
  • Company branding (i.e logos and website)
  • Pay our four actors



What's In It For Me(Him)?!

We are grateful for every donation and every bit of help you can give us, and to show you just how much it means to Me.Him, we have some stocking fillers for you in our perks!

What'll It Do For You(Him)?!
Your support will not only allow us to put the show on, but help Me.Him grow our audience base. We want people to know about our work and help us begin our journey to perform the show in Edinburgh.



It Isn't Gonna Be Easy...

We know that as a new company, our main challenge is to build an audience. Our hope is that by attaching ourselves to well-established new writing theatres, or venues with a regular audience base; we'll be able to develop a diverse audience across London as well as creating working relationships with these theatres.


#ChristmasSpirit

If you are unable to donate, you can still make all our Christmas dreams come true by following us on Twitter @MeHimTheatre or on Facebook, and start spreading the word.

But most of all, come and see the show!

story:
A Midsummer Night's Masquerade - 

June 18th 2016, Holiday Inn Sheffield

Our vision

We are aiming to start an annual celebration of the summer in the most opulent way we can think of, with a full masquerade ball, including 3 course meal, dancing, and continuous entertainment. All set to an appropriate theme for the time of year.

For our first year, we're aiming for a Faery Ball, based on "A Midsummer Night's Dream" by Shakespeare, with faeries, pixies, nixies, boggarts, goblins, hobgoblins and beastfolk.

It's our vision to provide a high end event that you'll never forget. But to do that, we need money.

Initial budget has worked out a cost of about £7000, based on minimum figures of 150 attendees.

While we're investing in this, we just can't afford to risk that much on our own.

Our aim is to raise £3000 towards costs for room hire, and securing the performers that we want at the event, but more than that it will show us that there is enough interest in the event.

Put bluntly we need to know this event will come at least close to a break even point to risk the amount of money we're putting into it. Should it make profit, we're pledging 25% of those profits to local charity, Weston Park Cancer Hospital, whereas the other 75% will be redirected into the next event (we're hoping to do a Yule ball as well).

Performance

We are currently in negotiation with several acts to provide you entertainment throughout the night including 

  • A string duo or quartet to serenade you while you eat and provide a background for ballroom dancing
  • A dance teacher to lead us through the formal dances for those of us that haven't danced before
  • Death defying stunts and comedy from a world class side show artist and comedian Preacher Muad'dib
  • Burlesque from fantastical creatures by Nenedhel Absynthium and Pansy Cheung
  • Music from a renowned folk/rock band
  • A host of other faery related distractions

Dress code

We will be enforcing a strict dress code of extravagance and masks with a faery theme.

Pricing

Full price tickets will be £50 each, inclusive of a 3 course meal, music, cabaret, and more. This campaign will be offering early bird tickets, as well as special deals on hotel rooms (prices currently under negotiation).

We're also currently working on additional perks, including professional photography and event merchandise, and are currently in negotiation with some vendors about supplying masks for our contributors.

Perks

We are starting with just early bird tickets for both singles and couples, but more will appear as we negotiate deals with the hotel and merchandise suppliers.

story:
We are Matthew...

We at Opera Fusion believe that the genre of opera or “musical drama” must take on current issues. For our second season we are undertaking an ambitious project: the premiere of Not In My Town, a musical drama in one 90-minute act written by Fort Lauderdale composer Michael W. Ross, based on the events surrounding the death of Matthew Shepard, a young, gay college student who was beaten, tied to a fence, and left to die. 

Matthew's story is one of tragedy, but ultimate triumph for those in the LGBTQA community dealing with the same issues. The Hate Crimes Act (The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act) aids all groups that have been bullied, physically abused, or violated for reasons as simple as sexual orientation, color of skin, or chosen religion. 

The composer of Not In My Town, Michael Ross, says it perfectly: "I wanted to write this piece because I want people to understand that good can come from such a terrible tragedy." 

To protect Matthew's family from seeing and hearing the hateful members of the Westboro Baptist Church who were protesting at the funeral and the trials, Matthew's best friend, Romaine Patterson, founded Angel Action. To physically block the protesters from view, these people dressed as angels and spread their wings. Be an Angel and help us to tell Matthew's story. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are embarking on a fundraising campaign to raise $150,000 for the production and marketing of four performances planned in Fort Lauderdale, West Palm Beach, and Miami in June 2016. We also look forward to partnering with organizations and individuals who are active in the LGBTQA and Human Rights communities. 

This Musical Drama requires seven singing parts, two mute parts, double chorus, and a nine-piece orchestra. Opera Fusion will be using only local singers of the highest caliber. In addition, international opera star and Opera Fusion’s own Dean Peterson will be directing. The set will be simple and rear projection screens will be used to enhance the set and mood. Because the set is easily transportable, the singers are local, and the orchestra is small, the production cost will be much, much lower than conventional operas. 
Usually, in a medium sized opera house the average production cost, not including artist fees, can run well over $350,000 per production. The average cost for opening a Broadway musical? Well over $10 million!

For our productions, here's the breakdown:
- Theatre Rentals- $15,000 
- Marketing- $35,000 (gotta get the word out!!)
- Set and Costumes- $10,000
- Artist Fees (Chorus)- $24,000
- Artist Fees (Conductor & Orchestra)- $14,000
- Artist Fees (Soloists)-  $22,000
- Artist Fees (Rehearsal Pianists)- $4,000
- Director/Production Manager- $6,000 
- Crew- $2,000
- Composer- $5,000
- Perks!- $13,000
We have a large range of perks for our Angels! From anywhere between $5 and $20,000 you can be a part of this production.
The musical drama will feature a mosaic of pictures as a backdrop. This mosaic will be a snapshot of all of our contributors (if they wished to provide a photo.) For only a $5 donation you can be part of the mosaic of people who stand with Matthew. 
Want to be more hands on? Our $10,000 perk, Be an Angel, gets you ONSTAGE as one of the Angels of Angel Action!
We understand that even though we are only asking for a fraction of what a larger production would cost, we might not meet our goal. Have no fear. Even if we do not reach our goal, you will still receive your selected perks and we will put on at least one performance of Not In My Town. 
Keep an eye out for our updates!!
The Impact
One of our core values is the use of local talent in our shows. Too often, talented musicians go without the opportunity to perform lead roles in full productions. It is our goal to always hire as much local talent as we can. 
Composer of Not In My Town, Michael Ross, is part of the local talent that we thrive on. Birgit Fioravante, the Executive Director of Opera Fusion, says about Michael's music, "No matter what part of Michael's many works I listen to, I am always moved. Modern opera and musical dramas are often seen as hard to relate to, but that is not the case with Michael's music." This is the first of his stunning work that has been performed on this scale. 
Opera Fusion Inc., a nonprofit artist-driven company, is based in West Palm Beach and will mount shows throughout South Florida.  It is beginning its second season.  In its first season, Opera Fusion successfully put on two musical revues, “The Sopranos: An Opera You Can’t Refuse” and “Duelling Divas” as well as two operas, “Bluebeard’s Castle” and “Cosi Fan Tutte/Die Fledermaus” in a summer “bootcamp” workshop. Our team has a collective experience of well over 75 years in all aspects of music and theater! We have created amazing things on a shoestring budget in the past and feel confident we can bring something amazing to the public. We have the talent, we have the passion, now all we need is our Angels!

I can't contribute right now, but how can I still help?

Help us spread the word! Word of mouth is our most powerful tool. Does Matthew's story move you? Does Michael's music inspire you? Share that feeling with your friends and family. Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, with email, through smoke signals, however you like to communicate! Be sure to use #IamMatthew!
Have you seen our productions before? We would love to share your testimonial! We appreciate any help you can offer us! Thank you in advance to ALL of our ANGELS!

story:
Defaulting on trillions of dollars in US treasury debt to China, a concord is signed in the year 2018, giving America two years to pay their debt to China, but China has no intention of handing our country back to us. 

Why should they? 

Would anything change?

The plot of the play centers on the trial of Miriam Hopkins, who at the time of default, turns from being an anti-American terrorist to an American patriot, fighting against the takeover of her country.

The trial comes down to the conflict between the newly formed UNITED STATES OF CHINA ,and the deceit of a people who failed in their collective responsibility to themselves — bringing about their downfall.

The UNITED STATES OF CHINA is a new, full-length play to open in Seattle on in March of 2016, for an initial run of 6 - 9 weeks.

This is much more than a unique theatrical experience — it's a wake-up call for all of America — and perhaps the world.

Something has got to give - or we may go under! 

The play was originally produced as a series of readings in 
Seattle Center in December, 2015. 
The audience reaction/reviews were uniform:



James Patrick  


Stephen Sumida


Campaign starts on December 18, 2015, ends January 22, 2016.

FLEXIBLE FUNDING

  $10  |  Gets you a listing in the "Special Thanks" section of the playbill.

  $10 and up   |  Gets any Asian-American contributing $10 or more an extra role in                                   the play.

  $30  |  gets you a limited edition play poster.

  $40  |  Gets you a personalized signed script- with a special signed note from Nick                  and the rest of the cast.

  $50  |  gets you a play T-shirt.

  $75  |  Gets you to sit in on dress rehearsal and offer feedback.

$100  |  Gets you an invitation to opening night.

$250  |  Gets you and invite to cast and crew party; two seats to opening night                            performance, and a personal thank you on opening night; and a signed,                          hard copy of the script.

story:
Ibsen comes to Halifax

Head First Productions brings together Director Dorian Lang and Actor Margaret Legere to stage Ibsen's Hedda Gabler.

Our goals for the project

Head First Productions is committed to supporting Professional Artists while working on this demanding project.  Our hope is to gather funds through grants, sponsorship, and crowd funded support.  

We're pleased to announce the full cast for this production:

Mauralea Austin as Aunt Julie

Kim Parkhill as Berta

Andrew Chandler as Tesman

Margaret Legere as Hedda

Henricus Gielis as Brack

Katie Dorian as Thea

Jeff Schwager as Lovborg

Our creative team includes:

Stage Manager Tessa Pekeles

Lighting and Set Design Vicky Williams

Costume Designer Rose Erin Durnan

Director Dorian Lang

The Play

In Hedda Gabler, Ibsen exposes the discreet lives of characters who must hazard their dignity to fulfill their deepest desires.  For Hedda, the most primal passions are coupled with an urgent need to concealed from scandal.  The risk of scandal is even greater with the play set in the future, and the advancement of mass communication strips away privacy.  Where is the place for unbridled passion in our civilized future?

The Impact

You can be the reason this project is a success!  As an independent theatre production, your donation will go a long way to making the show possible.

This month we need your help to raise $5000

This will help us:

  • pay for up front design costs
  • cover a deposit on our theatre venue
  • pay our outstanding artists

Our timeline

  • Dec 12 - Futuristic Fashion Show at Pacifico
  • Jan 6 - The end of this Indigogo campaign
  • Jan 19 - Rehearsals start
  • Feb 10-14 -The show is performed!

Other Ways You Can Help

We're aware that not everyone can donate at this time of year, but it would be a huge gift to us if you would share with others why you might like to donate.  

  • Please share our campaign on facebook with a note about why you'd like to support us.
  • Send us a message if you're interested in donating your time in other ways.  We'll be looking for volunteers to help with fundraisers, front of house, and loading our show into the venue.

Many thanks for reading about our campaign, and see you in the Ibsenverse!

 Head First Productions brings together Director Dorian Lang and Actor Margaret Legere to stage Ibsen's Hedda Gabler.

Our goals for the project
Head First Productions is committed to supporting Professional Artists while working on this demanding project.  Our hope is to gather funds through grants, sponsorship, and crowd funded support.  

We're pleased to announce the full cast for this production:
Mauralea Austin as Aunt Julie
Kim Parkhill as Berta
Andrew Chandler as Tesman
Margaret Legere as Hedda
Henricus Gielis as Brack
Katie Dorian as Thea
Jeff Schwager as Lovborg
Our creative team includes:
Stage Manager Tessa Pekeles
Lighting and Set Design Vicky Williams
Costume Designer Rose Erin Durnan
Director Dorian Lang


The Play
In Hedda Gabler, Ibsen exposes the discreet lives of characters who must hazard their dignity to fulfill their deepest desires.  For Hedda, the most primal passions are coupled with an urgent need to concealed from scandal.  The risk of scandal is even greater with the play set in the future, and the advancement of mass communication strips away privacy.  Where is the place for unbridled passion in our civilized future?
The Impact
You can be the reason this project is a success!  As an independent theatre production, your donation will go a long way to making the show possible.
This month we need your help to raise $5000
 This will help us:  pay for up front design costs cover a deposit on our theatre venue pay our outstanding artists   
Our timeline



Dec 12 - Futuristic Fashion Show at Pacifico

Jan 6 - The end of this Indigogo campaign
Jan 19 - Rehearsals start
Feb 10-14 -The show is performed!

        Other Ways You Can Help We're aware that not everyone can donate at this time of year, but it would be a huge gift to us if you would share with others why you might like to donate.    Please share our campaign on facebook with a note about why you'd like to support us. Send us a message if you're interested in donating your time in other ways.  We'll be looking for volunteers to help with fundraisers, front of house, and loading our show into the venue.   Many thanks for reading about our campaign, and see you in the Ibsenverse!

story:
THIS ROUGH MAGIC THEATRE COLLECTIVE

Summer's End Festival

We've dedicated this season to raising money to benefit those in need in the wake of Hurricane Harvey. All of our proceeds will be donated to the relief effort.

This summer, we're producing a fully realized production of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night and Horse Girls by Jenny Rachel Weiner, along with a few midnight readings of new plays by up-and-coming playwrights.

|| WHAT WE'RE DOING ||

Twelfth Night

September 23 and 24th at 7:00 pm at in room 125 at Cascade Complex at Southern Oregon University

  • This play focuses on the spirit of youth and the indomitable power of hope. We're very excited to share it with you!
  • Read more about the play here.
  • This production is directed by Martha Thatcher and Hannah Fawcett, assisted by Katie Herling and Jake Raiter. The set design is by Meg Chambers with lighting design by Logan Tiedt. Bucanan Howard is the stage manager. The cast includes Cameron Davis, Hannah Fawcett, Katie Herling, Torrin Kelly, Josh Nile, Jake Raiter Nolan Sanchez, Hunter Sims-Douglas, Martha Thatcher, Jonah Thorpe-Kramp, Sarah Tyson and Sarah Tyson.

Horse Girls

September 21 at 7:00

  • Jenny Rachel Weiner's dark comedy tells the story of Ashleigh and the Lady Jean Ladies, an exclusive South Florida horse club, as they face a crisis. Their stables are being sold and the horses will be sold for meat. This play focuses on adolescence with its insecurities, deceptions, and the overwhelming need to find one's place. 
  • This play is directed by Aurelia Grierson, assisted by Hannah Berg. Sound design is by Reilly Shrader-Dee with set and prop design by Hannah Berg. Madeline Hartrich is the stage manager. The cast includes Megan Jones, Delaney Barbour, Emily Hawks, Quinci Freeman-Lytle, Grace Kent, Chandler Parrott-Thomas, and Savanna Padilla.

New Works and Readings

  • We are presenting a series of late night readings by both new and classic playwrights.
  • Works include
    • Oliver and Emeline and The Clock Runs Down by Martha Thatcher.
    • A Midsummer Night's Dream by William Shakespeare.
    • A special grab-bag reading to be announced!

|| WHAT YOU CAN DO ||

We will donate 100% of our proceeds to organizations dedicated to help those in need in the wake of Hurricane Harvey, but we need your help to produce the show!

  • We're asking for $1000 to so we can buy a generator to power our productions and feed the during tech week. After that, the money will go to our costume, set, and technical budget. 
  • All extra funds will be donated along with our proceeds.

If you feel called to donate, any amount is appreciated. Anything helps!

|| PERKS ||

What's in it for you, you might ask? 

  • We're offering three different perk packages at $25, $50, and $100.
    • Some perks include but aren't limited to VIP seating at all our events, unlimited access to the snack cart, and a letter of thanks from the company.

 

CAN'T DONATE?

That's ok! We're so thankful to you for taking the time to read our campaign, watch our trailer, and we hope to see you at the show. 

  • If you cannot donate at this time, please consider sharing our campaign on your social media with your family and friends.

 

For more information, please contact us at thisroughmagictheatre@gmail.com.

 

Thank you so much!

-- Martha Thatcher and Hannah Fawcett

Producers of THIS ROUGH MAGIC Summer's End Theatre Festival

story:
When a childhood friend’s racist rant goes viral, Lee wrestles with the rage insider herself and in others. Trigger by Sam Chanse lives on the edge of rage and sanity. It teeters violently between the intellect and murderous mayhem. Trigger asks how can we connect with people in a time of heightened hatred? 

Starting with the 17/18 season, Leviathan Lab has re-dedicated ourselves to centering our work within a community that values risk, innovation, inclusion, and living on the edge of failure. We want to push the boundaries of the work we do as Asian American artists.

It takes a community of committed artists and generous supporters like you to give new voices of American theater a chance to be heard. Leviathan Lab prides ourselves to be a driving force in this process. Join us in producing Sam Chanse’s Trigger. Let’s move the needle forward.

The Artistic Team

Directed by Flordelino Lagundino
Set and Props by Deb O
Lights by Christina Watanabe
Sound by Matt Otto
Production Management by Lico Whitfield
Dramaturgy by Donatella Galella


About Sam Chanse

Sam Chanse’s plays and theater work include The Other Instinct, Fruiting Bodies, What you are now, Lydia’s Funeral Video, gilgamesh & the mosquito (with composer/collaborator Bob Kelly), about that whole dying thing, and Asian American Jesus (with director/collaborator Yasmine Gomez). She is a resident of New Dramatists, Rita Goldberg Playwrights’ Workshop Fellow at The Lark, and member of Ars Nova’s Play Group and Ma-Yi Writers Lab. A former Sundance/Ucross Playwright Fellow, MacDowell Fellow, and Playwrights Realm Writing Fellow, she has received residencies from Djerassi, Tofte Lake Center, SPACE at Ryder Farm, and the Lark. Her work has been recognized by The Kilroys (Fruiting Bodies: 2015 List and 2014 Honorable Mention; The Other Instinct: 2016 Honorable Mention). Commissions include Ensemble Studio Theatre/Sloan, Ma-Yi/the Flea, Second Generation, Leviathan Lab and the San Francisco Arts Commission. Her first solo play, Lydia’s Funeral Video, is published by Kaya Press. Sam is an alumna of the Lark’s New York Stage & Film Vassar Retreat, Meeting of the Minds, and Playground, and of the Civilians R&D Group; her work has also been developed with The Yale Institute for Music Theatre, The Claque, Labyrinth Theater, Ars Nova’s ANT Fest, Bindlestiff Studio, Asian American Theater Company, and the New York International Fringe Festival. MFA playwriting: Columbia University; MFA musical theater writing: NYU.


About Leviathan Lab

Founded in 2009, Leviathan Lab (LL) is an award-winning not-for-profit creative studio whose mission is the advancement of Asian and Asian American (A/AA) performing artists and their work. Through the speaking of A/AA artists’ words, and the presentation of A/AA bodies, presence, and gestures, LL works to open spaces that promote social justice, bridge communities, and assert the power of art to change the world. We function as a lab where artists can be courageous, experiment, and thrive, even as they create works that captivate the audiences we serve.

For more information visit www.leviathanlab.com. 

All donations tax deductible.

story:
Please help us fund our upcoming workshop in February 2018!

YouTube Channel
Facebook Page
 

Our Story

The Fourth Estate began in early 2012 as a direct response to an increasingly polarized political climate and the diminishing voice of the average citizen in government affairs. Troubled by the rise of partisan news outlets and the dangers of inaccurate coverage in our political process, author/composer John Fritz began working on an 11 song demo under the banner of “The Suburbia Project" from his studio in Washington DC.

This proof of concept laid the groundwork for what would ultimately become The Fourth Estate. By mixing traditional musical theatre storytelling with rock and roll irreverence, The Fourth Estate found its voice as a clarion call for journalistic integrity and the public's right to unbiased information. 

The Fourth Estate will be premiering its first public workshop at Stephens College in February 2018. Ranked #6 nationwide for Best College Theatre by The Princeton Review, this opportunity will allow the Fourth Estate to refine its message alongside some of the nation's premier talent.

While this is a strong step forward, it is by no means the end of the journey. Rather, this is where the real work begins. We invite you to join us as we take The Fourth Estate through this process, challenging our audiences just as we challenge ourselves.

If you support a free and honest press that values truth over ratings and integrity over profit, please help us hit our $7500 fundraising goal and contribute to our campaign by clicking the "Back It" button at the top of the page. This funding will be used for transcriptions of the score onto sheet music by one of Broadway's top arrangers, performance costs at our upcoming  workshop, and future expenditures as we build toward new opportunities for The Fourth Estate in 2018/2019. 

Thank you for your support and when you listen, listen loud.

Hear Us Rise.

Welcome to The Fourth Estate.

story:
The Play

" Let me tell you something , You don't get rainbows without rain!' -  2 years of eternal joy                

 After a young woman is diagnosed with cancer, she and her fiancé find their relationship tested by the hidden resentments the illness brings out in her family.   Joy and Jah are hit with the devastating news that Joy has ovarian cancer.  When breaking the news to family and friends everyone’s love, or lack thereof, is revealed and tested.  Joy’s mother, Shanice, wants to take care of her and hold off her marriage to Jah.  Joy’s father, George, wants Jah to convince Joy to slowed.  Out of resentment Rudy, Joy’s sister, tells Joy sister is completely unsupportive. When the couple decides that they want to go through unifying their life and love the family become distraught and unsupportive.  Yet through the trials and tribulations of sickness and family Joy and Jah’s love grows strong and becomes the healing everyone needs.                              

 

Ok, That Sounds Interesting !? Where can I see it ?

2 Years of Eternal Joy has been chosen to appear in Broadway Bound Theater festival. The festival is geared towards introducing up and coming Playwright to the New York stage.  Sherod D. Lee has been charged with task to present 3 the full runs on his production on stage. However, this is no easy feat.  We are asking you to "Join our Journey" to Broadway Bound Theater Festival ! 

How do I Join The Journey !?

So you are ready to take this crazy ride with us ? Welcome ! We are so excited to go through this experience with you by our side.  Here is what we need. It really takes a village to put on a play. Below is a break down of our budget of the things we need to a to acquire to bring "2 years of Eternal Joy" Life. 

Rehearsal Space :$432

Travel Expense: $300

Housing: $1,800

Emergency Money: $300

Props: $300

YOU CAN INVEST AS LOWER AS $5!  IT GOES A LONG WAY!

Other Ways to Join the Journey!

There are other way to Join the Journey!  You can head over to our social media accounts and MAKE SOME NOISE!!!!! Like, share, comment so we know you are with us. 

Follow us on Instagram: @eternaljoynyc and on Twitter: @eternaljoy_nyc

Like us at https://www.facebook.com/EternalJoyNYC/?fref=nf

We also would love to see your beautiful faces in our audience. 

The Broadway Bound Theater Festival will be held from August 18th to August 20th. "2 Years of Eternal Joy" will be performed on: 
Friday, August 18th at 12:30 p.m
Saturday, August 19th at 10:30 p.m
Sunday, August 20th at 6:30 p.m

You can purchase tickets at https://www.broadwayboundfestival.com/book-online

story:
I'm Esmé Boyce, choreographer, and director of Esmé Boyce Dance. My work has been performed at BAM Fishman Space, 92Y, Baryshnikov Arts Center, Center for Performance Research, Judson Church, and Dixon Place. I work closely with composer Cody Boyce to create interdisciplinary dance works set to original scores. In our collaborations, dance, music, sculptural form, and image are developed in tandem. For our newest work, "Interrobang," I am fortunate to work with a talented group of artists: 

Cody Boyce, composer and musician

Dancers: Cori Kresge, Pierre Guilbualt, Kit McDaniel and Matilda Sakamoto

Ken Kresge, actor/musician

Musicians: Talice Lee and Morgan Vo

Kit Boyce, set designer

Sue Julien, costume designer 

All donations will go directly to "Interrobang," fulfilling our goal to pay artists a fair wage and to ensure that art continues to thrive in these alarming times. 

We are aiming to raise $10,000 for the premiere of "Interrobang" and the re-staging of "Dark and Pretty Flat." All funds will go first and foremost to paying the dancers' and musicians' fees, as well as the core creative team and production costs such as materials and rehearsal space rental. It is essential to the caliber of the work that our dancers and musicians are paid a fair wage for their hard work and dedication. 

Perks for donating include a shout out on social media, an online download of original music, a custom "Interrobang" lapel pin, dinner with the creative team, a VIP seat to see the show, an original garment created by our costumer and your name in the program as a major supporter.

Esmé Boyce Dance has successfully premiered evening length works at Baryshnikov Arts Center in the Howard Gilman Space and at Dixon Place. It is a unique honor and opportunity to be presented by the 92nd Street Y as a part of their DIG DANCE Series. Please help us take full advantage of this wonderful opportunity!

We are grateful for any and all forms of support. Spreading the word about this fundraising campaign and/or coming to our shows are also greatly appreciated!

story:
SUBWAY CIRCUS by William Saroyan

Blarney Productions needs you!!

Blarney Production is an Edmonton based independent theatre company, inspired into inception by a dare, who made their inaugural premiere in 2006 with Brian Friel's Afterplay at the Edmonton Fringe Festival. It became a critical and box office hit and was awarded four Elizabeth Sterling Haynes nominations, winning two for its co-founders Wayne Paquette (Best Director) and John Sproule (Best Actor).  Ron Blair's The Christian Brothers followed the following year, once again greeted with both critical and commercial success, nominated for three Sterling awards and winning one (Best Director – Wayne Paquette). 

Blarney Productions has continued presenting new, challenging works including the Canadian premieres of J.T. Roger's Madagascar, Joan Didion's The Year of Magical Thinking, David Harrower's A Slow Air, Adam Peck's Bonnie & Clyde, and Philip Ridley's Dark Vanilla Jungle. In addition, Blarney has presented diverse works such as Conor MacPherson's The Good Thief, Lee Blessing's A Body of Water (Sterling award for Best Actress and Best Director), Catherine Hayes' Skirmishes, Arlene Hutton Last Train to Nibroc, and Craig Wright's Orange Flower Water (Sterling award for Best Supporting Actress).

In the 2012/13 season, Blarney Productions teamed up with two of Edmonton's leading independent companies, The Maggie Tree for Linda Griffith's The Age of Arousal and Promise Production's for Ellen Chorley's Murielle (Sterling award for Best Independent Production and Production for Young Audiences - World premiere). In the 2014/15 Blarney presented its first mainstage season, including the Canadian premiere of Donn Short's Full Frontal Diva, the world premiere of Jose Teodoro's MOTE, and Keith Huff's A Steady Rain. 

What makes Subway Circus so exciting and important to Blarney Productions is that it marks Braydon Dowler-Coltman's professional directing debut.  A part of Blarney Production's philosophy is to present originality, and with Subway Circus and Braydon Dowler-Coltman's vision, we feel that this project is the perfect environment for giving time and space for a new and emerging voice to learn his craft and grow as a director and become one the next generation's leading artists. 

YOUR CONTRIBUTION:

Independent theatre has the great challenge of finding the appropriate funds that are required to support the blood sweat and tears passion and talent that goes into these kinds of projects.  However, we at Blarney Productions believe that at a certain point in anyone’s career there comes a necessity to reimburse the artists for their sacrifices and contributions into making something so special for audiences. It’s the difference between a career and an expensive hobby.  We want the artists to remain artists.  It’s important to us, to our city, and to our culture.

This is the first time that Blarney Productions is reaching out to it's audience to contribute to the realization of our production, Subway Circus.

Your contribution to Subway Circus will guarantee that the artists will be paid for this unique project.  They are an inspiring and endlessly talented group of people from all areas of the arts:  actors Merran Carr-Wiggin, Patricia Cerra, Zoe Glassman, Andrew Gummer, Laura Raboud, Evan Terlesky, and introducing Samuel Udma.  It will be directed by Braydon Dowler-Coltman, with original music by Jesse Werkman & Kristian Stec, sound design by Bobby Smale, lighting design by Nico Van der Kley, projection Design by Jordan Dowler-Coltman, movement and choreography by Richelle Thoreson & Jake Hastey, with stage management by Lore Green.  It’s hugely ambitious but this project is genuinely being put together from the heart.

YOUR PERKS

We at Blarney Productions love presents!  And we would love to offer some very exciting perks for your generous contribution.

THEATRE and INTERNET ACKNOWLEDGMENT:

For a contribution of $9.95 (the price of an Edmonton All Day Transit Fare) - $19 dollars, you will receive a very special thank you on our thank you board at the PCL theatre, on the Blarney Productions website and facebook page.

SIGNED POSTER:

For a contribution of $20 - $49 dollars, you will receive a signed poster of Subway Circus, and you will receive a very special thank you on our thank you board at the PCL theatre, on the Blarney Productions website and facebook page.

ADOPT AN ARTIST:

For a contribution of $50 - $99 dollars, you can ADOPT one of artists.  In doing so, you will receive a very special thank you on our thank you board at the PCL theatre, on the Blarney Productions website and facebook page; a personal invite to meet your adopted actor after the show; and finally a personal letter thanking you and telling you how your contribution made a difference to our production.

DANCE and MOVEMENT LESSONS:

We have only 2 chances for this perk.

For a contribution of $200 dollars, Toy Guns will offer a 3-class dance pass.  Learn from the best in Edmonton; you will also receive a very special thank you on our thank you board at the PCL theatre, on the Blarney Productions website and facebook page.

JIU JITSU LESSONS – PRIVATE LESSONS

For a contribution of $300 dollars, Andrew Gummer is offering free private lesson in brazilian jiu jitsu.

JIU JITSU LESSONS – FREE MONTH OF TRAINING:

For a contribution of $400 dollars, Andrew Gummer is offering a free month of training in Brazilian jiu jitsu and Method BJJ.

And if you cannot make a donation to our Subway Circus indie gogo campaign, no worries!  We would ask that you pass along our information and get the word out there for the SUBWAY CIRCUS cause!

YOUR IMPACT

Your contribution will be extremely important in the realization of our production, Subway Circus, and especially to all the artists who have committed their time and talents to bringing a little magic to theatre.

We thank you .
story_txt:
SUBWAY CIRCUS by William Saroyan Blarney Productions needs you!!Blarney Production is an Edmonton based independent theatre company, inspired into inception by a dare, who made their inaugural premiere in 2006 with Brian Friel's Afterplay at the
Edmonton Fringe Festival. It became a critical and box office hit and was
awarded four Elizabeth Sterling Haynes nominations, winning two for its
co-founders Wayne Paquette (Best Director) and John Sproule (Best Actor).  Ron Blair's The Christian Brothers
followed the following year, once again greeted with both critical and
commercial success, nominated for three Sterling awards and winning one (Best
Director – Wayne Paquette).  Blarney Productions
has continued presenting new, challenging works including the Canadian
premieres of J.T. Roger's Madagascar, Joan Didion's The Year of
Magical Thinking, David Harrower's A Slow Air, Adam Peck's Bonnie
& Clyde, and Philip Ridley's Dark Vanilla Jungle. In addition,
Blarney has presented diverse works such as Conor MacPherson's The Good
Thief, Lee Blessing's A Body of Water (Sterling award for Best
Actress and Best Director), Catherine Hayes' Skirmishes, Arlene Hutton Last
Train to Nibroc, and Craig Wright's Orange Flower Water (Sterling
award for Best Supporting Actress). In the 2012/13
season, Blarney Productions teamed up with two of Edmonton's leading
independent companies, The Maggie Tree for Linda Griffith's The Age of
Arousal and Promise Production's for Ellen Chorley's Murielle (Sterling
award for Best Independent Production and Production for Young Audiences -
World premiere). In the 2014/15 Blarney presented its first mainstage season,
including the Canadian premiere of Donn Short's Full Frontal Diva, the
world premiere of Jose Teodoro's MOTE, and Keith Huff's A Steady Rain.  What makes Subway Circus
so exciting and important to Blarney Productions is that it marks Braydon Dowler-Coltman's professional directing
debut.  A part of Blarney Production's philosophy is to present originality, and with Subway Circus and Braydon Dowler-Coltman's vision, we feel that this project is the perfect environment for giving time and space for a new and emerging voice to learn his craft and grow as a director and become one the next generation's leading artists.  

YOUR CONTRIBUTION:Independent theatre has the great
challenge of finding the appropriate funds that are required to support the blood
sweat and tears passion and talent that goes into these kinds of projects.  However, we at Blarney Productions believe
that at a certain point in anyone’s career there comes a necessity to reimburse
the artists for their sacrifices and contributions into making something so
special for audiences. It’s the difference between a career and an expensive
hobby.  We want the artists to remain
artists.  It’s important to us, to our
city, and to our culture.
This is the first time that Blarney Productions is reaching out to it's audience to contribute to the realization of our production, Subway Circus.Your contribution to Subway Circus

story:
Sex and God

From renowned Scottish playwright Linda McLean, Sex and God sees an all-female cast weave four sharply emotional intergenerational monologues on faith, lust and family. It is a play that spans the twentieth century through the lives of four women of four generations. Their experiences of family, religion and ambition are shaped by the times they live in and who they live with. Jane, a kitchen maid, the first in her family to move to the big city for work; Lizzie, passionate but unskilled and permanently dodging poverty; Sally, an early school-leaver who tries to escape a dangerous relationship by working her way into a profession; and Fiona, first in her family to go to University and discover the world of bewildering choices. 



"Remarkable event on the London Fringe for female artistry" ★★★★

- London Pub Theatres

For a weekend of May we have the chance to perform this fantastic play at one of the most renowned venues of the Brighton Fringe, The Warren: Theatre Box. And we need your financial help to make this happen!

The Company

Cuts and Grazes theatre company creates ambitious contemporary work about social issues in the past, present and future. The company currently consists of theatre makers Anna Carfora, Eva O’Connor, Anne Bertreau, Ailis Duff, Lindsay Weldon and Tonje Wik Olaussen. Cuts and Grazes was established in 2014 after the original company graduated from the MA Theatre Ensemble programme at Rose Bruford College together. This will be the fourth time the company stage the  performance of Sex and God, but the first time outside of London.

"The international cast and crew of Cuts and Grazes successfully combine humorous exploration and harrowing physical interpretation to discuss female issues throughout the centuries." 

- Tess Van Leeuwen, All Guts No Glory

The Playwright

Linda McLean was born in Glasgow where she studied and trained as a teacher. She travelled teaching English as a foreign language in Europe, America, Africa and Scandinavia before she wrote plays. Other plays include THIS IS WATER (2010), ANY GIVEN DAY (2010), STRANGERS, BABIES (Susan Smith Blackburn prize finalist) and SHIMMER (Herald Angel).

"Their stories are ordinary, but as they resonate with each other, they say something bigger about the female experience of sexuality, motherhood and survival." 

- The Guardian, on Sex and God


The Brighton Fringe

The Brighton Fringe is the largest annual arts festival in England, and it takes place every year during the month of May. One of the event’s main objectives is to promote local talent and the arts. It also offers performers an opportunity for their event to be reviewed or picked up by promoters, as well as going on to the Edinburgh Fringe. In 2011 Brighton Fringe launched the Professional Development Programme, aimed at offering workshops to aspiring performers wanting to progress in the business. 

What we need your money for

Putting on a show at a festival has its expenses. We will be using the money for paying rights to the playwright, paying the venue for letting us perform our show there, we need to pay for a place to stay and for the train journey over to Brighton from London. On top of this we need money to pay for posters and flyers to be printed so people will hear about our show and hopefully come see it. 

A short breakdown of the budget:

- Rights to the playwright: £225

- Venue fees: £330

- Accommodation and travel: £395

- Marketing: £50

The Perks

We have tried to come up with some pretty excellent perks for you to claim when supporting our campaign. Simply choose one of them when donating and we'll make sure it gets to you before long. Hopefully you'll find something you fancy, but if you think they're all pretty dumb then you can of course donate without claiming any of them.

Why support us?

1. Art. Art is one of the last pure conduits through which we as people can reflect upon the human condition; it is a vital tool through which expression is given genuine freedom. We aim to produce plays which reach for people; that move them and hopefully leave them looking more closely at themselves and the world around them.

2. Women. Help support emerging female artists. We are proud of being an all female ensemble of theatre makers. We put on performances that often centers around women's issues of today, yesterday and tomorrow. Finding a great play such as Sex and God, with four strong female characters was a big challenge. So we hope that by going around performing this show more playwrights, artists, audiences and others will see that women's voices and stories should be heard. By supporting us you'll be supporting the development of our company, us as emerging artists, and the future of women in the arts. 


Other ways you can help

Even if you can't contribute financially that doesn't mean you can't help. Getting the word out and sharing this campaign amongst your social and professional networks would be such fabulous support.

And then there's the actual show – come along to Brighton!

Link to buy tickets: www.otherplacebrighton.co.uk/1761/sex-and-god

story:
Young Choreographers Project provides young dance students (ages 13 - 18 years old) with access to full self-expression through choreography and movement.  Students experience a new relationship with dance and learn how to express their thoughts, feelings and ideas through dance and movement.  

We just started our 2016 program and are offering this unique experience to 12 new students.  We need to raise money to cover the cost for one-on-one mentoring for each of our students, costumes, lighting, and our performance venue.

Our Mentors are what make this program so unique.  Each student gets the opportunity to be mentored by a professional choreographer and/or dancer who is currently pursuing dance and choreography as a career.  Students are provided with an opportunity to work one-on-one with their mentors and learn valuable skills that support them through the process of creating their very own dance pieces.  Without our mentors, this program would not be possible.  

Professional choreographers and dancers are the lowest paid in the entertainment industry.  YCPLA.org is committed to providing income to the mentors we work with.  That's why we need your support.  A majority of our budget goes towards stipends for our Mentors.  


  • Making a donation of $70 covers the cost of one mentoring session for one student.

Our final showcase is what makes this experience so special.  After working one-on-one with their mentors, our students will have created an original dance piece that they can share with their family and friends.  Having their pieces performed on stage with lights, music and costumes is an out-of-this-world experience for them.  It's an opportunity for them to marvel at what they were able to accomplish and to celebrate their success after working so hard for several weeks.  The final showcase is their finish line!


  • Making a donation of $30 covers the cost of costumes and lighting for one student's dance piece.

story:
About The Project

Hi everybody! My name's Anya Kopischke and I've been writing a play called Mrs. Babinski in the Kitchen that follows the story of an old Russian witch who has been asleep for 100 years and is rudely awakened by children trying to perform a science experiment on her body. Going backwards from spring to fall, the story follows her trying to remember where she fell asleep and the people and events that brought her there. The piece is an exploration of storytelling; it experiments with non-conventional uses of song and folklore, creating a fantastically strange world to tell a truly modern and universal story of lost friendship.

The opportunity has finally presented itself to produce this experimental piece at Bard College April 9th-11th. There is a fantastic team of students from of all artistic backgrounds dedicated to the exploration of this project! Actors, singers, musicians, and visual artists have joined together to stretch the boundaries of theatre and discover the many ways one can tell a story.

So This Is Important Because

Student theatre is incredibly important for these type of explorations. It's this incredible thing where students from a variety of majors and artistic mediums can come together to experiment with new things, things outside of their comfort zone, and collaborate with each other. And they volunteer on their own time FOR FREE!

Unfortunately, making theatre is EXPENSIVE, and student theatre rarely gets the funding it needs or deserves.

That's Where You Come In!

While we have this amazing opportunity to stretch the boundaries together, money is not easy to come by for these projects. And while everyone involved has dedicated their time, we need to provide them with high quality materials.

Mrs. Babinski in the Kitchen is a project that focuses heavily on the feeling of the different worlds it creates. It will therefore depend very heavily on an original aesthetic. Visual artists are working together to create set and costumes that are as much works of art as they are functional elements of a play. They need need money for lumber, fabric, costume pieces, and prop pieces to create a world that evokes a a very specific feeling.

'What's in it for me,' you ask?

These sorts of projects don't happen very often. Not for lack of motive or creativity in our generation, but for lack of funding. The types of shows that make money are the types of shows that are a sure-sell, because something very similar like it has been done before and made a profit. 

But every once in a blue moon, something comes out that challenges this archetype in theatre: someone pushes the boundaries and forces the rest of the theatre world to grow and evolve. So many of these productions are itching to happen, but because they are pushing the boundaries they are very hard to fund. But these productions NEED TO HAPPEN in order for our society to grow culturally and intellectually. Therefore, these productions depend on donations from people who care, THAT'S YOU!!

Any amount you can donate makes a difference and is deeply appreciated, but as an added bonus, you can claim one of the awesome, personalized gifts listed on the right when you donate a designated amount. Even if you can't donate anything, spread the word, share on facebook, theatre thrives on word of mouth!

This is sure to be an exciting, cathartic, terrifying experience! Any support you can offer is appreciated by everyone involved!

-Anya Kopischke

story:
Who Is The Gallery Players

The Gallery Players, now in it's 48th Season, is a not-for-profit independent theater which produces compelling and innovative theater in the heart of Brooklyn. 

Gallery strives to be a place where artists can come to collaborate, create, and develop their craft in a supportive and professional environment. 

What We Need and Where The Funds are Going

Theater is expensive to produce, and ticket sales are not enough to put on a single production, let alone keep a theater running. We are trying to raise funds to support this dynamic production for two main purposes:

CREATIVE DESIGN PRODUCTION COSTS

Artists have grand and brilliant visions, but it requires more than just creative brilliance to bring a design to life. It requires the funding to bring that vision to life. We are trying to raise additional funds to help us let our designers create the world they want to create.

  • In total, we hope to raise an additional $8500 to put towards design production costs
WAGES FOR OUR ARTISTS AND ACTORS
We believe being an artist is a career choice, and artists should expect to be paid a respectful wage like any other career. We are trying to raise additional funds to help us pay our artists and actors appropriately for the hard and noble work that they do:
  • In total we hope to raise an additional $7500 to help pay our designers, actors, director, stage managers, and musicians

PERKS

While we hope there's a simple joy in knowing that you're helping to support the arts, we're upping the ante and offering some exhilerating perks, including Gallery Players swag, signed swag from the cast and creatives, an invitation to our final dress, a VIP pass to the opening night party, and all the Karma points we can give. 

Not to mention that each donation is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

Other Ways You Can Help

While we welcome the financial support, there are also other ways you can help us bring this production to life.

Gallery players is always in need of volunteers to help in every facet of the production: from building the sets, to ushering the shows and more.    

Want to volunteer? Shoot us an email:

volunteer@galleryplayers.com

story:
"Peter Pan" performances will take place on August 19th 7pm and August 20th 2:30pm and 7pm at The Attic Community Theater in Santa Ana CA


Actor’s Instrument

  I am Kirsten Bierly the founder of Actor’s Instrument a theater education company for young and old alike. Ever since I was young it has been a dream of mine to build my very own theater from the ground up; and with your help I can now do that with our very first production of the original J.M. Barrie play “Peter Pan.”

  Ever since I performed in my very first musical “Peter Pan” as the lost boy Curly when I was 9 years old I have yearned to be a part of the original play as the hero himself, Peter! I had fallen in love with the stage and the story of Peter Pan; and with your contributions you can help make my dreams come true.

How You Can Help

 This production, being our first, is entirely volunteer based. That being said we need your help to get this show off the ground. With your contributions we can pay for:

·  Theater Rental

·  Rehearsal Space

·  Costumes

·  Sets and Props

·  Scripts

·  Royalty

·  Advertisement

·  Posters

·  And more!

  But we don’t expect you to contribute for nothing! We have a number of exciting perks for you should you choose to donate. We understand that not everyone can contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help! There are a number of ways to spread the word about our campaign with Indiegogo’s share tools you can share our story with your friends and family.

The Impact

 With the success of this production Actor’s Instrument will be able to form a community of actors together eager to learn and help build a better curriculum for Theater Education. When the production is finished work will start on gathering students for our acting classes and costume design classes starting in the Fall. Our goal is to bring the arts back into our children’s schools and lives. Students don’t just benefit as an actor they learn valuable life skills; they will form stronger relationships, have better communication skills, and so much more.

Peter Pan

  “So come with us where dreams are born and time is never planned” to a place called Never, Neverland. Fly away with Peter Pan, Wendy, Michael and John as they discover the magical island of Neverland and its many perils.

  Peter Pan was originally written by J.M. Barrie in a section of The Little White Bird in 1902, he later returned to the character in his famous play premiering in 1904. He then expanded upon the play’s story in his 1911 novel Peter and Wendy.

  J.M. Barrie created the character of Peter Pan based on his brother, David, who died in an ice skating accident, leaving him thought of as forever a boy. Peter Pan was originally created to entertain George and Jack Llewelyn Davies, the boys that greatly influenced J.M. Barrie’s writing of the character.

story:
QUICK & FUNNY MUSICALS has been performing short, original musicals at Upright Citizens Brigade Theater LA for the past 5 years and this year we are going to NYC!  We are an official selection of the 2016 New York Musical Festival.  I mean, it doesn't get any more legit than musicals in New York.  Up next Broadway, but for now we gotta get our little show to the Big Apple.  Turns out, New York is expensive so we need help meeting the festival fees and travel and all that jazz, literally.  Help us bring comedy to NYMF and we'll bring the musical comedy to you.

Where the money is going to:

Physical Production (instrument rentals, microphones, tech equipment, transportation, costumes), NYMF Fees (Production Manager, House Manager, Venue Rental, Festival Marketing, Publicity, Admin Support), Creative (Musical Director, Musicians, Director, Lighting Director, Board Operator Choreographer, Actors) Travel (12 people from LA to NYC) and more.  

We will be offering some perks as a way to express our gratitude.  More details as the campaign continues but we can tell you they involve “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend”, musical songs, dance and laughter and messages or massages.

If we don’t meet our full goal, we will donate our creative time and focus on paying the festival fees and travel.  Every dollar helps!  we have been doing free/live musical comedy for years and are ready to take our show to the next level, which of course comes with a price.  

Please go to our website to check out our awesome company:
http://www.quickandfunnymusicals.com/

And check out our NYMF page here:
http://www.nymf.org/festival/2016-events/quickfunnymusicals/

If you can't donate at the moment please help us spread the word and share our story with the IndieGoGo share tools.

Thanks SO MUCH!  We love you all.  High fives and kicks,

QF

story:
Bref résumé

La compagnie Théâtre Kata est fière de vous présenter ses nouveaux projets pour la saison théâtrale 2016-2017 ! Elle aura la chance de se produire dans la Capitale et dans la métropole mais aura besoin de vous pour subvenir à quelques imprévus ;)

Doggy dans Gravel // 13 septembre au 1er octobre // Théâtre Premier Acte

«J’me saoule aux Long Island dans l’tout inclu d’ton cul. / J’ai peur d’être un vieux frustré condamné à BudLime pis à la pornographie infantile pour célébrer son TGIF. / Est-ce que c’est toi qui est responsable de ton propre viol parce que tu portais pas d’bobette en t’sour de ta robe cigarette? »

Cinq scouts.

Un après-bal. 

Pour vous procurer des billets:
http://www.premieracte.ca/programmation/2016-2007/

Le Sang de Michi (précédé de Négresse) // 11 au 29 octobre // Salle intime du théâtre Prospero

Marie et Karl, jeune couple en déclin, partagent leur quotidien entre misère sentimentale, pauvreté matérielle et étroitesse d’esprit. Leur mode de communication se résume à des clichés et de vieux proverbes éculés. Puis Karl apprend la soudaine grossesse de Marie. Dans Négresse, une femme invite son jeune amant à manger et à passer la nuit chez elle. Elle est séparée, mais non divorcée de son mari qui boit et a perdu son travail. —— « Négresse…pièce formidable, sexiste, brutale, magnifique que j’ai écrite à mes débuts… Et ce qui me plaît tellement chez Kroetz, c’est qu’il n’explique rien, il ne donne pas de leçons, il ne juge pas, il décrit, simplement. Comme je connais bien ce jeune Kroetz, je sais : il écrit sur un milieu qu’il connaît ! C’est authentique, plastique, merveilleusement terrible. Exactement ma pièce…» F.X . Kroetz, tiré d’un entretien.

Pour vous procurer des billets:

http://www.theatreprospero.com/spectacle/sang-d...
 

Ce dont nous avons besoin

Transport des décors, salaire des différents concepteurs, gels, attaché de presse, assurances, des melons d'eau, des popsicles, des poulets crus, des ragoûts de boulettes, des plats congelés, un micro-onde, trois murs, des stores & un lieu pour s'héberger du 11 au 29 octobre :P
 

L'impact

La compagnie Théâtre Kata a connue un grand succès avec son spectacle Le Monstre lors de son passage au Festival St-Ambroise Fringe 2014. En effet la compagnie a remportée le prix de la meilleure production francophone et son auteur (et metteur en scène) Olivier Arteau s'est vu décerner le prix de l'auteur le plus prometteur. 

En 2015, Doggy dans Gravel  a fait partie des spectacles les plus attendus pour le 25e anniversaire du Festival St-Ambroise Fringe de Montréal, selon Amy Blackmore, directrice générale et artistique, a rapporté le Devoir et le Journal de Montréal. Il sera présenté de nouveau cette année dans une version 2.0  au sein de la saison officielle 2016-2017 du Théâtre Premier Acte.

De plus, en ayant contribué à la dernière campagne de financement Indiegogo, vous avez participé au rayonnement du théâtre francophone à l'extérieur du Québec en nous permettant, à l'été 2015, de nous rendre au Nouveau-Brunswick avec la production de danse-théâtre Natashâ. Tout cela grâce à vous et à votre générosité!

En contribuant au financement, vous permettez à une jeune compagnie de théâtre de faire vivre et revivre des créations de la relève. Vous encouragez également la jeune carrière de plusieurs comédiens en début de parcours.

La collaboration est au centre des préoccupations de notre compagnie. On provoque la rencontre entre des artistes de la métropole et de la capitale issus de diverses disciplines artistiques. En espérant vous rencontrer, vous aussi. Parce qu'en cliquant, vous faite automatiquement partie de la famille. Merci. On vous aime.

story:
Short Summary

THE WRTE VISION to sustain theater as a viable art form includes the offering of programs that not only inspire and educate, but also challenge us as a theater company to move in tandem with the rest of the world. We ask questions, we reach beyond what we know, and we are committed to theater as a vehicle for change. To that end we hope to discover new layers in Shakespeare's work through a feminine voice.  In a continuing effort to ignite the creative flame in young people, we will engage local high school students through matinee performances that include pre-show study guides and post-show discussions.

IN SPRING 2017 we will expand our reach to under-served populations through an initiative designed to engage participants in the process of storytelling for the stage.

It's a very exciting time and your support will allow us to produce this wildly complex and fascinating work by Shakespeare which will set the stage for a yet another season of excellence!

What We Need & What You Get

LEND YOUR SUPPORT! It was a dark and not so stormy night in the desert town of Tucson when four courageous Ensemble Members forged a union and ventured into the realm of theater management. There is strength in numbers and our FOUR has become FIVE determined individuals who will take the next fork in the road together.

A NEW ENERGY! With a motivated BOARD of DIRECTORS, a Brilliant adaptation of the Bard's work, an equally brilliant DIRECTOR, a Talented all FEMALE CAST and a DREAM CREW, each is committed to the success of this theater and have contributed support either through monetary or in-kind means.

WHAT WE NEED FROM YOU:

Financial support for the cost of production, which includes:

  • Production materials
  • Artist's stipends
  • Designer fees
  • Venue rental
  • Administrative/marketing expenses. 

WHAT YOU GET FROM US:

  • Free WRTE Cookies
  • Acknowledgement in WRTE Season Production Programs
  • Sneak Preview Event Invites
  • Free Tickets or Season Subscription
  • TShirts, Coffee Mugs, Stress Balls. Oh and. Did we say Cookies?

The Impact

Your support will provide the funds needed to support production #1 of the WRTE 2016-17 Season. With performances October 20-November 5, our first production of the season sets the tone for the rest of the season and we are wildly excited about Julius Caesar and the timeliness of its premiere. 

We have scheduled an offering of theatrical productions that we feel will not only touch the audience members we know, but also resonate with an audience we have yet to meet at our east-side venue. 

  • In March 2017 WRTE will present The Language Archive by Julia Cho, a fascinating story about a man in love with language who fails to find the words to express his love for a departing wife.
  • In May 2017, we will present an adaptation of Ron Carlson's News of the World, stories ripe for tabloid headlines that take us in unexpected directions. This final production of the season will launch a New Works Festival that will engage under-served populations in the creative process of writing for the stage. 

We continually seek funding from local, regional and national granting agencies and foundations and have been consistently funded by the Tucson Pima Arts-Council, the Arizona Commission on the Arts, and the Dramatists Guild. We are persistant in our search for more diverse funding streams and trust that with expanded programming, we will continue to open doors. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are a number of ways you can support our cause outside of a monetary contribution. 

  • Spread the word! Ask your friends to check us out on Facebook, visit our website, or the Indiegogo site. 
  • Volunteer for a production. We welcome individuals with an interest in theater to join us.
  • Come see a show.
  • Support Theater Everywhere!

story:
If we reach our target, we will use the money to pay all our creatives and two Auslan interpreters to enable the participation of one or two deaf performers. It’s important to fund disability arts because just under 20% of people in Australia identify as disabled and yet we are not adequately represented in the media and the arts.

This is the first project by The Waiting Room Arts Company. We are a for profit group which commissions artistic work in the disciplines of music, visual arts, theatre and dance. It consists of Jess Kapuscinski-Evans as its artistic director and has a board comprising one artist in each discipline. We are a disability led company which means all work is by or driven by a disabled artist, and/or treats disability as its main subject. As we are a for profit company, we aim to sell merchandise as well as various forms of art for the public to take home and treasure. In the future we hope to tour works to schools however we are not a children’s art group specifically.

What’s in the name? We people with disabilities spend our lives in waiting rooms, the doctors, Centrelink, metaphorically. In waiting rooms there is crass pop culture (magazines, TV, music) and high art in the form of photography and paintings hung on the walls. There are lots of diverse people in waiting rooms. Whilst our main focus is on providing opportunities for emerging artists with disabilities (aged 18 years and older, with no more than five years experience making independent art), we also seek to work with people of colour, people from migrant backgrounds, people who identify as indigenous, women and/or LGBTIQA+. We are also open to works in different languages and from different cultures.  We will wait no longer. We will take back and take up space, seeking out performance venues and exhibition areas which are independent and innovative, or finding new ways to use old spaces. We will of course look after the environment as we do so.

story:
Hi!

We are Quixotic Productions, a brand new amateur theatre company for young adults based in Cardiff, Wales! And we need your help in getting our very first production off the ground: The award-winning classic musical 'Man of La Mancha', to be staged at Cardiff's 'The Gate' arts centre in the Spring of 2017 (exact dates TBD).

This project is aimed at getting young people in Cardiff (ages 18-25) involved in a highly rewarding theatrical experience.


What We Need & Where Your Money Goes

It goes without saying that independent theatre gets nowhere without the generosity of financial backers. Staging a theatrical show, and musicals in particular, incurs significant overheads which cannot be avoided.

The largest of these overheads by far is the cost of hiring the venue and acquiring the rights to put on the show. That's where you come in, as the £1500 goal of our Indiegogo campaign will go towards meeting these initial upfront expenses.

We will be seeking to fund the remainder of the production through other means, however, should the Indiegogo campaign succeed its goal, you can rest assured that any additional will also be put to good use by being invested in the show!

Check out our perks to see which size donation is right for you. Again, we are incredibly thankful for every act of generosity, no matter the size!


Experience

Director Chris has had years of experience in staging musicals, having previously worked on the production team for the Welsh premiere of 'A Theory of Justice', originally written in 2013, and as a crew member for one of the first officially licenced amateur productions of 'The Phantom of The Opera' in 2012. He also holds a degree in music from Cardiff University.

Our Musical Director Owen has also worked on a number of musicals before, including Dracula Spectacular, Grease, High School Musical, Oliver, and Annie, as well as taking rehearsals with the Pendyrus male voice choir.

Production Manager Henri is also a seasoned amateur dramatic, and is currently the treasurer for Cardiff University's theatre society, Act One.


Risks & Challenges

Producing a theatrical show is tricky business, and is not without its challenges. Having covered the initial venue hire and licencing fees with your donations here, the next step is creating the show itself. This will require meticulous planning of every aspect, from devising a marketing strategy, to building and designing the set. However, with firm financial backing and advance planning, this will provide us with the best footing from which to launch our project.


Other Ways You Can Help

We would be incredibly thankful if you would do all you can to help spread the word about this campaign and to generate further interest. You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help with this.

Once again, if you are passionate about independent theatre, then help us get this project off the ground with your generosity, so we can begin to make this impossible dream of ours a reality!

Thank you,

Quixotic Productions
story_txt:
Hi!
We are Quixotic Productions, a brand new amateur theatre company for young adults based in Cardiff, Wales! And we need your help in getting our very first production off the ground: The award-winning classic musical 'Man of La Mancha', to be staged at Cardiff's 'The Gate' arts centre in the Spring of 2017 (exact dates TBD).
  This project is aimed at getting young people in Cardiff (ages 18-25) involved in a highly rewarding theatrical experience.
   What We Need & Where Your Money Goes It goes without saying that independent theatre gets nowhere without the generosity of financial backers. Staging a theatrical show, and musicals in particular, incurs significant overheads which cannot be avoided.
The largest of these overheads by far is the cost of hiring the venue and acquiring the rights to put on the show. That's where you come in, as the £1500 goal of our Indiegogo campaign will go towards meeting these initial upfront expenses.
We will be seeking to fund the remainder of the production through other means, however, should the Indiegogo campaign succeed its goal, you can rest assured that any additional will also be put to good use by being invested in the show!
Check out our perks to see which size donation is right for you. Again, we are incredibly thankful for every act of generosity, no matter the size!
   Experience Director Chris has had years of experience in staging musicals, having previously worked on the production team for the Welsh premiere of 'A Theory of Justice', originally written in 2013, and as a crew member for one of the first officially licenced amateur productions of 'The Phantom of The Opera' in 2012. He also holds a degree in music from Cardiff University.
Our Musical Director Owen has also worked on a number of musicals before, including Dracula Spectacular, Grease, High School
Musical, Oliver, and Annie, as well as taking rehearsals with the Pendyrus male voice choir.
Production Manager Henri is also a seasoned amateur dramatic, and is currently the treasurer for Cardiff University's theatre society, Act One.
   Risks & Challenges Producing a theatrical show is tricky business, and is not without its challenges. Having covered the initial venue hire and licencing fees with your donations here, the next step is creating the show itself. This will require meticulous planning of every aspect, from devising a marketing strategy, to building and designing the set. However, with firm financial backing and advance planning, this will provide us with the best footing from which to launch our project.

    Other Ways You Can Help We would be incredibly thankful if you would do all you can to help spread the word about this campaign and to generate further interest. You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help with this.
Once again, if you are passionate about independent theatre, then help us get this project off the ground with your generosity, so we can begin to make this impossible dream of ours a reality!
Thank you,
Quixotic Productions

story:
Short Summary

Thunderclap Productions is a a 501(c)3 nonprofit theatre company dedicated to presenting the best new and little-known plays and musicals. This April, we will be bringing Aizzah Fatima in from NYC to perform her accalaimed one-woman show DIRTY PAKI LINGERIE for two weekends.  But we can't do this without your support!

What We Need & What You Get

Mounting a full-scale play and bringing in a guest performer from NYC is an expensive endeavor.  We estimate our costs to be around $6,000 and we would like to raise at least $2,000 of it from this campaign.  Here's a breakdown of where these costs go: 

All donations are tax deductible.  We also have a  number of thank you gifts available including tickets to the performances and signed show posters (please note that by federal law, if you accept a gift, we must deduct the value of the gift from the tax deductible portion of your donation).

Risks & Challenges

When you put on new theatre — even highly acclaimed new theatre — it can be hard to get the word out.  Shows like this don't have name recognition yet, so ticket sales are always uncertain.  This is a unique and extraordinary new theatrical work, but cannot make it to Houston without your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

All donations to this campaign of any dollar amount will help, but if you're not in a position to donate, please share this campaign on your facebook page and twitter feed, as well as by email with anyone you know who might be interested.  (You can use indiegogo's built-in sharing tools to make it easy.)  We also hope to see you at one of our pay-what-you-can performances!
