story:
SHOW TIMES

Preview: April 9th

Opening: April 10th

Show days: April 11th, 12th, 16th, 17th, 18th, 24th, 25th, 26th

Show times are always at 8pm

If you bought a perk, message us to reserve your ticket!

What is Prism?

Prism is a movement theatre piece that reveals the creation of civilization in three stages: darkness, light, and color. This incredible production will premiere in the Trinity Groves warehouses during Dallas Arts Week alongside an actual art gallery curated by John Marcucci. 

Prism holds a special place in our hearts, not just because it was our first performance as an ensemble together, but simply because of how much fun it is to experience. It's a joy to see the amazed faces of the audience as we suddenly create civilizations, monsters, gods and goddesses using simple, every day objects.

With just a few flashlights, our players thrust you into the world of darkness, a place where creatures and people are created and destroyed in an instant as they struggle for light and power. Then, using mirrors and weight-sharing to delve into a world of light, a man and a woman explore the obstacles they face as they go on to create civilization. Finally, our ensemble uses paint to explore the world of color as a diverse community creates an entirely fictional language, but just as quickly the differences in this language bring about conflict and eventually, all-consuming warfare.  

The epic themes, combined with the simple, minimalist execution, provide a vulnerability and magical sense of wonder that lives and breathes in every moment. Ultimately, Prism is an invitation to play, a chance for our audience members to dream of the times when they played sweetly and fiercely and birthed the light of their own stories from the darkness of nothing. 

What We Need 

This is a huge project, and with that fact in mind, we've got some good and bad news.

Bad news first: while your funding will be a great help, ensuring that we can cover what we need, it by no means will cover it all. 

Here's the good news: If we raise this money, Southern Methodist University’s Meadows program has offered to not only match, but exceed the amount raised, bringing us to a total of $5000. 

Not only is this truly an incredible gift, but it also means that you have a chance to fund not only Prism, but our upcoming season as well. 

Your funds, along with SMU’s contribution will go toward:

Sound: Speakers, tape, and extension cords so that the room can be filled with Fabricio’s and Seun Soyemi's original music.

Lighting: Lighting equipment, rigging, work lights and LEDs that will not only be used prominently in Prism, but will also be used as an investment to make future shows possible.

Costumes: We will need to get costumes that are easily washable while still allowing us to be fully mobile.

Set: Special effects, canvases to fight on, rigging

Props/Theming: Paint, mirrors, paintbrushes, flashlights, bowls, eye protectors, water balloons, etc.

Funding our next season: We've got a lot of shows and dreams we want to see come to life, and your funding will be the first step in making those dreams a reality.

What You'll Get 

Instead of thinking of this as just a fundraising campaign, we'd like our funders to think of this as a VIP preordering system. While at the actual event, tickets will be $15-$25 each, we will be giving all of our funders the opportunity to pre-order their tickets to this beautiful show, which ends in an honest to goodness paint war for just $10 each. 

PrismCo has a history of having sold out weekends, so funding us now is one way to guarantee that you have a seat.

And for those of us who have been to a PrismCo show before, good seats run out pretty fast, so why not guarantee that you’ll have the seat of your choice? At $20, we will reserve a seat wherever you want it, and at $40 we’ll reserve those seats for you and a guest.

The money we are requesting is the minimum amount we will need in order to make this incredible event happen.  But if we meet our goal and raise more, we will be able to offer other awesome perks at discounted prices like your very own PrismCo t-shirt, and Prism Canvases for lower prices than you would get at the actual event!

The Impact

We have nothing but the highest expectations for PrismCo’s effect on the Dallas arts scene. Not only are we offering a type of theatre that is very rarely seen in the Dallas arts community, we hope our productions will offer opportunities to a wide variety of artists from different disciplines to showcase their work. For a lot of our visual, musical and performing artists, these shows can serve as their chance to premiere in the Dallas arts world, or hone their skills and try something completely new. We want to make sure these artists’ amazing talents are seen by Dallas artistic professionals and that they are fairly compensated for their incredible talents.

Also, because of the nature of PrismCo’s wordless, movement based theatre, our productions are an excellent medium for educational theatre, as we are able to present a variety of myths and other artistic experiences to a younger audience in a way that is engaging, and easily digestible for students of all ages.

 Finally, we hope that PrismCo will ultimately help kick start West Dallas’ artistic growth as the area transitions into a new noncommercial arts district. With funding, we will not only be able to make our company become a reality, but we will be helping to diversify the Dallas community of artists as a whole.

Overcoming risks and challenges

As a team, PrismCo has had a very consistent and successful track record of delivering exceptional and engaging artistic projects that consistently result in sold out weekends.

Below is a list of shows we have produced in the past, along with a few links to our reviews where applicable.

Galatea: an innovative, wordless movement show that uses paper, aerial silks, and weight-sharing to explore the story of an artist who attempts to create a perfect girl as his one true love. In the process, he creates an entire world; populated with vibrant characters who help to teach the girl what it is to be human.

Galatea was named one of Dallas’ top 10 plays and one of Mark Lowry’s top 5 favorite new works of 2014 (Theater Jones). Galatea was also recognized by the Dallas-Fort Worth Theatre Critics Forum Awards for its outstanding movement work.

· http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/columnists/nancy-churnin/20140412-galatea-mime-show-a-thoughtful-dreamy-must-see.ece

· http://www.theaterjones.com/ntx/reviews/20140413110948/2014-04-15/Prism-Co/Galatea

· http://thecolumnawards.org/columnonline/review/04-14-2014_GALATEA/

· http://www.theaterjones.com/ntx/2014inreview/20141231072949/2014-12-31/The-Year-in-New-Plays

· http://www.theaterjones.com/ntx/2014inreview/20...

Teotl: Aztec deities – Tezcatlipoca and Quetzalcoatl – have been submerged in the sands of Mexico for over a thousand years until archeologists stumble upon their remains. Awakened from ancient slumbers, the two gods resume their eternal rivalry with a furious battle involving Tezcatlipoca’s minions and an unwitting archeologist.

· http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/columni...

· http://www.theaterjones.com/ntx/reviews/2014102...

· http://dallas.culturemap.com/news/arts/12-28-14...

Baba Yaga: a wordless movement show that uses elastics to follow the story of a mother witch and her three magical children trying to find a fourth member to complete their family. 

Additionally, we are excited to tackle the challenge of redesigning our set, story and special effects as well as creating the immersive experience for the audience. The greatest challenge may be getting people to come see our amazing work, but through a stellar marketing plan, we are developing in collaboration with the Striped Heart, we are working to ensure that everyone in DFW Metroplex will be excited to see Prism.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, My name is Alex J Frantz, Artistic Director and Founder of Antix Theatrix. Antix is an arts organization dedicated to creativity, collaboration, and community. We also practice Fair Trade Artists, the concept that artists deserve to be fairly compensated for their time and talents. Antix Theatrix is looking to produce it's first production this upcoming summer, of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" by William Shakespeare. The theme of the production is Pride- celebrating the diverse LGBTQ culture within and beyond the Fox Cities. As a non-binary individual, I have a unique perspective to offer through my direction of this production.

What We Need & What You Get

Producing Theater is expensive. Our total production budget is $23,000- over $10,000 of which goes towards paying our collaborators $8/Hour for their time and talents. Essential to any theatrical production is a venue and insurance. We're looking to raise $3500 to secure our Venue and purchase insurance so that we can begin the production process. Your contribution will make this unique production a reality.

The Impact

Appleton has a unique and thriving LGBTQ Community, yet we lack any sort of Pride celebration. Similarly, we have a thriving theatrical community, yet most community theaters offer minimal compensation to their players. Through producing this Shakespearean classic, we aim to offer a theatrical experience that embraces and celebrates the LGBTQ community and offering local artists a fair wage for their time, talents, and experiences. Additionally, we seek to partner with local colleges to provide design internships for their students.

As a graduate of Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), I have experience producing and directing projects big and small. While at CMU, I put together a production as a showcase fundraiser and we sold-out three shows! Following graduation, I spent time as an executive assistant to an NYC Theater producer and managed a $10,000 theater music demo.

Risks & Challenges

Producing Theater is a risky endeavor. The main obstacle is low ticket sales. We aim to overcome this barrier by promoting the event to educators, thespians and the LGBTQ community. Additionally, we will create a live stream of the performance (on a pay-per-view model) so that family, friends and fans from around the world are able to attend.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to fiscal contributions, we need volunteers to assist with the actual event. If interested, email Alex at antixtheatrix@gmail.com

story:
We are group of women committed to providing more opportunities for women in theatre in the Baton Rouge, Louisiana area. Once we committed ourselves to making the Red Magnolia Theatre Company a reality, we needed to find a script about women and their stories. After stacks of texts, we finally found THE ONE: Love, Loss, and What I Wore by Nora and Delia Ephron. We collectively knew this extraordinary play had to be our theatre company's debut when we first read it together. The production will run October 12-14, 2018 during Baton Rouge's Women's Week.

 

Love, Loss, and What I Wore opens October 12, 2018 during Baton Rouge Women's Week, and we need your help to get the show ready. We would like our inaugural production to set the tone for our new theatre company. Our goal is to raise $7,000 to cover the costs of the production, venue rental, and publicity.

The idea for Red Magnolia stemmed from a desire to bring strong female characters to the stage in performances that entertain, inspire, and enlighten audiences. --Founder, Michele Johnson

It is not only important for us to provide interesting stage roles for women, but we also want to give women opportunities to develop their craft in all the elements of theatre. From directing, to design, to management, Red Magnolia Theatre Company seeks to be a truly collaborative women's theatre in the Baton Rouge area. 

In-Kind Donations:

  • Space for rehearsals (approx. 1,000 sqft)
  • Space for our events
  • Free or discounted printing for our programs, posters, postcards, event invitations, etc.
  • Scenic material for building sets, as needed per production (lumber, hardware, paint, etc.)
  • Food and/or Alcohol for events

Personal Support:

  • Help up find sponsors who align with our mission
  • Share our campaign on social media
  • Talk about us and our mission with your friends and family. You never know where a seed may plant!

story:
Thicc Strip is a Body Positive Movement

Women who do not fit societally constructed standards of beauty are told on a daily basis that they are not worthy, because they do not fit one very specific mold pushed by mainstream media. Frankly, we are sick of it. Thicc Strip is a night dedicated to calling this ridiculous notion out for the total BS that it is. All women can and should feel good about themselves, and all women are deserving of self-love and confidence. We are putting an end to "fat" being a bad word. 

 

How do we want to do this? With a real, live strip show! We are women who do not fit a specific mold and yet, we know we look good. We want to show other women like us that self-love goes further than outside hate. Thicc Strip is a show that embraces body diversity in the most explicit way possible. We want to prove that beauty is diverse, being sexual is not a sin, and we are all capable of looking and feeling great.

Who Is Organizing This?


My name is Alison Stevenson and I’m a comedian, writer, and unabashed fat Instagram slut (@JustAboutGlad) who has written extensively about body image, most notably for Vice. I also co-host a sex positive dating podcast called V Single. My writing and comedy is unapologetically feminist. You can learn more about me on my website: alisonstevenson.com.

 

My name is Kayli (@kaylisage on Instagram), and I was born and raised in Southern California. My whole life I have weighed more than “normal” but have learned to embrace it, especially in the last few years. Marijuana has been a huge part of my adult life and I advocate it whenever possible. Going to concerts and art shows is my favorite hobby. Let’s be friends.

 

Hey! It's Linda, and when I'm not slangin' drinks at concerts and festivals, I'm finding ways to fight the patriarchy. From getting my toes wet in the plus size modeling scene, to contributing to a feminist blog, to waking up before the sun for clinic escorting. I love finding new and exciting ways to be unapologetically me.

 

Elizabeth here. I am an event organizer and often mostly-naked body positive babe. I spend my down time volunteering as a Crisis Care Counselor and assisting local civic groups in bridging the gap between communities around the world. I advocate for female equality, LGTBQIA rights, and an end to fat shaming. Find me on Instagram: @localsupercluster

 

What We Need 

This started out as a faint idea that seemed impossible to attain, but the more we talked about it the more we knew we had to do it. We're asking for help from the community and all people who support our goal to help us make this dream a reality.

Your contributions will help us acquire the venue, and further help us create an unforgettable night of big girl debauchery. You will also be helping a Los Angeles based women’s charity that our proceeds will be going to night of the show.

Dancers get to keep their singles though, because duh.

By contributing at least $10 to this campaign, you are guaranteed free entrance to the show (which will be taking place in Los Angeles). Once you contribute, you will be added to our mailing list where more information will be given after the campaign has completed. Currently, our goal is for this to take place during the first week of December (but that depends on if we can raise this money in time - so please help!).

Overall, we want this to be an unforgettable night of performance and partying where all people can come together and embrace the body positive movement in an approach that is a lot more in-your-face (literally). This is fun and raunchy as much as it is powerful and inclusive. Support women who love themselves, and help inspire others to feel the same way.

 

One last thing…

If you identify as a plus size woman and want to join our group of dancers, you can! Email us at psstrip15@gmail.com for more info.
story_txt:
Thicc Strip is a Body Positive Movement
Women who do not fit societally constructed standards of beauty are told on a daily basis that they are not worthy, because they do not fit one very specific mold pushed by mainstream media. Frankly, we are sick of it. Thicc Strip is a night dedicated to calling this ridiculous notion out for the total BS that it is. All women can and should feel good about themselves, and all women are deserving of self-love and confidence. We are putting an end to "fat" being a bad word.  How do we want to do this? With a real, live strip show! We are women who do not fit a specific mold and yet, we know we look good. We want to show other women like us that self-love goes further than outside hate. Thicc Strip is a show that embraces body diversity in the most explicit way possible. We want to prove that beauty is diverse, being sexual is not a sin, and we are all capable of looking and feeling great.
Who Is Organizing This?

My name is Alison Stevenson and I’m a comedian, writer, and unabashed fat Instagram slut (@JustAboutGlad) who has written extensively about body image, most notably for Vice. I also co-host a sex positive dating podcast called V Single. My writing and comedy is unapologetically feminist. You can learn more about me on my website: alisonstevenson.com.

story:
ABOUT COURDANCE. 

Courdance. comes from the Latin root-word for courage, 'cor', which means 'heart.' Courage, the ability to do something frightening, must empower us to be creative. We aim to tell the stories of who we are with our whole hearts. We aim to embody courage -  Courdance. is courage in motion. 

Our mission is to engage our community through dance. We do this by providing performance and choreographic opportunities to emerging dance artists, presenting dance to audiences of all ages through a series of home season performances, site-specific performances, and a seasonal tour, as well as providing dance programming that fosters a creative, courageous spirit. 

Welcome to our first season!

 

ABOUT RENDERING HOME 

Rendering Home is a dance piece that showcases personal perspectives of home and the varying stories that inevitably follow; both the stories of displacement and uncertainty as well as those of hope and restoration.

Rendering Home is a response to the millions of individuals with and without, those uprooted, those unsettled, those hopeful, and those seeking what it means to belong.

Situated around numerous memories and experiences, a cast of five dancers piece together their stories of home as they wrestle with themes of order, chaos, displacement, uncertainty, balance, burden, and belonging.

This work has been coming to life since August 2017. Inspired by a combination of her experiences of homesickness and several encounters befriending individuals experiencing homelessness during her time living in Chicago, Courdance. director Kaitlin Flynn Goodwin set out to physically investigate the answers to the question, "What is Home?"

A smaller interpretation of this work premiered in February 2018 alongside a visual arts exhibition titled SHELTER: Crafting a Safe Home at Society for Contemporary Craft in Pittsburgh. During that time, Flynn Goodwin was commissioned to create a work in Albuquerque, NM that ultimately laid the foundation for the evening-length work that will premiere in November 2018. Since then, the artists of Courdance.  have been researching, investigating, and crafting unique stories of home. We are so excited to share this performance with you!

 

COLLABORATORS

My fantastic collaborators are photographer Richard Frost and dancers Marcella Day, Tricia Grace, Emily Koch, and Rudy Wright.  Additionally, I am using sound from classical composer Tristan Eckerson. 

This performance will take place at Union Project in Pittsburgh on November 9th and 10th.  Your support will allow us to pay for performance space, production costs, promotional materials, and most importantly, compensation for these talented artists. 

 

WHY IT'S IMPORTANT

We exist to engage our community. That means we desire to connect and grow with our audience. We rely on our donors to engage and support the programming we present, allowing us to create more art, pay our artists, and share more opportunities. Without supporters, we would not be able to fully present work that engages the community, while on tour or at home.

Thank you for investing in dance, art, collaboration, and in the city of Pittsburgh. Your generosity allows us to use dance as a vehicle for social change in our city, country, and the world.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We are grateful for all of our supporters, small and large, near and far!  Some more ways to help:

  • LOCALS (Yinzers): Join us for the show! Rendering Home will premiere on Friday 11/9 and Saturday 11/10 at Union Project (801 N Negley Avenue). For tickets, visit www.courdance.com.
  • LOCALS (Yinzers): VOLUNTEER @ Rendering Home - We are looking for several members of our community to assist us with pre-show and post-show duties (prop load-in, ticketing, bar manager, program passer-outer, and clean up crew. If you'd like to see the show for free, this way is for you! For more info, email us at courdance@gmail.com. 
  • NON-LOCALS (Courdance. Community): Give us a LIKE! Follow our journey on social media. Check out our Facebook page or join the Courdance. community on Instagram: @courdance

Thank you from the bottom of our hearts for all of your love, support, prayers, positivity, and encouragement. We are grateful. Let's dance!

story:
Last Call by Anne Kenney

The Open Fist Theatre Company produced Last Call as a staged reading during last year's First Look Festival. Now, we are ecstatic to to bring you the world premiere production for this year's Festival Jan 18 - Feb 23, 2019 at the Atwater Village Theatre (3269 Casitas Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90039)

About the Play: The Vaughn family’s go-to defense mechanism of sarcasm and mordant humor falls short when the aging parents hatch a not-so-funny way to avoid the retirement home.

About the Playwright: Anne Kenney is a wonderfully talented writer and producer, known for her outstanding work on the series Outlander, Greek, Switched at Birth, and Hellcats.

Last Call is directed by Lane Allison, produced by Katie May Porter, and features Laura Richardson, Ben Martin, Lynn Milgrim, Art Hall, Bronte Scoggins, Stephanie Crothers, and Bryan Bertone.

Join us for:

  • All the excitement of Opening Night including a red-carpet reception after the show
  • Talkback nights (Sat Jan 19 and Sat Feb 16), where after the show, the writer and cast will discuss Last Call moderated by SPECIAL GUESTS! 
    • Sat Jan 19 - Moderator: Diana Gabaldon, New York Times best selling author of the “Outlander” novels.
    • Sat Feb 16 - Moderator: Fred Golan, writer/producer of Justified on FX and Amazon Prime’s Sneaky Pete.

(Don't want to miss out on these special events?  Donate and get these as a perk!! Or tickets will be on sale starting Dec 26 at https://openfist.secure.force.com/ticket)

 

Who We Are & What We Need

Founded in 1990, the company chose the name Open Fist to represent its fierce determination to reach out and engage audiences with impactful work. From its inception, the company immediately established its reputation as a cutting-edge ensemble, willing to tackle difficult material. Open Fist is passionately led by Artistic Director Martha Demson.

Last Call brings all this together with a sense of heart. With such a giving writer and talented cast, we really wanted to give this production the quality and attention it deserves and our immensely creative design team the resources to immerse us in the world of the Vaughn family.

Here is how we will use your contributions:

Support this project and then use your perk to come experience through Last Call how freedom of choice can manifest itself in so many wonderfully different ways.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign, and of course come see the show! We are so excited to share this story with you and need your help to share it with the world!

story:
Short Summary

We are They Played Productions, the team behind last year's Hollywood Fringe Festival musical hit "Nothing Bad: A Werewolf Rock Musical"! We are comprised of co-owners Erik Blair (writer/director of Nothing Bad) and Thea Rivera (producer).

For Hollywood Fringe Festival 2018, we have a new show. Without your help, we cannot bring this world-premiere production to the stage.

"God: The Apologies Tour" is an interactive, improvisational show that will give audiences the chance to speak directly with the divine Itself. Live. On-stage. The Creator will offer insight into how the universe was started, why Free Will has turned out to be such a mistake and will even answer questions from the audience.

For over a decade, Erik has been examining the role of religion in the 21st century, trying to imagine how the Creator would look at the world around us if the Creator returned. This production is the conversation that comes from that examination--and it's a conversation that you can be part of. It's a show built around the idea of you conversing with the Creator in real-time, person to entity. You can ask whatever is on your mind--and get the answer.

With over a dozen years' of improvisational experience and a deep knowledge of most world-wide religions, Erik believes this show will contemplate today's topics through the uniquely alien perspective brought by the One who created everything and who has watched us all...since we all began.

You can also expect some surprises when you walk through the Pearly Gates to visit the Creator. After all, when one is hanging out with an Immortal Being...anything might happen, including to the audience itself.

We have a 6-night run planned for this world-premiere production:

  • June 3rd: 7:30 PM     
  • June 7th: 7:30 PM
  • June 10th: 9:00 PM
  • June 16th: 1:30 PM
  • June 17th: 4:30 PM
  • June 22nd: 8:00 PM

We need your help to bring "God: The Apologies Tour" to the 2018 Hollywood Fringe. Fringe theatre is produced by those who are passionate about generating unique visions and unusual ideas. By pledging to help us reach our production requirement goals, you will be a part of that passion.

In return, we are offering perks for you to have your own connection to the divine. And it doesn't matter if you can see the show live or if you live far away. Regardless of where you are, if you pledge to the campaign you will have your own chance to connect with the Creator. And you will have our blessings, as well, for all your help in bringing this unique idea to an audience.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $3000 total for the show--all of which goes towards producing the show and which will cover the entirety of the production. The specific breakdown is as follows:

  • $1100 – Theatre Space

  • $250 – Festival Registration

  • $350 – Stage Manager

  • $350 – Cast

  • $250 – Crew

  • $200 – Costumes/Set

  • $300 – Marketing

  • $200 – Performance Recording

TOTAL: $3000

In return, we're offering you perks that we're really excited about giving you. Our perks connect you as the audience directly to the concept of the show in multiple ways. These perks include:

  • Your Name in the Program
  • Thanked Live on-stage
  • A Personalized Thank-You Video from God
  • Your Question Answered on Video by God
  • "Heaven & Hell" Gift Bags
  • Digital Recordings of the Show
  • Behind The Scenes Videos
  • VIP On-Stage Seats
  • A Chance to Be Part of the Show

We're offering you so many options because we believe in this show and we know that the more interaction we can bring to it, the better the show will become. So we can't WAIT to reward you however you choose to pledge!

Whatever funds we make will go directly towards producing God: The Apologies Tour. If we don't raise all of the funds we need, we will continue to try to put on the production. But the less funds we receive, the more scaled-down the production will be by necessity.

The Impact

Fringe festivals are one of the top avenues in the last decade for theatrical artists to create unique and unusual theatre for audiences. They are places where artists can experiment to find new and different approaches to subjects and to theatrical forms and concepts.

The Hollywood Fringe Festival is the largest such festival in the Western half of the United States and we at They Played Productions have been involved in it for the last two festivals. In 2016, we were actors and stage managers. In 2017, we wrote and produced "Nothing Bad: A Werewolf Rock Musical", which was both a commercial success and award-winning from the festival itself. We also raised over $900 for the production here on Indiegogo.

We have returned to Indiegogo this year because the show we hope to bring to the festival is more unique. We believe this show has great potential to be successful both at HFF and beyond. It's our hope that we will use this first premiere production as a spring-board to open up potentials for this show to play in other cities and other Fringe festivals.

In a time where our politics are so fractured and our own selves are so caught up in the social-media-driven madness of our existence, we believe that this show will be an experience that will reach beyond and through all of the noise. We believe this show can speak to everyone, regardless of their religious affiliation--because this is not the Christian God. It's not -any- specific God. You are going to meet the creator--and It may not be exactly what you think.

But we believe wholeheartedly that you're going to find this production exciting. Whether you're here in person or watching the recorded production, this will be a Creator that can speak to you. One that can remind people that there is more to life than the next "like" or the next Instagram foodie pic.

This is an immersive, interactive experience with the One behind reality. And we believe you--and everyone--will enjoy what we've got planned.

Risks & Challenges

This production is, like many Fringe shows, an experiment. We believe that it's going to be a strong, well-received production. But any experiment may fail, and we may turn out to be wrong.

Moreover, if we cannot raise enough money, there is the potential that the show may fail because we couldn't make it as completely as we want to make it. The advantages of Fringe festivals include being able to create theatre on a much smaller budget than otherwise--but even still, there are costs. The budget we're asking for here is designed to cover those costs--but barely. If we cannot raise the funds completely, we may have to make cuts that could impact the show.

The advantage here is that the show is our own creation, so we can--and will--adjust as we have to adjust. They Played Productions' team is ready to handle the challenges of the show and to alter course if we must. That is the advantage of having a team who have already proven they can pull off a MUCH larger cast musical in the same festival settings during last year. But we are also the team that is much more aware, now, of the true costs the Hollywood Fringe Festival, and we would far prefer to have the funds to complete the show without any additional issues.

Other Ways You Can Help

We sincerely hope you will pledge to help our production.

But if you can't pledge money directly, you CAN still help us succeed in our funding goals!

You can:

  • Spread the love--talk about us to your friends, your family, your social media connections
  • Use the Indiegogo sharing tools to spread our campaign across the media world
  • Suggest to podcasts and blogs that you love that they interview us by emailing/contacting them

Any way you can spread our campaign helps us as well. The more people know about this show, the more people will learn about our plans for this experience--and the closer we will get to the funds we need to make it a reality.

You can find our project (currently in process of getting registered) on the Hollywood Fringe website at: http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/4810

You are going to meet the creator--and It may not be exactly what you think.
But we believe wholeheartedly that you're going to find this production exciting. Whether you're here in person or watching the recorded production, this will be a Creator that can speak to you. One that can remind people that there is more to life than the next "like" or the next Instagram foodie pic.
This is an immersive, interactive experience with the One behind reality. And we believe you--and everyone--will enjoy what we've got planned.

Risks & Challenges
This production is, like many Fringe shows, an experiment. We believe that it's going to be a strong, well-received production. But any experiment may fail, and we may turn out to be wrong.
Moreover, if we cannot raise enough money, there is the potential that the show may fail because we couldn't make it as completely as we want to make it. The advantages of Fringe festivals include being able to create theatre on a much smaller budget than otherwise--but even still, there are costs. The budget we're asking for here is designed to cover those costs--but barely. If we cannot raise the funds completely, we may have to make cuts that could impact the show.
The advantage here is that the show is our own creation, so we can--and will--adjust as we have to adjust. They Played Productions' team is ready to handle the challenges of the show and to alter course if we must. That is the advantage of having a team who have already proven they can pull off a MUCH larger cast musical in the same festival settings during last year. But we are also the team that is much more aware, now, of the true costs the Hollywood Fringe Festival, and we would far prefer to have the funds to complete the show without any additional issues.

Other Ways You Can Help
We sincerely hope you will pledge to help our production.
But if you can't pledge money directly, you CAN still help us succeed in our funding goals!
You can:

Spread the love--talk about us to your friends, your family, your social media connections
Use the Indiegogo sharing tools to spread our campaign across the media world
Suggest to podcasts and blogs that you love that they interview us by emailing/contacting them

Any way you can spread our campaign helps us as well. The more people know about this show, the more people will learn about our plans for this experience--and the closer we will get to the funds we need to make it a reality.You can find our project (currently in process of getting registered) on the Hollywood Fringe website at: http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/4810

story:
Who are you funding?

Two working class actors who are committed to giving a voice in theatre to those who need it.

Hi, we are Stacey and Nicola Bland, sisters from Essex who now live in East London. We started in the industry at a young age and have been working professionally for 12 years. We both have a varied backgrounds within the industry.

Stacey

I produced & acted in a production of Alan Ayckbourn's GamePlan at The Hen and Chickens Theatre where I achieved a sell out run. In 2016 I worked at Theatre Royal Stratford East on Home Theatre where I wrote, devised & performed my own bespoke piece of theatre. I was also the associate producer on Arts Council funded Chicken Palace, which achieved a sell out run at the new studio space at TRSE. As an actor, my credits include Suzanne in Don’t Dress For Dinner (UK Tour), Dibs in Santa’s New Sleigh (Lichfield Garrick, Key Theatre, Peterborough, Walker Theatre Shrewsbury, Arts Theatre, London), Ugly Sister in Cinderella (Lichfield Garrick), Finian’s Rainbow (Union Theatre), Hey Mr Producer (Lyceum), Oliver (Palladium), Sorrel in GamePlan (Hen and Chickens), Ensemble/ cover & played Mum in Little Red Riding Hood (Theatre Royal Stratford East), Florinda/Granny in Into The Woods (Bridewell Theatre) Sasha in Falariki: The Greek Tragedy (Lyric Hammersmith), Shirley in Tales of Aviation Heroes (Soho Theatre), Ensemble in Yeoman of the Guard (Tower of London Festival).  God Save the Teen (Trafalgar Square), Blade Runner (Secret Cinema, Canary Wharf) and Show Girl in Bugsy Malone (Secret Cinema, The Troxy). I have been the female lead in short film Best Bud (Sanbon Films), ‘Coulda Shoulda Woulda’ (London Dreams Motion Pictures), Downsizing (Mad Ninja Films).  I was a regular dancer on The Justin Lee Collins Show (ITV2) as well as dancing for Sky Sports, The Katy Brand Show (ITV2) and 1 Direction on X Factor (ITV). 

Nicola 

Nicola began professionally acting from a young age with her first lead role in the film “Yellow” starring alongside Ray Winstone, shortly followed by Eponine in Les Miserables at The Palace Theatre. Since leaving E15 Acting School, Nicola went straight into "Tits/Teeth" at the Soho Theatre and has since been working on various projects. Nicola has been working professionally for the last 15 years with roles in The Bill, Casualty, ITV Drama “Pickles”, BBC period drama "Messiah" many adverts, Short films and Plays at The Soho Theatre, Roundhouse Theatre, Criterion Theatre, Barbican Cockpit and Royal Court Theatre. Recently finishing a 2 month transfer of "Fight Club" in Hong Kong. 

The Project

Both proud members of the NYT where our love for exploring new writing began. Together we have written a play ‘Call me Vicky’ based on the life of our inspirational Godmother a transgender woman growing up in 80s South London. 10 years ago I had a dream Vicky was born a man. It was only from my mums reaction that we knew Martin ever existed. We had no reason to
question it beforehand, why would we. We both felt a huge connection to the story & separately started exploring different avenues. I based my writing on conversations with my Mum & her version of events as I didn’t want to make Vicky uncomfortable & I was conscious that this may not have been something she ever thought we would know. Whereas Nicola, never being the one to shy away from these things had conversations with Vicky, who, it transpired was happy to talk about her story & was keen for us to explore artistically. The journey of this script has taken many different paths & it wasn't until we decided to come together that it began to take shape as a play. 

We are eager to generate a conversation in schools colleges and 6th forms as well, and the funding will help us take a stripped back version of the play and work with the students in their own environment. 

We are sure this play will have a huge impact on the people that see it and know that with the right team behind us we can work to change the minds of even the most closed in society. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise a total of £40,000 to put this play on and take it into schools across London. Your donation along with funding from other avenues will go towards the following: 

Hire of the Theatre, Payment for the actors, Set design, Costume, Sound and Lighting design, Payment for the Director, Payment for the Stage Manager, Hire for the Rehearsal Venue.

If we do not reach our goal then the money will still go to all of these things we will just have to re assess our budgeting and explore other money raising avenues. 

If you can’t give money we would really appreciate it if you helped to support our campaign in the following ways:

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign on social media.

 Share it on Facebook/Twitter/Instagram

 The more audience we reach the better are odds are.


Thank you so much in advance for all of your support! 

 

Stacey and Nicola xxx

story:
Who We Are:

CSz Boston and The Riot Theater are 2 locally owned and operated organizations working together to bring more improv and sketch comedy to the diverse community of Roslindale and its surrounding neighborhoods.

About CSz Boston
CSz Boston is New England's home for the award-winning, competitive improv show, ComedySportz. CSz Boston is locally owned and operated by Courtney Pong and Betse Green. In addition to ComedySportz, CSz Boston offers improv & applied improv workshops and classes to empower the people, businesses, and organizations in Boston to live their best possible lives through fun and play. CSz Boston is part of CSz Worldwide, a global network of companies that have been transforming the world using improvisation since 1987.

About The Riot Theater
The Riot Theater is locally owned and operated by Improv Jones Boston, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that has been performing improv comedy in the Greater Boston area since 2006. The organization opened The Riot Theater in November 2014 to bring comedy of all forms to the underserved areas of Boston, in Jamaica Plain, Roslindale, West Roxbury and beyond. It is under the direction of Joseph Gels.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $15,000 in funding to help outfit this new space to meet the needs of dozens of performers and over a thousand audience members a year. Your donation will go directly toward:

  • Building a new box office/tech booth
  • Painting the walls
  • Decorating the place to create an exceptional audience experience
  • Installing necessary theatrical equipment

Basically doing the big and little things that make the space look and feel like a professional place where the community of Roslindale, the city of Boston, and visitors alike can enjoy comedy with their friends and family. A place with comedy for everyone.

If we do not reach our full $15,000, the funds we do collect will still go toward exactly the items mentioned.

For you:

Whether you live in these communities or are helping support from afar, we've got a variety of perks that reward your donation, including:

  • Tickets
  • Workshops
  • Local business advertising packages
  • T-shirts and buttons
  • Lifetime passes

The Impact

With this new home, we can move toward making a space that can we intend to be a centerpiece of the community. Improv and comedy build community in a unique way that few other things can. With this new home and your donation, we will be able to expand our offerings so that more people can enjoy the facility and what we plan to offer, from programming suitable for all audiences to enriching education.

Risks & Challenges

There are risks with any change. Will current audiences stick with us as we relocate? Will we be able to build new audiences in our new home? We are confident that we have the right team and strategy to not only bring our audiences with us but also firmly build roots in the rapidly growing community of Roslindale, especially with the help of wonderful neighbors like the Roslindale Village Main Streets. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, via word of mouth or on your social channels - help us find folks who are passionate about bringing improv and comedy to communities. Every little bit helps. 

With gratitude,

CSz Boston & The Riot

story:
caitlin+dancers and Kaley Pruitt Dance will share an NYC Season June 1 & 2 at Martha Graham Studio Theater. Each company will present one work from repertoire and one world premiere, and you can be a part of making it happen!

 

Kaley Pruitt is the Artistic Director and performer with Kaley Pruitt Dance. Her work investigates the nuances of the human experience and explores the intrinsic communication between bodies in space. The work spans from comedic dance theater to abstract concert aesthetic. Originally from Ketchum, Idaho, she has presented her work in Idaho, California, Massachusetts, Florida, New York, and Illinois. She now travels between Illinois and New York teaching and creating work on students at Illinois State University and working with the professional company in New York City.

 

Caitlin Dutton-Reaver is the Director of caitlin+dancers, a company dedicated to reflecting human subtlety and the exploration and development of new movement-based, technical modern work. The company presents in both traditional theaters and unconventional, ad hoc spaces/site-specific environments to showcase movement as a conduit for imaginative grandeur and promote dance as a community asset. The company performs along the East Coast from Georgia to Vermont in addition to its New York base.

 

The Project

 

Kaley Pruitt Dance

In our dreams we become grand versions of ourselves - we conquer fears, fly to new heights, and live as our most extraordinary selves. “Limitless” (NYC premiere) came into being through a desire to embody the sensations of our dream selves in real life. It came from a drive to celebrate the human spirit: our determination, compassion and power in times of real threat to those pillars of individuality. The score, being so iconic, gave me a new challenge as a choreographer; to take Gershwin’s bold and exuberant themes and expand them into space audiences had not previously imagined was possible. I wanted to bring to life the invincibility we have all experienced in our imaginations. The movement is churning, energetic, celebratory, ecstatic and pushes past limitations both physical and imagined.

 

“Like Minds” (premiere) takes its inspiration from the space two people inhabit when they deeply understand one another, depend on one another, and share opinions and inspirations. This space is one of connection, and also dynamic fluctuation that pushes each individual to grow and challenge their world. While creating this work, I envision magnets in that they can have such powerful force unifying them, and in one turn, they can just as forcefully repel. There is a phenomenal energy created by two people who understand one another but also deliberately challenge and question those understandings. What does it look and feel like when on one hand we build something greater than ourselves with someone else, and simultaneously destabilize what we’ve made in searching to really know and understand that person?

 

caitlin+dancers

 

“Gifts for the Void” (2016) is a dance propelled by the idea of displacement: in movement, social context, and between bodies in space. Thrown into the realm of visual interest, “Gifts” plays with contrast, alignment, and communal effort. An original score by Michael Wall includes an intertwining of breath and instrumental substructure, creating a “Lord of the Flies”-type tension between dancers, sound, and environment. “Gifts for the Void” is a constantly shifting arena, moving fluidly between alliances and ideas.

 

“Variations on a Ghost” (premiere) draws from the ghost signature: and Edwardian fad that saw its height at around 1909, where a signature would be written in slow drying ink then quickly folded over to create a new image of peaks and curves. This new work will play on the duality of the folded inscription as well as the newly formed image. It layers in the idea of how a person leaves evidence of existence and individuality through their autograph, though when folded into a unique image, remains legally binding as an official mark of their entity.

 

Funding Goals

 

caitlin+dancers and Kaley Pruitt Dance are looking to raise $6,000 through this campaign to fund the dancers’ rehearsal and performance pay, space rental, and costuming. We are committed to our artistic visions and strongly committed to paying our dancers fairly for their professional work. Here is a breakdown of our June season budget:

 
  • $600 – Space rental for rehearsals to create 4 works
  • $1,700 – Dancer rehearsal pay for 10 dancers across both companies
  • $1,700 – Theater rental for 2 performances
  • $1,400 – Dancer performance pay for 10 dancers for 2 shows
  • $600 – Costumes, printed materials, photographer/videographer
 

Know that no donation amount is too small! Contributions of any amount are incredibly helpful to furthering our work. Your dollars will go directly towards the dancers pay first and foremost, then to the other budget items as we approach our funding goal. If we exceed our fundraising goal, the C+D and KPD dancers receive a well-deserved raise! If you want to help but are unable to donate, please share our campaign and performance details with everyone you know.

 

Perks

 

Donate $15 – Special shout-out on our performance program.

Donate $30 – Receive 1 complimentary ticket to the performance of your choice, plus a special shout-out on our performance program.

Donate $50 – Receive 2 complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice, plus a special shout-out on our performance program.

Donate $75 – Receive 2 complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice and a public thank you via video.

Donate $150 – Backstage Pass: Receive 2 complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice, plus join the dancers in a rehearsal (popcorn provided) and access to our Tech/Dress rehearsal to see how the whole show comes together.

Donate $300 or more – Receive 4 complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice plus dinner and drinks out with the whole company after opening night, Backstage Pass to our Tech/Dress rehearsal, plus 8x10 printed photo of each company in performance signed by the whole company, respectively.

 

Special Out-of-Towner’s Perks

 

Donate $20 – Receive a special shout-out on our performance program and a public thank you via video.

Donate $50 – Receive a 5x7 printed performance photo of each company, signed by the whole company, respectively.

Donate $100 – Receive a company T-shirt of your choice and a 5x7 printed performance photo of each company, signed by the whole company, respectively.

Donate $200 or more – Receive a DVD of the show, both company T-shirts and an 8x10 printed performance photo of each company, signed by the whole company, respectively.

 

Thank you in advance. We can’t wait to share this work with you June 1 & 2 at The Martha Graham Center!

 

Kaley Pruitt of Kaley Pruitt Dance

Caitlin Dutton-Reaver of caitlin+dancers

Get more information on C+D and KPD's work and the upcoming June shows below!

www.KaleyPruittDance.com

www.caitlinplusdancers.org

Donations are not tax-deductible.

story:
Please Note:

  • Donations on IndieGoGo are not tax-deductible. You may make a tax-deductible donation on Fractured Atlas: Rude Grooms' Commons Series is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Rude Grooms' Commons Series must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.​
  • When making a donation, make sure to enter a whole number without a decimal point (i.e., 35 rather than 35.00) -- contributors have reported issues with decimal points when backing the project. If you have any questions or issues, please reach out to us directly and we'll figure it out.

 

 

In Brief

We are a Startup Theatre Experiment run by experienced actor-creators. With your help, we'll bring a free professional, accessible, and family-friendly performances of William Shakespeare's Much Ado About Nothing to audiences in culturally underserved areas of Queens, NY. In the long run, this production is the first step towards establishing a series of free and pay-what-you-can productions of new and classic plays built as immersive, interactive, and irreplicable experiences.

  • The ensemble of this production includes veterans of Shakespeare's Globe, The Old Globe, New York Classical Theatre, Classic Stage Company, Trinity Shakespeare Festival, and Seven Stages Shakespeare, among many other national and international companies.
  • Bringing world-class, approachable productions of these timeless stories directly to an audience is more important than ever in our increasingly fragmented society. By supporting this production, you will be playing a very active role in bringing communities together to share in joy, understanding, and empathy.
  • With a successful first public production, we can expand this program to serve an even wider community by seeking financial support through grants, foundations, and corporate sponsors; your contribution is not just helping to put up this production, it is cementing our Commons Series program as a free, public cultural resource for even more communities in the future.

You can make a meaningful difference with even the smallest contribution. Our perks will make sure that your investment is well rewarded; more importantly, with even the smallest donation you are planting a seed to grow understanding and build community.

 

 

What's in it for You (and Us)?

As an experiment in translating the Elizabethan theatre troupe model intro 21st Century Startup vernacular, our Patrons are of especially significant importance to us. With as small a donation as $25, you'll get priority access to all of our events -- including events not available to the general public (like our Secret Shakespeare Hunt, which guests have called "by far THE COOLEST THING I'VE EVER DONE IN New York City").

Here is exactly where your $6,000 will go:

  • $2,250 - Artist Stipends - though the production is free, we are committed to ensuring that our collaborating artists receive stipends above the minimum transportation reimbursement required by Actors Equity Association. As a company, we plan to move aggressively towards paying our artists at least minimum wage for their skilled work; in the meantime, all artists involved in the production receive an equal favored nations stipend of $150 for the two week commitment, including our two Acting Apprentices.
  • $1,700 - Production Costs -  this includes costumes, props, wardrobe and musical instrument maintenance, a 10x10 canopy for changing area and basic scenic requirements, City Park permits, theater rental
  • $1,250 - Rehearsal Expenses - this includes rehearsal space rental (for three rehearsals where we cannot be accommodated by our partner, Long Island City Artists at the Plaxall Gallery) and stage management expenses during the hectic one-week rehearsal process.
  • $500 - Insurance - this is a contribution of 1/6 the annual premiums for general liability and volunteer accident insurance to make sure that our artists and our audiences are protected.
  • $300 - Publicity and Marketing - minimal advertising, including postcards to hand out in the communities surrounding the performances and targeting online advertising.

In addition to joining our extended family, the following contributions will get you unique perks:

  • $1 - Upstart Crow - a video thank you from the cast, an Elizabethan social media shout-out, access to exclusive behind the scenes updates throughout the process, and a listing on our website as a Pioneer Supporter of the Commons Series.
  • $25 - Patron - all of the above, plus exclusive access to our Private Series through July 2019.
  • $50 - Shake-Scene - all of the above, plus access to VIP seating area for you and a guest at the performance of your choice, and a Rude Grooms water bottle.
  • $100 - Muse of Fire - all of the above, plus an original sonnet composed to you (or the person of your choice) by Rude Grooms’ Master of the Revels Montgomery Sutton.
  • $250 - Tiger's Heart - all of the above, plus an invitation to observe a rehearsal (in person or via private video-conference)
  • $500 - Player's Hide - all of the above, plus a walk-on role at the performance of your choice (only one spot available per performance)
  • $5,000 - Lord Chamberlain - all of the above, plus a private performance at your own venue (you provide transportation if outside of NYC)
  • $10,000 - Queen - all of the above, plus a custom, immersive theatrical event created just for you and your friends.

Even if we don't meet our goal, this production is coming in August. Our modest budget for this first experiment was designed to ensure that we can each work extra shifts, load up credit cards, beg, borrow, and do whatever it takes to bring this production to our inspiring venues and communities.

 

 

The Production

When we considered launching Rude Grooms' Commons Series with Much Ado About Nothing, we asked ourselves what makes the play relevant today: why Much Ado, and why now?

Three responses emerged that have become  the guiding principles of our process:

1. Can the events of the play believably take place in our modern world and the #MeToo movement? If so, how might its depictions of gender roles illuminate our current struggle for equality and respect?

2. The play's rich explorations of interpersonal warfare ask challenging questions about why or whether we choose to forgive those who have hurt us most intimately.

3. Much Ado is a delicious cocktail of wit, delight, and heart: in our increasingly fragmented world, joining as a community to laugh, love, and mend together couldn't be more important.

We are led by actor-manager Laura Piccoli (Unhealthy at Batallion Theatre Co) and produced in partnership with Long Island City Artists at the Plaxall Gallery and the Astoria Park Alliance.

In addition to Piccoli, the acting company includes Marie Louise Guinier* (Scissoring at INTAR), Sibel Damar (“We Will Slay” at UCB), Dhruv Iyengar (Taming of the Shrew at Ithaca Shakespeare Company), Daniel Kemper (The Limit of the Tongue at The Daughter’s Collective), Deb Radloff* (Caucasian Chalk Circle at Classic Stage Company), Joseph Robinson* (Nashville Shakespeare Festival), Amanda Rojas (Iridescent, Cannes 2018), Eduardo Ruiz (Pericles at Sainsbury Theatre), Montgomery Sutton* (Twelfth Night at Shakespeare’s Globe), and Molly Thomas (Medea at Titan Theatre Company).

Kate Pitt (The Way of the World at the Folger Theatre) is the Book-Holder, Kara Arena (The Winter's Tale at Seven Stages Shakespeare) is the Master of Music, Bridget Bose (Guilty Pleasures Cabaret) is the Master of Movement, and Calley Luman is Associate Producer.

 

 

More Ways to Help

Seriously, the smallest contribution will have a major impact on this production, and through it, the communities that it touches. But there are many more ways you can help:

  • Share this campaign all over your social networks. Connect us with people in your circle who have the desire and ability to help launch unique arts organizations.
  • Come and see us, and bring your friends! The best way for us to build word of mouth and find new patrons and sponsors is with bodies on the grass.
  • If you or a family member know of corporations with an interest in supporting arts and cultural programming, please point us in their direction to make an appeal.

 

 

Stretch Goals

If, beyond our wildest dreams, we not only meet but exceed our initial goal, here is our plan for how additional funds will bolster the production.

  • $6,000-$8,550 - Artist Stipends - every dollar raised between $6,000 and $8,550 will go directly towards increasing artist stipends until we have doubled our initially budgeted amount
  • $8,550-$9,000 - Additional Production Expenses - a second 10’x10’ canopy to extend our scenic capabilities and changing areas.
  • $9,000-$10,000 - Additional PR and Marketing - more targeted online advertising, printing posters to put up near performance venues, etc.
  • $10,000+ - Moving Towards a Living Wage - anything above $10,000 will be allocated equally among artists until they each reach the equivalent of NY State minimum wage for hours worked on the production. Beyond that, it will be an investment in our next free, public Commons Series production.

story:
Short Summary

  • In 2007, Liimu McGill read The Secret, a book about how to use the Law of Attraction to manifest the life of your dreams. Within a matter of months she used the Law of Attraction to manifest a huge lifelong dream: she landed a solo on NBC's Clash of Choirs and performed with Patti LaBelle for 10 million viewers across the United States.
  • Since then, Liimu has built a million-dollar consulting business, shepherded the budding musical careers of her three daughters, created and starred in her own reality series and moved her family to Malibu to live the life they always dreamed of. Now her mission is to teach other moms how to reclaim their dreams and inspire their children in the process. In MOMSTAR: FROM MADHOUSE TO MALIBU, she shares her story, and will make you believe you can change your life, too​. 
  • As a contributor, you will help bring Liimu's story to millions, helping moms around the world reconnect with their innermost dreams and live their most powerfully authentic lives. Change in the world happens one person at a time... and this is your chance to contribute to the positive global shift we've all been feeling. 

What We Need & What You Get

Liimu's July 13th performance in Philadelphia is already a done deal. We need your help to bring her message to the world by hiring a professional production company to film the show and livestream it to a global audience. 

                   

  • To say "thanks!" we have a variety of fun perks from which to choose. Check them out on the right!
  • If for some reason we don't meet our goal, the funds will be broken down in the same way. If we exceed our goal, the funds will be put toward continuing to spread the MomStar message!

The Impact

  • Your contribution goes a lot farther than simply helping fund the July 13th performance: once we've filmed the show, the footage will live forever, serving to educate and inspire women around the world for years to come! 
  • Over the last 10 years, Liimu has built a hugely successful million-dollar business simply by following her heart and tuning in to her intuition. Imagine what the world would be like if everyone did that! Now Liimu's ready to show others how to live the lives they have only dreamt of.

Risks & Challenges

  • Nothing is a given in this world, and Liimu knows that. In her life, she's been on the upside (living in Malibu with a thriving business and a beautiful family) and the downside (living in a beat-up car with a broke boyfriend and a serious drug addiction) and she knows first hand how hard it can be to "give it up and trust." In creating MomStar, Liimu hopes to reach millions of women so they can learn from her experiences—but there's no guarantee that the world is ready for her message. 
  • Liimu is willing to put it all on the line to share what she has learned about living a life of joyful creation. She has crafted a show in which she bares her heart and soul for the sake of making the world a better place and now she's giving it up to a higher power to manifest her biggest dream. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • You can help us get the word out by sharing this campaign via social media. It's a tremendously effective, cost-free way to help us grow.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

Happy Manifesting,

Liimu + the MomStar Team

story:
WHAT IT'S ALL ABOUT...

THE 1st ANNUAL TRUMP FAMILY SPECIAL is an original musical comedy spoofing the first family in a yuge way!  In this send-up, Trump’s brood has gathered to perform in a live televised event for the new Trump TV network. But when the orange man-of-the hour runs late, host Ivanka stalls by interviewing the various family members, which leads to a wide array of clever character songs.  And when they are “off camera,” we find out what they’re really thinking…

Reminiscent of vintage TV family specials like The Partridge Family and The Brady Bunch, the show offers comic relief for these frustrating times - with a fresh perspective and fun-loving spirit.  A first rate cast delivers a cabaret evening you won't soon forget.

MUSICAL NUMBERS INCLUDE…Win, Win, Win * Look Gorgeous and Shut The Hell Up * The Brothers Trumpiovsky * If We Had It As Bad As You * Three Little Trophy Wives * The Spin Tango * You’re In Our Prayers * MAGA/And Then He Tweets * I’ve Got No Soul

WHAT SOME COOL PEOPLE ARE SAYING ABOUT US...

“It is SUBLIME!  An elixir for these insane times.” - Gregory Jbara, star of CBS hit Blue Bloods,       Tony Award winner, “Billy Elliot”

“A hilarious hour which somehow replaces the dread you've been feeling on a daily basis with pure unadulterated joy!" - Michelle Collins, SiriusXM's "The Michelle Collins Show"

"It's a laugh-out-loud, sweetly vicious takedown, with great music and fresh takes on this family of grifters, opportunists and Tiffany.” - Dave Holmes, Editor-at Large,  Esquire.com

“One of the funniest things I’ve seen on stage in ages..” - Dennis Hennsley, “Dennis Anyone” blog, writer, RuPaul’s Drag Race.

WHAT WE NEED...

Welllll...we need you. And your support. LOTS of support. We've had a great run so far but now we are looking at the reality of a 12 week run in NYC. We need costumes, rehearsal space to put in new jokes and songs, time with our amazing choreographer, and to pay the actors and put them on union contract! But don't worry, we'll make it worth your while!

WHAT YOU GET...

Besides the passive aggressive victory of sticking it to the orange one by donating to a show that lampoons him and his whole family, you're supporting the arts! We also have great perks...you know, if you're into that sort of thing.

story:
BoxLess Physical Theatre recently returned from a second London run, as well as a tour to Manchester, the team behind this five star show are packing up our bags and headed to Scotland. 

LOOP

LOOP began it's life at Theatre N16 in it's Balham days, where we performed a very brief extract from LOOP as part of a short play night. From the positive reaction we got to its early form, the rest of the script was written. From the first full production in summer 2017, to Theatre Royal Stratford East & 53two, Manchester earlier this year, we've taken LOOP up and down the country to great audience reception and loads (and loads) of four and five star reviews!

The story travels from 1965 to 1985 and finally to the present day, covering one family's loves, losses and struggles to the background of the music they grew up with. Combining a powerful family story with the best songs of the 60s and 80s, LOOP is the story of people evolving with the music they listen to.

"The combination of writing and movement makes this a physical piece of theatre which flows with a fascinating urgency." - ★★★★★ Theatre Weekly

"This may be the first play to articulate the stunted hopes of Generation Austerity." -★★★★ Manchester Theatre Awards

"A vivid exploration of love, culture and the coming of age" - ★★★★ Arthurs Seat UK

"A little bit of everything; it’s funny and heartwarming" - Theatre Things

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need £3000 - Edinburgh is more expensive than ever before but for us, this is an opportunity we couldn't turn down. Without the support of our producers, we couldn't have secured the time and venue we have done - we need to take this chance to get LOOP seen by the biggest audience we can! 

Even if we don't hit our £3000 total, anything you can spare will help, any money we can raise will go towards our target, and paying for everything that needs paying for - most crucially, the performers!

The Impact

Ensure that the cast can afford to leave London for a month, and have enough money to live and perform in Edinburgh.

  • Accommodation and travel for the cast and team, from London to Edinburgh.
  • The chance for LOOP to be seen by an international audience and be seen and reviewed by national journalists and theatre makers, leading to future opportunities for not only the company, but everyone involved.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can - come and see the show! There's something for everyone!
  • Any tweets, retweets or Facebook posts about LOOP would be greatly appreciated!

BoxLess Physical Theatre recently returned from a second London run, as well as a tour to Manchester, the team behind this five star show are packing up our bags and headed to Scotland. 

LOOP
LOOP began it's life at Theatre N16 in it's Balham days, where we performed a very brief extract from LOOP as part of a short play night. From the positive reaction we got to its early form, the rest of the script was written. From the first full production in summer 2017, to Theatre Royal Stratford East & 53two, Manchester earlier this year, we've taken LOOP up and down the country to great audience reception and loads (and loads) of four and five star reviews!
The story travels from 1965 to 1985 and finally to the present day, covering one family's loves, losses and struggles to the background of the music they grew up with. Combining a powerful family story with the best songs of the 60s and 80s, LOOP is the story of people evolving with the music they listen to.
"The combination of writing and movement makes this a physical piece of theatre which flows with a fascinating urgency." - ★★★★★ Theatre Weekly
"This may be the first play to articulate the stunted hopes of Generation Austerity." -★★★★ Manchester Theatre Awards
"A vivid exploration of love, culture and the coming of age" - ★★★★ Arthurs Seat UK
"A little bit of everything; it’s funny and heartwarming" - Theatre Things

 
What We Need & What You Get
We need £3000 - Edinburgh is more expensive than ever before but for us, this is an opportunity we couldn't turn down. Without the support of our producers, we couldn't have secured the time and venue we have done - we need to take this chance to get LOOP seen by the biggest audience we can! 
Even if we don't hit our £3000 total, anything you can spare will help, any money we can raise will go towards our target, and paying for everything that needs paying for - most crucially, the performers!

The Impact
Ensure that the cast can afford to leave London for a month, and have enough money to live and perform in Edinburgh.

Accommodation and travel for the cast and team, from London to Edinburgh.
The chance for LOOP to be seen by an international audience and be seen and reviewed by national journalists and theatre makers, leading to future opportunities for not only the company, but everyone involved.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can - come and see the show! There's something for everyone!
Any tweets, retweets or Facebook posts about LOOP would be greatly appreciated!

story:
THE STORY

Love & Pride is about 6 individuals who identify at different points along the spectrums of gender, sex, and sexuality, and the conflicts that arise within themselves and their relationships due to those identities.  The story is set during a summer in San Francisco, and we watch these characters go through profound changes against the backdrop of iconic San Francisco events like Bay2Breakers, Folsom Street Fair, and of course, Pride.

I started writing this story while I was in college majoring in theater, gender studies, and music.  to my dismay, I virtually never came across anything about queerness in the ways the ways that I understood or experienced.  I found a deep lack of nuance, critical thinking, and representation...so I was inspired and determined to write songs that gave visibility to these identities, and write a play that confronted these issues head on.

WHAT WE NEED

We are doing this crowdfunding campaign because we have Love & Pride booked at the legendary EXIT Theatre for an 8-show run, this Spring 2019.  This is so exciting because they are one of the oldest independent theaters in San Francisco, and one of the leading grass-roots theater organizations in the country.

The amount we're raising is to cover the cost of materials we need to build a set, and buy costumes and props.  We can not do this without your help!

With a cast of 12, and a play set in 20 different locations, the amount we're raising is the absolute minimum needed to bring our show to life.  Stay tuned for a detailed list of everything we need...

WHAT YOU GET

We are offering special reserved seating as Our Love perk for $25.  You can purchase this ticket for your self, or donate your ticket to a student.  We are currently working with high schools and colleges who are interested in bringing a group of their students to see the show.  This ticket is open-ended, so you can choose which date to see the show later.  The date must be chosen by February 28.  We will email you by February 28 to see which date you want to reserve your seats.  

We will share the process of designing and producing a musical by showing you all the costumes, props, and set pieces we are able to buy with your donations!

WHY THIS IS IMPORTANT

Inequality, prejudice, and violence against queer, trans and non-binary folks are still prevalent all over the world.  While this play centers on the topics of gender and sexuality, it is ultimately about the universal themes of finding your true self and learning to love others for who they truly are.  My hopes for this project that it fosters dialogue about complex and controversial topics, and creates awareness for marginalized communities - so that we can all relate to the struggles and joys of love, and be proud of that love, no matter how we identify.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please Like and Follow all of our pages and help Spread the Word about this show by sharing this campaign and our social media with your networks!

https://igg.me/at/loveandpridethemusicalEXIT

Website: loveandpridethemusical.com

Instagram: @loveandpridethemusical

Facebook: @loveandpridethemusical

Any amount and every share truly helps and will be very much appreciated! 

This is more than a musical, it's a movement...share your Love & Pride!

story:
Worth A Flutter? Worth A look?

Worth A Flutter is a gritty hard hitting comedy. Based on real life experiences and events 'Worth A Flutter' covers hard hitting issues such as domestic violence, the breakup of a marriage following the death of a child and growing up in a single parent family to a mother with mental health issues while aiming to entertain and make you smile and laugh, as from our experiences laughter is the best medicine.

Written by Michael Head, directed by Jonathon Carr and starring a stellar cast including Paul Danan, Lucy Pinder, award nominated Jack Harding and Claire Mcnamara 'Worth A Flutter' aims to make you laugh and cry while tackling important issues. Worth a flutter is a working class story by a working class writer and producer and we feel it is important that these voices are heard and still have a important role in society and theatre. With out your help projects like this are not sustainable or possible.

Reviews for Michael' other plays include

'More laughs from the stall than at any other show I can recall' Broadway World

'Touching and engaging' The Stage

'Michael Head is a master of his craft' Boyz

'Rollacoaster of emotion, Head's play will make you laugh and cry and then cry with laughter' MTM Reviews

'Think Monty Phyton meets Blackadder with memories of the Fast Show' Ham And High

With your help we aim to make this production not only the entertaining to date but also the most relevant to today's society. 

Why are we worth a Flutter?

We are aiming to raise £3,000 to help toward production costs, fringe theatre is always done on a tight budget but a little help will go a long way towards costs such as rehearsal space, advertising and of course wages of actors and creatives. Any help towards our goal will help with the production costs and the magical 'break even figure' that all fringe theatre strives for, any profit will not be given to the producers but to the creatives, cast and director that made this project happen. In exchange for your kind donations we aim to make your 'flutter' pay off with exciting rewards to show our appreciation. Even if we do not reach our goal all funds raised will help make 'Worth A Flutter' a show to remember! 

Why back this horse?

LAPA have produced over 15 shows and all have been well received by audiences, industry and theatre critiques so first and foremost we entertain. LAPA also feel working with working class writer Michael Head helps tell a narrative that is maybe sometimes lost in a theatre world which is often called elitist, so the chance for Michael to showcase his work and talent in the multi award winning Hope Theatre with an amazing cast is a real honour but also a risk as is all theatre. Not being a huge production company LAPA are hoping to raise funds in order to help pay the costs of the production and hopefully help them continue the work we have been doing for over 8 years, creating opportunities for actors and creatives, telling important stories and most importantly entertaining the audiences.   

If you can donate to this production we will be very grateful and hope you will enjoy the perks and rewards that we have to offer. We also understand not everyone has the funds to donate but if you can please share our story and campaign on any social media platform we would also be very grateful 

Thank you for taking the time to read this and we hope you feel we are well 'worth a flutter'

story:
Short Summary

Moonwater Dance Project is a contemporary dance company built on the idea that dance and humanity go hand in hand. It is of the utmost importance that we focus on the ethical treatment of dancers through collaborative creation, showcasing the duality of the strength and softness all individuals have.

Moonwater Dance Project strives to focus on what should really matter: artistry, individuality and the ability to be vulnerable. The aesthetic of Moonwater Dance Project is similar to water and has a captivating duality. Both are soft yet strong, both nurturing and destructive; a force to be reckoned with and unpredictable. 

What We Need 

  • Our first performance is coming up in June and we need support to help us with the costs of the theater, rehearsal space, paying choreographers and dancers, etc. 
  • If we reach our entire goal, the funds will go towards making sure the artists get paid for contributing their artistic voice to the community and continuing to make art. 

The Impact

  • Moonwater is devoted to the message that a dancer's talent should not take a backseat to their packaging. Dancers are constantly judged on superficial qualities and are often left with a sense of low self-worth. Because of this, dancers are willing to accept little to no payment for their work, which is not a sustainable way of life. 
  • We are continually inspired by the duality of water and mirror that through our all-female company, highlighting women's strength and fluidity. 
  • If we reach our goal and are able to put on a successful show, we would like to start reaching out to dance programs and studios to encourage female dancers to know their worth and their strength and help them harness it.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share our website, Facebook, Instagram, videos, come to our show and don't underestimate the power of word of mouth!
  • Thank you so much for your consideration of Moonwater Dance Project, we appreciate you taking the time to read about us and our campaign!
