Please share our website, Facebook, Instagram, videos, come to our show and don't underestimate the power of word of mouth!
Thank you so much for your consideration of Moonwater Dance Project, we appreciate you taking the time to read about us and our campaign!

story:
Did you see Tenderloin, Cutting Ball’s documentary-style play about our neighborhood, back in 2012?

A team of actors, armed with tape recorders and curiosity, took to the streets of the Tenderloin to interview its denizens - and from those conversations, we made a play. A vibrant collage of our local community, Tenderloin amplified the neglected voices of the neighborhood and fortified our own commitment to enriching and championing its people. Now, to mark our 20th anniversary, Cutting Ball is bringing Tenderloin back in a taut one-hour production that will tour the neighborhood to reach Tenderloin residents.

Will you help us bring this tour to the community that inspired the play?

What We Need

Our most popular show to date, the 2012 production of Tenderloin captivated audiences from  throughout the Bay Area - but not a lot of those viewers came from our own neighborhood. We’ve since learned that to reach our local community with our artistic programming, we need to bring the art out into the community. That's why The Tenderloin Tour will visit community locations throughout our city blocks with free performances for neighborhood citizens in January 2019. And this is where we need your help: can you donate towards our $8,000 goal, covering production costs to bring The Tenderloin Tour to the people of the Tenderloin?

The Impact

Cutting Ball has been making work in the Tenderloin since 1999. Seven years ago, we commissioned local theater-maker Annie Elias to create a piece that would shed light on our neighborhood and on the daily experiences of Tenderloin residents, in their own voices. The result? A stunning ensemble-generated play that brought the vitality, chaos, and complexity of the neighborhood to our stage.

Today, rapid shifts in San Francisco’s economic landscape have left its most fraught neighborhood especially vulnerable. As gentrification becomes an increasingly divisive force in our city, The Tenderloin Tour aims to forge bonds between the diverse populations living within our city blocks, cultivating a more unified Tenderloin. Every performance will be followed by a facilitated discussion, led by a member of the local community, reflecting on the issue's facing the Tenderloin now and building frameworks for the future.

Risks & Challenges

Reaching our neighborhood community with our art can be tricky. Even with our pay-what-you-can plan for Tenderloin residents, the theater is not a space where all people feel comfortable. That's why, rather than bringing our neighbors to see this show, we're bringing the show to our neighbors. 

Other Ways You Can Donate

Help us spread the word about this campaign and The Tenderloin Tour! Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, by e-mail, or through whatever platform you use to reach your crew.

story:
About The Speakeasy Society

We're an LA based immersive entertainment company creating intimate and epic experiences in unexpected places.  By crafting shared experiences where audience interaction is vital to the performance, our approach to immersive world-building is unique. Our work is primarily text-based and crafted for a mid-size audience, characterized by our commitment to creating a narrative where each audience member plays a specific role in the experience, and their actions impact their overall journey through the performance. 

Our Story

The Speakeasy Society was officially formed in a women’s restroom at California Institute of the Arts (CalArts) in 2012. Longtime collaborators Julianne Just, Genevieve Gearhart and Matthew Bamberg-Johnson, created “The Weird Sisters,” a witch-centric adaptation of Macbeth that gave audience members a new and personal experience of the classic narrative. Almost seven years and 22 unique productions later (33 including remounts) the company is quickly becoming identified as the industry standard for what is achievable for independent theatre companies in Los Angeles.

In the future, we want to continue increasing the scale and complexity of our work to meet the demands of an increasingly savvy immersive theatre audience while offering a space where hundreds of uninitiated newcomers to the immersive scene can have their first experience with the genre. After "The Johnny Cycle" we will begin development on a new project inspired by Greek mythology but experienced through a modern lens. The goal of this project is to create a show with the universal appeal of “Sleep No More” and the intimacy of “Then She Fell” that can run for years in a dedicated location. The kind of work that redefines a scene in a city; that can redefine the city itself.   

Achieving growth at a large scale requires time and dedicated focus. This means greater periods of incubation, testing, adjustment, workshops, revision - a process that requires financial, institutional support and partnership. And while we are very excited about our existing partnerships - we are looking forward to expanding and creating relationships with new institutions.

We hope to bring our work to broader audiences, increasing recognition of the art form of immersive theater internationally and in our own backyard, while situating the western United States as the definitive leader in the immersive movement.

Our Goal

In order to reach $23k, your support is crucial. Crowdfunding will enable us to: 

  • Keep ticket prices reasonable (with many immersive experiences costing $2/minute and some approaching $3/minute, your support ensures that audiences get a singular experience for a fair price.) 
  • Compensate our collaborators at a higher rate - as we grow, we want to make sure that we fairly compensate the artists who help make our shows so amazing!
  • Increase our investment in new technical equipment to make our magic even more seamless in the shows to come
  • Help us raise enough funds to extend the show in order to reach even more audiences!
  • Donors can expect access to pre-sale tickets, exclusive VIP content, behind the scene tours, cast meet-and-greets, and more!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


The Impact

"The Johnny Cycle" interrogates the cost of what it takes to “keep the world safe for democracy.” It offers few prescriptions or answers, but encourages us all to question our role in the decisions that cause young men and women to fight and die in other people’s wars.

The piece not only adapts the Dalton Trumbo novel, but highlights Trumbo’s own struggle through his trial with the House Un-American Activities committee, a sadly relevant experience in a political climate where voices of reason are silenced as inconvenient to the ruling narrative.

We can speak the truth, but who will listen?

Trumbo's Legacy

We are honored to be producing "The Johnny Cycle" with the full support of the Trumbo estate. Samantha Trumbo, Dalton's granddaughter, had the opportunity to come experience "Johnny: The Living", in 2017.  After the performance, she expressed that experiencing the piece helped her to understand the life and work of her grandfather.  The family has expressed that the more people experience this piece, the happier they will be.  And that is truly the highest praise we could hope to receive.  

“The Johnny Cycle” is an undeniably memorable evening spent in with a supremely talented cast in an extraordinary location exploring the themes of belief, patriotism, and death. It’s an incredibly interesting alternative in a form flooded with horror stories, and I highly recommend checking it out. - INSIDE THE MAGIC

This is an emotionally charged, politically fascinating, intricately woven thrill ride. The odd mix of history, fiction and philosophy unfolds in scenes of intense mystery and melancholy. Sound a little bit heavy? Maybe, it is. But rest assured it is a concoction designed to thrill. All you have to do is give yourself over to it. - MY HAUNT LIFE
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to donate? No problem. Here are other ways to help us reach our goal:

  • Purchase tickets to see The Johnny Cycle starting July 15

  • Share our crowdfunding link with your network 

  • Follow The Speakeasy Society on social media ( @thespeakeasysoc)

To all of our donors and friends, thank you.
-The Speakeasy Society

From L-R: Julianne Just (Artistic Director), Chris Porter (Associate Artistic Director), Matthew Bamberg-Johnson  (Artistic Director), John Henningsen (Producing Director) and Genevieve Gearhart (Artistic Director). Not pictured: Michael Bates (Associate Artistic Director), Andrew Lia, (Production Manager)

“The Johnny Cycle” is an undeniably memorable evening spent in with a supremely talented cast in an extraordinary location exploring the themes of belief, patriotism, and death. It’s an incredibly interesting alternative in a form flooded with horror stories, and I highly recommend checking it out. - INSIDE THE MAGIC
This is an emotionally charged, politically fascinating, intricately woven thrill ride. The odd mix of history, fiction and philosophy unfolds in scenes of intense mystery and melancholy. Sound a little bit heavy? Maybe, it is. But rest assured it is a concoction designed to thrill. All you have to do is give yourself over to it. - MY HAUNT LIFE 

Other Ways You Can Help
Not able to donate? No problem. Here are other ways to help us reach our goal:

Purchase tickets to see The Johnny Cycle starting July 15
Share our crowdfunding link with your network 
Follow The Speakeasy Society on social media ( @thespeakeasysoc)

To all of our donors and friends, thank you.-The Speakeasy Society

From L-R: Julianne Just (Artistic Director), Chris Porter (Associate Artistic Director), Matthew Bamberg-Johnson  (Artistic Director), John Henningsen (Producing Director) and Genevieve Gearhart (Artistic Director). Not pictured: Michael Bates (Associate Artistic Director), Andrew Lia, (Production Manager)

story:
Why are we taking this show to Europe?

SF Youth Theatre has been accepted into an international festival of student theatre, and we think it’s a great opportunity to bring our work to a bigger audience!

  • Our production of Gary Soto’s The Afterlife has made a positive impact on thousands of young people and families in San Francisco and Northern California, and we’re eager to bring it to an international group of students and theatre educators.
  • In addition to a once-in-a-lifetime performance opportunity, SFYT DREAM Ensemble Members will also have the unique opportunity to collaborate with young actors from across the globe in classes and workshops.
  • SFYT DREAM Ensemble is a talented troupe of emerging theatre professionals, largely composed of students of color from low-income backgrounds, ages 18-24; most have had little opportunity to travel internationally. Since several SFYT actors originate from conflict areas in Mexico and Central America, they will be able to learn from, and bring insight and understanding to students from other world conflict areas.

Help us make this trip a reality and increase SFYT’s visibility locally and internationally!

How you can help.

Your donation to this project will support:

  • Air travel, ground transportation, and per diems for all of the SFYT artists attending this event. You’ll also help in funding transport of the sets, costumes, and props to Bosnia and Herzegovina!
  • We have lots of amazing perks for folks who donate to our campaign. Depending on the amount of your donation, you have the opportunity to receive everything from raffle tickets to our Grand Raffle, an original song composed by SFYT Executive Director Emily Klion, or a private concert from George Brooks and the Elements Trio.

The Impact

Your contribution will do much  more than get SFYT and our gear to Europe:

  • The Afterlife is play about teen death and suicide. Gary Soto approaches these topics with a gentle touch, and the reminder that life is valuable is an important one to bring to a wider, international audience.
  • SFYT has completed several successful regional tours. We have experience on the road and are ready to put that knowledge to use on a trip overseas!
  • We are one of only 10 companies chosen for this festival from over 80 applicants. We’re honored by the invitation and are looking forward to the experience.

SFYT is inspired and ready to go!

We know that an international tour will not be easy, and we’re already preparing for those challenges.

  • The Afterlife has been touring Central and Northern California this year, so we already have portable sets, props, and costumes. We are actively collaborating with our designers to make things even more minimal for plane travel.
  • Cast members and designers are working to make sure they have the proper travel documents to make the trip smooth.
  • The festival will provide SFYT with lodging and meals while we are there, so we just need to raise airfare and provide some actor and designer fees!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, we’d love your help in other ways:

  • Share this campaign with friends and family on social media and via email.
  • Do you have miles to donate? We'd love to have them. 
  • Consider sponsoring an individual student. 
  • Let us know if you have any knowledge about traveling to this part of the world. We’d love your tips--everything from transportation tips to restaurant recommendations !
  • Know of other funding sources? Please tell us!

story:
Here's the gist of it all:

ONE SHOW LEFT!  Thank YOU, for stopping by and giving me a chance to tell you why you should invest your hard earned money on this project.

My name is Pamela Najera.  I am a 48 year old Filipina-American!

I have been fortunate enough to have experiences in life that have lead me to writing this production.  This show is my legacy and I hope that it moves, touches, and inspires women, immigrants and the vertically challenged in ways that motivate them to go for their wildest imagination.  Or at the very least, listen to that divine whisper guiding them to do some crazy idea and follow that impulse that moves them closer to their dreams...because that is exactly what happened to me.

I first intended to create this campaign to fund the expenses of this project.  But it wasn't enough to get this message out there to create a shift in the audience about themselves and their lives.  I also wanted to contribute to a non-profit organization that I utilized during my transition from life on the 'ocean', to living back in the real world. 

'The Actors Fund'  

https://actorsfund.org/services-and-programs/ca...

 

What your hard earned money will be providing:

Supporting Live Theater! Who knows? This could be your destiny of creating your own show and I will certainly reciprocate!

My total budget for the three Hollywood performances of "Too Old, Too Asian, Too Short" is ($5,000.00).

This includes paying my director/stage manager. 

Theatre rental/insurance for rehearsals and performances.

Hiring technicians for sound /lighting design and running the board.

Video/audio editing.

Hiring technicians for recording and editing the show.

Designing and producing postcard, posters, and multi-media marketing. 

20% of the proceeds will be going to The Actors Fund {$1,000.00}.

Your kind donations would be an awesome expression of your support for this project.

In the event that this campaign raises more than $5000.00, the extra funds will go towards the proceeds and to feed C. C.!

My third and final show of  "Too Old, Too Asian, Too Short" will be

THIS FRDAY ~ June 28th @ 10 p.m. ~ The Lounge Theatre ~ 6201 Santa Monica Blvd ~ Hollwood

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends and family!  Here is the link to the Fringe Festival Website. 

https://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/5864

If this campaign sparks any ideas in you of other organizations that can be included in future campaigns, please contact me at: https://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/5864

story:
Short Summary

Movement Headquarters Ballet Company is New York's newest dance organization headed by Artistic Director and award-winning choreographer Barry Kerollis.

Our company seeks to bring ballet back to the forefront of New York City's concert dance scene through innovative, engaging works that range in style from ballet to contemporary dance theatre for main stage performances and installation events accessible to the general public. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $28,000 in donations to build a strong foundation for our premiere season. Our top priorities for this money are our dancers' salaries and rehearsal/performance spaces; the building blocks of our company and our work.

Beyond these expenses, we need to budget money for costuming, pointe shoes, stage management, lighting design, marketing, and media, as well as fees from our fiscal sponsor that allow us to make your donations to Movement Headquarters tax-deductible. 

Your donation helps us hire local artists and build dance programming for you, the dance community, and the general public. It also sends a message that people in the tri-state area want more accessible avenues to see and participate in ballet programming.

There is a dearth of ballet programming happening outside of major troupes such as ABT and New York City Ballet. For example: each year, the Joyce Theatre programs a mid-summer ballet festival, where they regularly commission outside companies and local dancers to perform in works created by a variety of choreographers--yet, there has been little local representation beyond New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theatre on this program for years. We want to bring ballet to the forefront of the concert dance scene in New York City, and your donation has the potential to inspire that change.

The Impact

The lack of new ballet choreography outside of major companies limits audience options when it comes to arts entertainment, and it means local artists are working less and are finding less opportunities to nurture their artistic growth.

By helping us build an appropriate foundation for New York's next great dance organization, you are investing in the future of our city's artists and our city's culture, and making a statement that ballet is still alive and kicking in the capital of the dance world.

Risks & Challenges

It is challenging just to start a dance company in New York City, and maintaining and growing the company present a completely new, unique set of challenges. The dance community recently lost Jessica Lang Dance, one of the gems of our city, when the company closed its doors due to the overwhelming costs it takes to produce new work in New York. While there is great support for major established dance organizations in our city, there is very little assistance for us smaller organizations--outside of private donations. In the early stages of building what we hope will become a world class arts organization, we rely on the support and generosity of individuals who see our potential and wish to be a part of it. Without these donors, we do not exist. 

 

Movement Headquarters Ballet Company seeks, not only to get off the ground, but to build a foundation to allow ourselves to grow into a reputable dance organization that stands on its own two legs. I see our company growing over time to a roster of 30 dancers and including innovative works for the stage and in public spaces around the city. We are actively seeking innovative ways to connect with corporate America to fulfill our namesake, and establish ourselves as an organization using movement and dance to inspire outside of the arts, including fields like business and technology.

Other Ways You Can Help

The donation of services, materials, and space can be just as valuable as monetary donations. To build a dance company New York City can be proud to call its own, we will need assistance in accounting, grant writing, videography, photography, fundraising, studio rental, musical collaboration, costuming, props, volunteers at shows, etc. If you think you can be of help to us in any way, please do not be shy in contacting us to have a conversation. Your effort will not go unnoticed, and we will be eternally grateful for your generosity.

 

About The Founder

My name is Barry Kerollis, and I'm an award-winning choreographer, dance educator, and media personality based in New York City. I enjoyed a 13 year performance career, dancing leading roles with Pacific Northwest Ballet, Houston Ballet, and also more recently as a Principal Guest Artist for companies around the country.

Aside from my role as Artistic Director of Movement Headquarters Ballet Company, I teach on faculty at Broadway Dance Center and Steps on Broadway, write for Dance Media publications, and host my own podcast: Pas de Chát: Talking Dance on the Premier Dance Network.  I've been featured extensively in Dance Magazine, Dance Teacher, Inside Dance, and Pointe, and have received recognition from Dance/USA as an influencer.  I want to make good upon that recognition by creating a future for the ballet and contemporary dance world in New York City that works outside of the major, established box for strong and interesting new work to take shape.

story:
The Goal

Crux Of It Theatre are extremely passionate about bringing theatre to a wide range of audiences. The Edinburgh Fringe Festival provides us with the perfect opportunity to do this! Being the biggest arts festival in the world, nowhere else would seem fitting for us to have our company debut. While we are excited for the summer ahead, we are embarking on a very costly month for a new theatre company. We are therefore reaching out for donations to help us pay for our venue hire!

 

The Show

When Dave dies and is sent back to the living, only visible to his best friend Jimmy, It soon becomes clear their reunion is more of a curse than a blessing. Together, Jimmy and Dave must discover how to break down the walls between the living and the dead so that Dave can pass over.

This comedy-drama explores friendship, love, life and death and what would happen if our loved ones never truly left us. 

The show has been described as "laugh out loud funny" with "heart warming sentimentality" from audiences last year. After 2 highly successful runs, My Mate Dave Died has been met with universal acclaim from audiences and reviewers alike. However, we have always dealt with the limitation of time on our performance span - our longest run so far has been a week. We believe that taking My Mate Dave Died to the Fringe this August for the entirety of the festival will give the show it's best shot yet - giving more audiences the chance to see what we believe to be a well-loved and unforgettable story.

You can catch the show at C Venues Aquila Temple from the 1st - 26th of August 2019 (no performance on the 12th). Contains strong language, scenes of a sexual nature, nudity, drug related death and references to suicide. Age category: 14+

 

The Company

 Crux of It Theatre is a Sheffield- based theatre company that aim to tell stories that will warm your heart and open your mind. 
We are an inherently British company. What we create feels grounded in the reality of the UK and this is important to us. Beyond that, we’re not afraid to tackle dark and often challenging subject matter, we aim to make our audiences consider what is important to them, and leave our shows having gone through a range of emotions. 


Previous Work

Bringing together students and graduates from the University of Sheffield, our company members have worked together on various projects over the past two years. They all met through the Sheffield University Theatre Company (SUTCo) but have worked with numerous theatre companies independent of the University, including Paperfinch Theatre, Dear Hunter Theatre, Bunce and Malone and Colla Voce. The company has experience at performing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and many members have worked on award winning shows which were selected for the National Student Drama Festival 2016, 2017 and 2018.  

 

Previous 'My Mate Dave Died' Performances

11th-14th October 2017 – Sheffield University Drama Studio **SOLD OUT**

20th-25th August 2018 - Greenside Forrest Theatre- Edinburgh Fringe Festival **SOLD OUT**

 

Previous Acclaim

‘I’m happy to say that My Mate Dave Died is the best new play I’ve seen and I’d happily watch it again and again’ - Last Night I Dreamt Of

‘My Mate Dave Died exceeded my expectations, combining comedy and numerous relationships to explore life after death and the supple boundaries of friendships.’ - Forge Press

Winner of ‘Last Night I Dreamt Of’ Best New Play of 2017

Winner of ‘Chrisparkle’ Best Edinburgh Fringe Play 2018
 

Donations

Though there are no set sums we are asking to be donated, please see the 'perks' section of the campaign to see how you can get a selection of donation thank you gifts! All donations will be greatly appreciated.

story:
Unison – An Evening Supporting Israeli Excellence in Dance

Unison Dance Academy is one of Israel's leading dance schools, and the home for outstanding dancers who have received top placements in the world's leading amateur dance competitions. In this unique evening of dance, they will perform masterpieces of leading Israeli choreographers such as Ohad Naharin, Inbal Pinto, and Avshalom Pollak, as well as other outstanding contemporary pieces. 

Featured professional dancers:

Maayan Sheinfeld -Betsheva Dance Company

Bret Easterling- BE MOVING

Julia Eichten- LA Dance Project 

Austin Dale Tyson- Galim Dance Company, Sleep no more of Punchdrunk

 

These professionals will perform alongside Unison dancers.  

This is a non-profit event and all proceeds will be dedicated to providing scholarships for outstanding Israeli dancers.

story:
The Team

Helen Cox, Susie MacDonald, Holly Mainstone, Catherine Manwaring, Amelia Mehra

The Project

We are utterly delighted to announce that we will be living and working in Mumbai, India for 4 weeks in May/June!

We are excited to collaboratively create, explore, and devise stories with children, young people, and women's groups. We will also have the opportunity to work with teachers to incorporate creativity and drama into their daily practice, ensuring the sustainability of our project even after we leave.

The Manifesto 

  • Respect
  • Inclusion
  • Equality
  • Creativity!
  • Accessibility
  • Positive intent
  • Readiness to adapt
  • Collaboration

The Funding

We are very fortunate to have been awarded funding towards accommodation and flights from the Leverhulme foundation - but we still need your help.

Any donations would go towards project costs, resources and travel in Mumbai. Any extra funds will be donated to the schools and organisations we work with, to ensure the sustainability and longevity of the project - so we would be immensely grateful for any donation you can make!

The Social Media 

Facebook: https://fb.me/rounddoortheatre

Twitter: @rounddoortheatr

Instagram: @rounddoortheatre

The TeamHelen Cox, Susie MacDonald, Holly Mainstone, Catherine Manwaring, Amelia MehraThe ProjectWe are utterly delighted to announce that we will be living and working in Mumbai, India for 4 weeks in May/June!We are excited to collaboratively create, explore, and devise stories with children, young people, and women's groups. We will also have the opportunity to work with teachers to incorporate creativity and drama into their daily practice, ensuring the sustainability of our project even after we leave.The Manifesto 
Respect
Inclusion
Equality
Creativity!
Accessibility
Positive intent
Readiness to adapt
Collaboration
The FundingWe are very fortunate to have been awarded funding towards accommodation and flights from the Leverhulme foundation - but we still need your help.Any donations would go towards project costs, resources and travel in Mumbai. Any extra funds will be donated to the schools and organisations we work with, to ensure the sustainability and longevity of the project - so we would be immensely grateful for any donation you can make!The Social Media Facebook: https://fb.me/rounddoortheatreTwitter: @rounddoortheatrInstagram: @rounddoortheatre

story:
The Show

After narrowly escaping the horrors of slavery, Idabelle arrives to the North only to discover the Fugitive Slave Act has made it impossible for her to find honest work. With no other choice, she joins the women of Pinky’s Pleasure House where she is confronted by a wealthy Southern-planter who finds the women-run business disturbing. After an intense altercation in the privacy of her room, Idabelle and the women are faced with a life-or-death dilemma that tests their morality and questions the value of revenge.

Fancy Maids explores a dark chapter in America's history with a new lens. Turning the focus away from a plantation narrative, the play explores the lasting effects of slavery.

Read more about the production here: https://www.broadwayworld.com/off-off-broadway/...

What We Need & What You Get

Words can't describe how excited we are to have the opportunity to bring this show back to the stage. Not only is it a moving experience for us to perform this show. but it touches all who see it, but we need your help to make it happen! Every cent you donate helps and offest; 

  • Marketing Materials 
  • Lighting Design 
  • Sound Design 
  • Transportation of Props/Set to the Theater
